Utah Code Annotated - Title 10 - Utah Municipal Code
====================================================

Utah Code Annotated - Title 10 - Chapter 1 - General Provisions
***************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-101 Short title.
-------------------------------------------
This act shall be known and may be cited as the "Utah Municipal Code." In enacting this code, it is the legislative intent to repeal only those provisions of Utah law set forth in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-102 Effective date.
----------------------------------------------
This act shall become effective July 1, 1977.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-103 Construction.
--------------------------------------------
The powers herein delegated to any municipality shall be liberally construed to permit the municipality to exercise the powers granted by this act except in cases clearly contrary to the intent of the law.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-104 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this title:Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-104(1): 10-2-301 "City" means a municipality that is classified by population as a city of the first class, a city of the second class, a city of the third class, a city of the fourth class, or a city of the fifth class, under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-104(2): "Contiguous" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-104(2)(a): if used to described an area, continuous, uninterrupted, and without an island of territory not included as part of the area; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-104(2)(b): if used to describe an area's relationship to another area, sharing a common boundary.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-104(3): "Governing body" means collectively the legislative body and the executive of any municipality.  Unless otherwise provided:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-104(3)(a): in a city of the first or second class, the governing body is the city commission;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-104(3)(b): in a city of the third, fourth, or fifth class, the governing body is the city council; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-104(3)(c): in a town, the governing body is the town council.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-104(4): "Municipal" means of or relating to a municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-104(5): 10-2-301 "Municipality" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-104(5)(a): a city of the first class, city of the second class, city of the third class, city of the fourth class, city of the fifth class;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-104(5)(b): 10-2-301 a town, as classified in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-104(5)(c): a preliminary municipality incorporated under Chapter 2a, Part 5, Incorporation of a Preliminary Municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-104(6): "Peninsula," when used to describe an unincorporated area, means an area surrounded on more than 1/2 of its boundary distance, but not completely, by incorporated territory and situated so that the length of a line drawn across the unincorporated area from an incorporated area to an incorporated area on the opposite side shall be less than 25% of the total aggregate boundaries of the unincorporated area.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-104(7): "Person" means an individual, corporation, partnership, organization, association, trust, governmental agency, or any other legal entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-104(8): "Provisions of law" shall include other statutes of the state of Utah and ordinances, rules, and regulations properly adopted by any municipality unless the construction is clearly contrary to the intent of state law.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-104(9): "Recorder," unless clearly inapplicable, includes and applies to a town clerk.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-104(10): 10-2-301 "Town" means a municipality classified by population as a town under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-104(11): "Unincorporated" means not within a municipality.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-105 No changes intended.
---------------------------------------------------
Unless otherwise specifically provided in this act, the provisions of this act may not operate in any way to affect the property or contract rights or other actions which may exist in favor of or against any municipality.  Nor shall this act operate in any way to change or affect any ordinance, order or resolution in force in any municipality and such ordinances, orders and resolutions which are not repugnant to law, shall continue in full force and effect until repealed or amended.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-106 Scope of act.
--------------------------------------------
This act shall apply to all municipalities incorporated or existing under the law of the State of Utah except as otherwise specifically excepted by the home rule provisions of Article XI, Section 5 of the Constitution of the State of Utah.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-107 Municipalities.
----------------------------------------------
All municipalities which have been incorporated under any previous act of the United States or of the State of Utah shall be treated as properly incorporated under this act.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-108 Cumulative powers -- Powers not in derogation of state agencies.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The provisions of this act or any other act not expressly repealed by Section

Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-109 Saving clause.
---------------------------------------------
The repeal of the titles, chapters and sections specified in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 10-1-109(1): affect suits pending or rights existing immediately prior to the effective date of this act;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-109(2): impair, avoid, or affect any grant or conveyance made or right acquired or cause of action now existing under any repealed act or amendment thereto; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-109(3): 10-1-114 affect or impair the validity of any bonds or other obligation issued or sold prior to the effective date of this act.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-110 Continuation of prior law.
---------------------------------------------------------
The provisions of this act insofar as they are the same or substantially the same as those of any prior statute shall be construed as a continuation of the prior statute and not as a new enactment. If any other statutory reference is made to an act of the Legislature or a section of such an act, which is continued in this act, the reference shall be held to refer to the act or section thereof so continued in this act.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-111 Existing indebtedness.
-----------------------------------------------------
Any bond or other evidence of indebtedness issued under the provisions of any act repealed by this act which is outstanding and unpaid as of July 1, 1977, shall be amortized and retired by taxation or revenue in the manner provided by the act under which such indebtedness was incurred, notwithstanding repeal or change of the act.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-112 Headings do not limit sections.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Title, chapter, part, or section headings contained herein may not be deemed to govern, limit, modify or in any manner affect the scope, meaning or intent of the provisions of any title, chapter, part or section of this act.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-113 Severability clause.
---------------------------------------------------
If any chapter, part, section, paragraph or subsection of this act, or the application thereof is held to be invalid, the remainder of this act is not affected thereby.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-114 Repealer.
----------------------------------------


Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-115 Legislation enacted by Legislature.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Nothing in this act shall be construed to repeal any section of the various laws of which this act is comprised when the section is the subject of an amendment or new legislation enacted by this 42nd session of the Utah legislature and which becomes law. Furthermore, it is the intent of the legislature that the corresponding sections of this act shall be construed with such amended sections so as to give effect to the amendment as if it were made a part of this act.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-201 Municipalities as political subdivisions of the state.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Municipalities shall be political subdivisions of the State of Utah, municipal corporations, and bodies politic with perpetual existence unless disincorporated according to law.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-201.5 Metro townships converted to municipalities -- Classification -- Form of government -- Continuity of operations.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-201.5(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-201.5(1)(a): "Converted municipality" means a municipality that is converted from an incorporated township into a municipality under Subsection (2).
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-201.5(1)(b): "Incorporated township" means a metro township incorporated under Laws of Utah 2015, Chapter 352, Sections 50 through 62.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-201.5(2): As of May 1, 2024, an incorporated township is automatically converted into a municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-201.5(3): 10-2-301 The classification of a converted municipality is governed by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-201.5(4): 10-3b-601(1); 10-3b-606
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-201.5(4)(a): The powers of municipal government of a converted municipality are vested in a five-member council, as provided in Chapter 3b, Part 4, Five-Member Council Form of Municipal Government.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-201.5(4)(b): Subsection (4)(a) does not limit a converted municipality's ability to change the converted municipality's form of government, as provided in Chapter 3b, Part 6, Changing to Another Form of Municipal Government.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-201.5(4)(c): 10-3b-601(1); 10-3b-606
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-201.5(4)(c)(i): 10-3b-601(1) Notwithstanding Chapter 3b, Part 6, Changing to Another Form of Municipal Government, the council of a converted municipality may, by a resolution adopted before July 1, 2024 by two-thirds of all council members, change the converted municipality's form of government to another form listed in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-201.5(4)(c)(ii): 10-3b-606 If a converted municipality's form of government is changed under Subsection (4)(c)(i), the election of municipal officers under the new form of government is governed by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-201.5(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-201.5(5)(a): The members of a converted municipality's council on May 1, 2024 consist of the individuals serving as council members for the incorporated township immediately before the incorporated township was converted into a municipality under Subsection (2), with the mayor of the incorporated township becoming the mayor of the converted municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-201.5(5)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-201.5(5)(b)(i): Subject to Subsection (4)(c), if applicable, and to Subsection (5)(b)(ii), the term of office of a member of the converted municipality's council on May 1, 2024 is the same as the term of office that would have applied to the council member if the incorporated township had not converted to a municipality under Subsection (2).
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-201.5(5)(b)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-201.5(5)(b)(ii)(A): The office of mayor of a converted municipality is subject to election beginning the first municipal election after the incorporated township converts to a municipality under Subsection (2).
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-201.5(5)(b)(ii)(B): The term of office of the mayor of a converted municipality continues from May 1, 2024 until a successor to the office of mayor is elected and qualified.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-201.5(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-201.5(6)(a): Upon an incorporated township's conversion to a municipality under Subsection (2):
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-201.5(6)(a)(i): each ordinance, resolution, or policy of the incorporated township becomes the ordinance, resolution, or policy of the converted municipality;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-201.5(6)(a)(ii): the converted municipality may continue to:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-201.5(6)(a)(ii)(A): operate and function as the incorporated township had been operating and functioning before the conversion; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-201.5(6)(a)(ii)(B): provide services the incorporated township had been providing before the conversion;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-201.5(6)(a)(iii): a converted municipality may, after the conversion, continue to impose and collect a tax, fee, fine, or other charge that the incorporated township was authorized to impose and collect before the conversion;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-201.5(6)(a)(iv): a proceeding pending before the incorporated township at the time of conversion continues without change before the converted municipality;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-201.5(6)(a)(v): a right or privilege of the incorporated township becomes the right or privilege of the converted municipality; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-201.5(6)(a)(vi): a contractual or other obligation of the incorporated township, including a contractual or other obligation with another governmental entity, becomes the contractual or other obligation of the converted municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-201.5(6)(b): An ordinance that under Subsection (6)(a)(i) becomes an ordinance of the converted municipality includes a county ordinance that became an ordinance of the incorporated township under Laws of Utah 2016, Chapter 176, Section 2 and has not been repealed, subject to any amendment of that ordinance that the incorporated township enacted before the incorporated township's conversion to a municipality under Subsection (2).
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-201.5(7): A converted municipality succeeds to the position of the incorporated township with respect to the incorporated township's participation or inclusion in a special district or special service district, including a municipal services district.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-202 Power to sue, contract, adopt municipal name and seal.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Municipalities may sue and be sued, enter into contracts and by ordinance adopt a municipal name and seal which may be changed from time to time.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(5)(a):

Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(5)(a)(i)(C)(II): a purchaser from a business for which the municipality provides an enhanced level of municipal services.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(5)(b)(ii)(A): that primarily provides off-street parking services for a public facility that is wholly or partially funded by public money;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(5)(b)(ii)(B): that provides parking for one or more vehicles; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(5)(b)(ii)(C): that charges a fee for parking.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(5)(b)(iii)(A): is wholly or partially funded by public money;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(5)(b)(iii)(B): is operated by a business; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(5)(b)(iii)(C): requires a person attending an event at the assembly facility to purchase a ticket.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(5)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(5)(c)(i): Before the legislative body of a municipality imposes a license fee on a business that causes disproportionate costs of municipal services under Subsection (5)(a)(i)(C)(I), the legislative body of the municipality shall adopt an ordinance defining for purposes of the tax under Subsection (5)(a)(i)(C)(I):
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(5)(c)(i)(A): the costs that constitute disproportionate costs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(5)(c)(i)(B): the amounts that are reasonably related to the costs of the municipal services provided by the municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(5)(c)(ii): The amount of a fee under Subsection (5)(a)(i)(C)(I) shall be reasonably related to the costs of the municipal services provided by the municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(5)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(5)(d)(i): Before the legislative body of a municipality imposes a license fee on a purchaser from a business for which it provides an enhanced level of municipal services under Subsection (5)(a)(i)(C)(II), the legislative body of the municipality shall adopt an ordinance defining for purposes of the fee under Subsection (5)(a)(i)(C)(II):
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(5)(d)(i)(A): the level of municipal services that constitutes the basic level of municipal services in the municipality; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(5)(d)(i)(B): the amounts that are reasonably related to the costs of providing an enhanced level of municipal services in the municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(5)(d)(ii): The amount of a fee under Subsection (5)(a)(i)(C)(II) shall be reasonably related to the costs of providing an enhanced level of the municipal services.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(6): All license fees and taxes shall be uniform in respect to the class upon which they are imposed.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(7)(a): As used in this Subsection (7):
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(7)(a)(i): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(7)(a)(i)(A): "Event requirement" means a requirement a municipality imposes on individuals who participate in a municipal event.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(7)(a)(i)(B): "Event requirement" does not include a requirement that is inconsistent with Subsection (7)(b).
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(7)(a)(ii): "Exempt individual" means an individual who, under Subsection (7)(b), may not be required to have a business license or permit.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(7)(a)(iii): "Municipal event" means an event hosted or sponsored by a municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(7)(b): A municipality may notrequire a license or permit for a business that is operated:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(7)(b)(i): only occasionally; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(7)(b)(ii): by an individual who is under 19 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(7)(c): Subsection (7)(b) does not prevent a municipality from imposing an event requirement on an exempt individual who participates in a municipal event.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(8): A municipality may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(8)(a): charge any fee for a resident of the municipality to operate a home-based business, unless the combined offsite impact of the home-based business and the primary residential use materially exceeds the offsite impact of the primary residential use alone;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(8)(b): require, as a condition of obtaining or maintaining a license or permit for a business:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(8)(b)(i): that an employee or agent of a business complete education, continuing education, or training that is in addition to requirements under state law or state licensing requirements; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(8)(b)(ii): that a business disclose financial information, inventory amounts, or proprietary business information, except as specifically authorized under state or federal law.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(9): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(9)(a): Notwithstanding Subsection (8)(a), a municipality may charge an administrative fee for a license to a home-based business owner who is otherwise exempt under Subsection (8)(a) but who requests a license from the municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(9)(b): A municipality shall notify the owner of each home-based business of the exemption described in Subsection (8)(a) in any communication with the owner.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(10): The municipality shall transmit the information from each approved business license application to the county assessor within 60 days following the approval of the application.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203(11): If challenged in court, an ordinance enacted by a municipality before January 1, 1994, imposing a business license fee on rental dwellings under this section shall be upheld unless the business license fee is found to impose an unreasonable burden on the fee payer.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203.5 Disproportionate rental fee -- Good landlord training program -- Fee reduction.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203.5(1): (6) As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203.5(1)(a): "Business" means the rental of one or more residential units within a municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203.5(1)(b): "Disproportionate rental fee" means a fee adopted by a municipality to recover its disproportionate costs of providing municipal services to residential rental units compared to similarly-situated owner-occupied housing.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203.5(1)(c): "Disproportionate rental fee reduction" means a reduction of a disproportionate rental fee as a condition of complying with the requirements of a good landlord training program.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203.5(1)(d): "Exempt business" means the rental of a residential unit within a single structure that contains:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203.5(1)(d)(i): no more than four residential units; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-203.5(1)(d)(ii): one unit occupied by the owner.

-----------------------------------------------------
A municipality shall ensure that any training that the municipality requires of a municipal officer or employee complies with

Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-206 Sister municipality restriction.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-206(1): As used in this section, "forced labor" means labor from a child or an adult that is obtained through the use of force or coercion.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-206(2): A municipality may not enter into or renew a sister city agreement or arrangement with another municipality unless the other municipality confirms that there are no forced labor production facilities within the other municipality's borders.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-206(3): An agreement in violation of Subsection (2) is void.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-301 Title.
-------------------------------------
This part shall be known as the "Municipal Energy Sales and Use Tax Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-302 Purpose and intent.
--------------------------------------------------
The Legislature finds that:Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-302(1): the energy industry has previously been highly regulated and monopolistic;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-302(2): municipalities have historically raised town or city, respectively, general fund revenues by collecting franchise and business license revenues from the energy industry;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-302(3): substantial restructuring of the energy industry has created an opportunity for increased competition within the energy industry;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-302(4): the restructuring of the energy industry has diminished the effectiveness and fairness of the revenues collected by municipalities;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-302(5): to provide for a stable revenue source for municipalities and to create a more competitive environment for the energy industry, it is necessary to enact taxing authority for municipalities that accomplishes those goals; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-302(6): this part does not alter or affect the municipalities' authority to grant or regulate franchises, or to control municipal streets, highways, or other property.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-303 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-303(1): "Commission" means the State Tax Commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-303(2): "Contractual franchise fee" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-303(2)(a): a fee:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-303(2)(a)(i): provided for in a franchise agreement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-303(2)(a)(ii): that is consideration for the franchise agreement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-303(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-303(2)(b)(i): a fee similar to Subsection (2)(a); or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-303(2)(b)(ii): any combination of Subsections (2)(a) and (b).
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-303(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-303(3)(a): "Delivered value" means the fair market value of the taxable energy delivered for sale or use in the municipality and includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-303(3)(a)(i): the value of the energy itself; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-303(3)(a)(ii): any transportation, freight, customer demand charges, services charges, or other costs typically incurred in providing taxable energy in usable form to each class of customer in the municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-303(3)(b): "Delivered value" does not include the amount of a tax paid under:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-303(3)(b)(i): Title 59, Chapter 12, Sales and Use Tax Act; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-303(3)(b)(ii): this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-303(4)(a): 5% of the energy supplier's estimated total Utah gross receipts from sales of property or services; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-303(4)(b): $10,000.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-303(5): "Energy supplier" means a person supplying taxable energy, except that the commission may by rule exclude from this definition a person supplying a de minimis amount of taxable energy.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-303(8)(c): any combination of Subsections (8)(a) and (b).

Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-306 Rules for delivered value and point of sale.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-306(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The delivered value of taxable energy under this part shall be established pursuant to rules made by the commission in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-306(2): (1) The rules made by the commission under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-306(2)(a): shall provide that an arm's length sales price for taxable energy sold or used by a taxpayer in the municipality is the delivered value, unless the sales price does not include some portion of the taxable energy or component of delivered value;

Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-306(3)(a): shall take into account quantity discounts and other reductions or increases in value that are generally available in the marketplace for various grades or types of property and classes of services; and

Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-401 Title.
-------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Municipal Telecommunications License Tax Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(1): "Commission" means the State Tax Commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(2): 10-1-407
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(2)(a): Subject to Subsections (2)(b) and (c), "customer" means the person who is obligated under a contract with a telecommunications provider to pay for telecommunications service received under the contract.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(2)(b): 10-1-407 For purposes of this section and Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(2)(b)(i): the person who is obligated under a contract with a telecommunications provider to pay for telecommunications service received under the contract; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(2)(b)(ii): if the end user is not the person described in Subsection (2)(b)(i), the end user of telecommunications service.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(2)(c): "Customer" does not include a reseller:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(2)(c)(i): of telecommunications service; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(2)(c)(ii): for mobile telecommunications service, of a serving carrier under an agreement to serve the customer outside the telecommunications provider's licensed service area.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(3)(a): "End user" means the person who uses a telecommunications service.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(3)(b): For purposes of telecommunications service provided to a person who is not an individual, "end user" means the individual who uses the telecommunications service on behalf of the person who is provided the telecommunications service.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(4)(a): "Gross receipts from telecommunications service" means the revenue that a telecommunications provider receives for telecommunications service rendered except for amounts collected or paid as:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(4)(a)(i): a tax, fee, or charge:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(4)(a)(i)(A): imposed by a governmental entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(4)(a)(i)(B): separately identified as a tax, fee, or charge in the transaction with the customer for the telecommunications service; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(4)(a)(i)(C): imposed only on a telecommunications provider;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(4)(a)(ii): sales and use taxes collected by the telecommunications provider from a customer under Title 59, Chapter 12, Sales and Use Tax Act; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(4)(a)(iii): interest, a fee, or a charge that is charged by a telecommunications provider on a customer for failure to pay for telecommunications service when payment is due.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(4)(b): "Gross receipts from telecommunications service" includes a charge necessary to complete a sale of a telecommunications service.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(5): "Mobile telecommunications service" is as defined in the Mobile Telecommunications Sourcing Act, 4 U.S.C. Sec. 124.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(6): "Municipality" means a city or town.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(7): "Place of primary use":
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(7)(a): for telecommunications service other than mobile telecommunications service, means the street address representative of where the customer's use of the telecommunications service primarily occurs, which shall be:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(7)(a)(i): the residential street address of the customer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(7)(a)(ii): the primary business street address of the customer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(7)(b): for mobile telecommunications service, is as defined in the Mobile Telecommunications Sourcing Act, 4 U.S.C. Sec. 124.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(8): Notwithstanding where a call is billed or paid, "service address" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(8)(a): if the location described in this Subsection (8)(a) is known, the location of the telecommunications equipment:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(8)(a)(i): to which a call is charged; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(8)(a)(ii): from which the call originates or terminates;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(8)(b): if the location described in Subsection (8)(a) is not known but the location described in this Subsection (8)(b) is known, the location of the origination point of the signal of the telecommunications service first identified by:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(8)(b)(i): the telecommunications system of the telecommunications provider; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(8)(b)(ii): if the system used to transport the signal is not a system of the telecommunications provider, information received by the telecommunications provider from its service provider; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(8)(c): if the locations described in Subsection (8)(a) or (b) are not known, the location of a customer's place of primary use.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(9): 54-8b-2
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(9)(a): Subject to Subsections (9)(b) and (9)(c), "telecommunications provider" means a person that:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(9)(a)(i): owns, controls, operates, or manages a telecommunications service; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(9)(a)(ii): engages in an activity described in Subsection (9)(a)(i) for the shared use with or resale to any person of the telecommunications service.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(9)(b): A person described in Subsection (9)(a) is a telecommunications provider whether or not the Public Service Commission of Utah regulates:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(9)(b)(i): that person; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(9)(b)(ii): the telecommunications service that the person owns, controls, operates, or manages.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(9)(c): 54-8b-2 "Telecommunications provider" does not include an aggregator as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(10): 59-12-102; 59-12-102; 59-12-102 "Telecommunications service" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(10)(a): 59-12-102 telecommunications service, as defined in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(10)(b)(i): that originates and terminates within the boundaries of one state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(10)(b)(ii): only to the extent permitted by the Mobile Telecommunications Sourcing Act, 4 U.S.C. Sec. 116 et seq.; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(10)(c): 59-12-102 an ancillary service as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(11): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-402(11)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (11)(b), "telecommunications tax or fee" means any of the following imposed by a municipality on a telecommunications provider:

Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-408 Procedure for taxes erroneously recovered from customers.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A customer may not bring a cause of action against a telecommunications provider on the basis that the telecommunications provider erroneously recovered from the customer municipal telecommunications license taxes authorized by this part unless the customer meets the same requirements that a purchaser is required to meet to bring a cause of action against a seller for a refund or credit as provided in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-410 Transactions consisting of telecommunications service and nontelecommunications services.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-410(1): For purposes of this section, "nontelecommunications services" means services or tangible personal property that are:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-410(1)(a): not telecommunications service; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-410(1)(b): provided by a telecommunications provider to a customer.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-410(2): Except to the extent prohibited by federal law, if a telecommunications provider provides nontelecommunications services to a customer as part of the same transaction in which the telecommunications provider provides telecommunications service, the gross receipts from the nontelecommunications services provided by the telecommunications provider are subject to a tax under this part unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-410(2)(a): the charge for the nontelecommunications services is separately identified in the statement of the transaction with the customer of the telecommunications service; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-410(2)(b): from the books and records of the telecommunications provider that are kept in the regular course of business, the telecommunications provider can reasonably identify the portion of the total charge for the transaction that is attributable to:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-410(2)(b)(i): the nontelecommunications services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-1-410(2)(b)(ii): the telecommunications service.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 10 - Chapter 2 - Classification, Boundaries, Consolidation, and Dissolution of Municipalities
*************************************************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-301 Classification of municipalities according to population.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-301(1): Each municipality shall be classified according to its population, as provided in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-301(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-301(2)(a): A municipality with a population of 100,000 or more is a city of the first class.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-301(2)(b): A municipality with a population of 65,000 or more but less than 100,000 is a city of the second class.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-301(2)(c): A municipality with a population of 30,000 or more but less than 65,000 is a city of the third class.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-301(2)(d): A municipality with a population of 10,000 or more but less than 30,000 is a city of the fourth class.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-301(2)(e): A municipality with a population of 1,000 or more but less than 10,000 is a city of the fifth class.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-301(2)(f): A municipality with a population under 1,000 is a town.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-302 Change of class of municipality.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-302(1): 10-2-301; 67-1a-2 Each municipality shall retain its classification under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-302(2): 67-1a-2 If a municipality's population, as determined by the lieutenant governor under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-302(3): 67-1a-2 A municipality's change in class is effective on the date of the lieutenant governor's certificate under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-303 Effect of change in class.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-303(1): If a municipality changes from one class to another:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-303(1)(a): all property, property rights, and other rights that belonged to or were vested in the municipality at the time of the change shall belong to and be vested in it after the change;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-303(1)(b): no contract, claim, or right of the municipality or demand or liability against it shall be altered or affected in any way by the change;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-303(1)(c): each ordinance, order, and resolution in force in the municipality when it changes classes shall, to the extent that it is not inconsistent with law, not be affected by the change and shall remain in effect until repealed or amended;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-303(1)(d): the change may not affect the identity of the municipality;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-303(1)(e): each municipal officer in office at the time of the change shall continue as an officer until that officer's term expires and a successor is duly elected and qualified; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-303(1)(f): the municipality maintains after the change in class the same form of government that it had immediately before the change.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-303(2): (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-303(2)(a): A change in class does not affect an action at law, prosecution, business, or work of the municipality changing classes, and proceedings shall continue and may be conducted and proceed as if no change in class had occurred.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-303(2)(b): (2)(a) Notwithstanding Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-306 Judicial notice taken of existence and class.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
All courts in this state shall take judicial notice of the existence and classification of any municipality.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-401.5(4)(c): consider current and projected costs of infrastructure, urban services, and public facilities necessary:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-401.5(4)(c)(i): to facilitate full development of the area within the municipality; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-401.5(4)(c)(ii): to expand the infrastructure, services, and facilities into the area being considered for inclusion in the expansion area;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-401.5(4)(d): consider, in conjunction with the municipality's general plan, the need over the next 20 years for additional land suitable for residential, commercial, and industrial development;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-401.5(4)(e): consider the reasons for including agricultural lands, forests, recreational areas, and wildlife management areas in the municipality; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-401.5(4)(f): 10-2-403(5) be guided by the principles set forth in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-401.5(5): Within 30 days after adopting an annexation policy plan, the municipal legislative body shall submit a copy of the plan to the legislative body of each county in which any of the municipality's expansion area is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-401.5(6): Nothing in this chapter may be construed to prohibit or restrict two or more municipalities in specified counties from negotiating and cooperating with respect to defining each municipality's expansion area under an annexation policy plan.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-409 Boundary commission -- Creation -- Members.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-409(1): 10-2-407 The legislative body of each county:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-409(1)(a): may create a boundary commission on its own initiative at any time; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-409(1)(b): 10-2-407 shall create a boundary commission within 30 days of the filing of a protest under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-409(2): Each commission shall be composed of:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-409(2)(a): in a county with two or more municipalities:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-409(2)(a)(i): two members who are elected county officers, appointed by:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-409(2)(a)(i)(A): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-409(2)(a)(i)(A)(I): in a county of the first class operating under a form of government in which the executive and legislative functions are separated, the county executive with the advice and consent of the county legislative body; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-409(2)(a)(i)(A)(II): in a county of the first class operating under a form of government in which the executive and legislative functions of the governing body are not separated, the county legislative body; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-409(2)(a)(i)(B): in a specified county, the county legislative body;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-409(2)(a)(ii): two members who are elected municipal officers from separate municipalities within the county, appointed by the municipal selection committee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-409(2)(a)(iii): three members who are residents of the county, none of whom is a county or municipal officer, appointed by the four other members of the boundary commission; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-409(2)(b): in a county with only one municipality:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-409(2)(b)(i): two members who are county elected officers, appointed by the county legislative body;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-409(2)(b)(ii): one member who is a municipal officer, appointed by the governing body of the municipality; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-409(2)(b)(iii): two members who are residents of the county, neither of whom is a county or municipal officer, appointed by the other three members of the boundary commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-409(3): At the expiration of the term of each member appointed under this section, the member's successor shall be appointed by the same body that appointed the member whose term is expiring, as provided in this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-409.5 Municipal selection committee.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-409.5(1): In each county in which there are two or more municipalities there shall be a municipal selection committee consisting of the mayor of each municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-409.5(2): A majority of the members of the municipal selection committee constitutes a quorum.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-409.5(3): 10-2-409(2)(a)(iii) The municipal selection committee shall appoint each municipal member of the county boundary commission under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-420 Bonds not affected by boundary adjustments or annexations -- Payment of property taxes.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-420(1): A boundary adjustment or annexation under this part may not jeopardize or endanger any general obligation or revenue bond.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-420(2): A bondholder may require the payment of property taxes from any area that:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-420(2)(a): was included in the taxable value of the municipality or other governmental entity issuing the bond at the time the bond was issued; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-420(2)(b): is no longer within the boundaries of the municipality or other governmental entity issuing the bond due to the boundary adjustment or annexation.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-422 Conclusive presumption of annexation.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
An area annexed to a municipality under this part shall be conclusively presumed to have been validly annexed if:Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-422(1): the municipality has levied and the taxpayers within the area have paid property taxes for more than one year after annexation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-422(2): no resident of the area has contested the annexation in a court of proper jurisdiction during the year following annexation.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-502.7 Court action.
----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-502.7(1): 10-2-502.5 After the filing of a petition under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-502.7(2): At the hearing, the court shall hear evidence regarding the viability of the disconnection proposal.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-502.7(3): The burden of proof is on the petitioner to prove, by a preponderance of the evidence:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-502.7(3)(a): the viability of the disconnection;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-502.7(3)(b): that justice and equity require that the territory be disconnected from the municipality;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-502.7(3)(c): that the proposed disconnection will not:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-502.7(3)(c)(i): leave the municipality with an area within its boundaries for which the cost, requirements, or other burdens of providing municipal services would materially increase over previous years;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-502.7(3)(c)(ii): make it economically or practically unfeasible for the municipality to continue to function as a municipality; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-502.7(3)(c)(iii): leave or create one or more islands or peninsulas of unincorporated territory; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-502.7(3)(d): that the county in which the area proposed for disconnection is located is capable, in a cost-effective manner and without materially increasing the county's costs of providing municipal services, of providing to the area the services that the municipality will no longer provide to the area due to the disconnection.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-502.7(4): (3)(c)(i); (ii) In determining whether the petitioner has met the petitioner's burden of proof with respect to Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-502.7(4)(a): the municipality or community as a whole;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-502.7(4)(b): adjoining property owners;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-502.7(4)(c): existing or projected streets or public ways;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-502.7(4)(d): water mains and water services;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-502.7(4)(e): sewer mains and sewer services;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-502.7(4)(f): law enforcement;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-502.7(4)(g): zoning; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-502.7(4)(h): other municipal services.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-502.7(5): The court's order either ordering or rejecting disconnection shall be in writing with findings and reasons.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-509 Costs.
-------------------------------------
Each party to the court action for disconnection shall pay its own witnesses and the petitioner shall pay all other costs.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-603 Plan of consolidation.
-----------------------------------------------------
The resolution for consolidation shall have attached a plan approved by the governing bodies, properly executed by the mayors and attested by the recorders setting forth the nature of the obligations, assets, and liabilities of the municipalities to be included within the proposed consolidated municipality.  The plan shall include a list of every public utility or property on which any debt is owed or due, all or any part of which is payable from the revenues of the utility or property, or from taxes which have been levied and which are outstanding at the time the proposed consolidation is to become effective.  The plan shall also specify the rights, duties, and obligations of the proposed consolidated municipality.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-604 Duty of county legislative body when petition is by electors.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
When the petition for consolidation is properly presented by the electors, the county legislative bodies and officers of each of the respective municipalities shall, within 15 days after the filing of the petition with the county legislative bodies, cause to be filed with the county legislative bodies a plan of consolidation containing the same information as is required in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-605 Effect of plan of consolidation.
---------------------------------------------------------------
The plan of consolidation shall be subordinate in all respects to the contract rights of all holders of any securities or obligations of the municipality outstanding at the effective date of the consolidation. The plan shall be available to the public for inspection and copying. The plan may extend for a period of up to 20 years, except that those provisions necessary for the protection of the holders of any securities or other obligations of any municipalities being consolidated shall extend for such longer time as may be necessary to ensure the payment of the securities and obligations. Any person may enforce the provisions and terms of the plan during the period in which the plan is effective. After the expiration of the period of the plan, the rights, duties and obligations stated in the plan shall be governed by the laws of the State of Utah and not by the plan. The plan shall be effective only if the consolidation is approved by the voters of the respective municipalities to be consolidated.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-606 Public hearings.
-----------------------------------------------
The governing body of each municipality in its plan for consolidation shall set a time and place for a public hearing or public hearings which shall be held at least 10 days after the plan of consolidation and the dates of the public hearing have been submitted to the county legislative bodies. The public hearing may be held jointly or separately by the governing bodies of each municipality to be consolidated. Any interested person may be heard on any aspect of the proposed consolidation. One or more certified copies of the plan of consolidation shall be available in the recorder's office of each municipality at least five days prior to the hearing.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-607 Notice of election.
--------------------------------------------------
If the county legislative bodies find that the resolution or petition for consolidation and their attachments substantially conform with the requirements of this part, the county legislative bodies shall, for at least four weeks before the day of the election, publish notice of the election for consolidation, as a class A notice under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-608 Contents of notice.
--------------------------------------------------
The notice required in the preceding section shall contain a summary of:Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-608(1): the contents of the resolutions or petitions for consolidation;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-608(2): the consolidation plan;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-608(3): where the resolutions or petitions and consolidation plan can be found;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-608(4): the time and place where public hearings on the question of consolidation will be held and shall state that any interested person may be heard on the question of consolidation and on the plan for consolidation;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-608(5): a description of the territory and the names of the municipalities which will be included within the proposed consolidated municipality which descriptions may be by any means which describe the territories involved;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-608(6): the time and place or places at which the election for consolidation shall be held; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-608(7): the form of the ballot to be used in the election to determine the question of consolidation which shall read substantially as follows:


Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-609 Election on consolidation.
---------------------------------------------------------
The election on consolidation shall be held as nearly as possible in the same manner as a general election.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-611(2): 59-2-305.5; 10-2-610(3)(b)

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-612 New municipality -- Ownership of property -- Indebtedness of original municipalities.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any consolidated municipality shall be deemed to be a continuation of the merged municipalities, except as herein expressly provided, and shall own all of the assets, property, records, seals, equipment, and be responsible for the liabilities of each and all of the municipalities dissolved by the consolidation. The new municipality shall require the inhabitants of an original municipality included in the consolidation, by special tax levy, to satisfy any indebtedness incurred by the original municipalities provided inhabitants residing in other parts of the consolidated municipality did not or do not benefit by the revenue or services obtained by the expenditures causing the indebtedness. The governing body of the consolidated municipality shall be subject to the terms of the consolidation plan.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-613 Governing body until next election.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Until the next regular municipal election, the elected officials of the municipalities consolidated into the consolidated municipality shall constitute the governing body of the municipality. The governing body shall elect one of their members to serve as mayor of the municipality and may appoint such other officers as deemed necessary to carry out the business of the municipality.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-614 Ordinances, resolutions, and orders.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
All ordinances, resolutions and orders, in force in any of the municipalities when it is consolidated, shall remain in full force and effect within the respective areas of the municipalities which existed prior to consolidation insofar as the ordinances, resolutions and orders are not repugnant to law, until repealed or amended, but may not in any case exceed three years.  The governing body of the new municipality shall as soon as possible adopt new ordinances, resolutions and orders for the uniform governance of the new municipality.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-701 Petition for disincorporation -- Validity -- Certification of petition signatures -- Removal of signature -- District court order for election.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-701(2): The petition shall bear signatures equal in number to 25% of all votes cast from the municipality at the last congressional election.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-701(3): No signature is valid, for purposes of this section, unless it is that of a registered voter who is a resident of the municipality proposed for disincorporation.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-701(4): The petition containing the specified number of signatures shall be filed with the county clerk for validation by that officer.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-702 District court to examine petition -- Set date for election.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If the court determines that the petition is complete, the court shall set a date for the election to determine the question of dissolution which date shall be at least 60 but not more than 90 days after the petition is filed with the court.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-704 Form of ballot.
----------------------------------------------
The form of the ballot used to vote on the issue of dissolution shall be separate from any other ballot and shall read substantially as follows:

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-705 Judgment -- Determination of claims.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
The vote shall be taken and canvassed in the same manner as in other municipal elections, and return thereof made to the district court.  If the district court finds that a majority of the votes cast favored dissolution, a judgment shall be entered approving the dissolution of the municipality and, upon dissolution, the corporate powers of such municipality shall cease, and the court shall cause notice to be given in a manner to be prescribed by it, requiring all claims against the municipality to be filed in the court within a time fixed in the notice, not exceeding six months, and all claims not so filed shall be forever barred.  At the expiration of the time so fixed the court shall adjudicate claims so filed, which shall be treated as denied, and any citizen of the municipality at the time the vote was taken may appear and defend against any claim so filed, or the court may in its discretion appoint some person for that purpose.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-706 Taxes to meet municipal obligations.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
The court shall have power to wind down the affairs of the municipality, to dispose of its property as provided by law, and to make provisions for the payment of all indebtedness thereof and for the performance of its contracts and obligations, and shall order such taxes levied from time to time as may be requisite therefore, which the county legislative body shall levy against the property within the municipality. The taxes shall be collected by the county treasurer in the manner for collecting other property taxes and shall be paid out under the orders of the court, and the surplus, if any, shall be paid into the school fund for the district in which the taxes were levied. All municipal property remaining after the winding down of the affairs of the municipality, shall be transferred to the board of education of such school district, which board hereby is empowered to enforce all claims for the same and to have the use of all property so vesting.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-707 Disposition of records.
------------------------------------------------------
The books, documents, records, papers, and seal of any dissolved municipality shall be deposited with the county clerk for safekeeping and reference.  All court records of justice court judges shall be deposited with a justice court judge of the county to be designated by the court, and other records with the district court.  The courts respectively have authority to execute and complete all unfinished business standing on the same.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-708 Notice of disincorporation.
----------------------------------------------------------
When a municipality has been dissolved, the clerk of the court shall provide notice of the dissolution for the county, as a class B notice under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-709 Expenses of election.
----------------------------------------------------
The expenses of the election, of winding down the affairs and of dissolving the municipality, shall be the obligation of the municipality and shall be paid by it.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-710 Limitation on jurisdiction of court to consider disincorporation petition.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A court may not consider a petition seeking disincorporation of a municipality or to order an election based upon the submission of such a petition if:Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-710(1): the disincorporation petition is filed with the court less than two years after the official date of incorporation of the municipality which the petition seeks to dissolve; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2-710(2): the disincorporation petition is filed with the court less than two years after the date of an election held to decide the question of dissolution of the municipality which the petition seeks to dissolve.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-107(1): 10-2-429 As used in this section:

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-107(3): All roads and other utilities that before incorporation of a community council municipality were under the jurisdiction of the county in which the community council municipality is located become, upon incorporation, under the jurisdiction of the community council municipality.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-202(1): Subject to Subsection (2), the process to incorporate an unincorporated area as a municipality is initiated by an individual filing a feasibility request, with the county clerk of the county where the area proposed to be incorporated is located, that :

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-202(1)(a)(iii): is, as of January 1 of the current year, equal in assessed fair market value to at least 7% of the assessed fair market value of all private real property within the area;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-202(1)(b): includes the typed or printed name and current residence address of each owner signing the request; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-202(1)(c): is accompanied by the Utah Population Committee's written notice under Subsection (2)(d)(ii).

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.3 Notice to property owners -- First public hearing.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
You have received this notice because you reside or own property within an area proposed for incorporation, or an area within 300 feet of an area proposed for incorporation. The first public hearing in relation to the proposed incorporation will be held on [insert date, time, and location]. The purpose of the first public hearing is to provide information regarding the proposed incorporation, the incorporation process, including the process for deciding whether to incorporate, and certain rights you may have in relation to the proposed incorporation. A specified landowner, as defined in Utah Code SectionUtah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.3(1): 10-2a-204; 10-2a-207; 10-2a-204 The county clerk shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.3(1)(a): 10-2a-204 hold the first public hearing in relation to the proposed incorporation, at a location approved by the lieutenant governor, no later than 30 days after the day on which the lieutenant governor certifies the feasibility request under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.3(1)(b): 10-2a-207 publish notice of the hearing in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.3(1)(c): 10-2a-204 within seven calendar days after the day on which the lieutenant governor certifies the feasibility request under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.3(1)(c)(i): each residence within, and each owner of real property located within:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.3(1)(c)(i)(A): the proposed incorporation boundaries; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.3(1)(c)(i)(B): 300 feet of the proposed incorporation boundaries;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.3(1)(c)(ii): the contact sponsor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.3(1)(c)(iii): the lieutenant governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.3(2): 10-2a-204.5 The written notice provided by the county clerk under Subsections (1)(b) and (c) shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.3(2)(a): 10-2a-204.5 the following statement:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.3(2)(b): a clear description of the area proposed for incorporation.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.3(3): 10-2a-204.5 Notwithstanding that the county conducts the first public hearing, the lieutenant governor, or a designee of the lieutenant governor, shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.3(3)(a): direct the proceedings at the first public hearing, with the assistance of the county clerk as needed;

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.3(3)(f): answer questions from individuals who attend the first public hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.3(4): The contact sponsor, or an agent of the contact sponsor, and the county clerk, or an employee of the county clerk designated by the county clerk, shall attend the first public hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.3(5): The county clerk shall:

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.3(5)(b): ensure compliance with the requirements of Title 52, Chapter 4, Open and Public Meetings Act, in relation to the public hearing.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5 Notice to owner of property -- Exclusion or inclusion of property from or in proposed municipality.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5(1): 17-41-101 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5(1)(a): "Owner" means a person having an interest in real property, including an affiliate, subsidiary, or parent company.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5(1)(b): 17-41-101 "Specified landowner" means a record owner of real property:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5(1)(b)(i): who owns more than:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5(1)(b)(i)(A): 1% of the assessed fair market value, as of January 1 of the current year, of all property within the boundaries of a proposed incorporation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5(1)(b)(i)(B): 10% of the total private land area within the boundaries of a proposed incorporation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5(1)(b)(ii): 17-41-101 located in a mining protection area as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5(2): 10-2a-204.3 Within 30 calendar days after the day of the first public hearing described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5(2)(a): a specified landowner may request that the county clerk exclude all or part of the land owned by the specified landowner from the area proposed for incorporation by filing a request for exclusion with the county clerk that describes the land for which the specified landowner requests exclusion; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5(2)(b): any owner of land located within the county where the area proposed for incorporation is located may file a request that all or part of that land be included in the area proposed for incorporation by filing a request for inclusion with the county clerk that describes the land that the landowner desires to include.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5(3): The county clerk shall exclude the land identified by a specified landowner under Subsection (2)(a) from the proposed incorporation boundaries unless the county clerk finds by clear and convincing evidence that:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5(3)(a): except for a proposed incorporation of a community council area, the exclusion will leave an unincorporated island within the proposed municipality; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5(3)(b): the land receives from the county a majority of currently provided municipal services.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5(4): The county clerk shall include land identified by a landowner under Subsection (2)(b) in the area proposed for incorporation unless the county clerk finds by clear and convincing evidence that:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5(4)(a): except for a proposed incorporation of a community council area, the land will not be contiguous with the area of the proposed municipality, taking into account other requests for inclusion or requests for exclusion received before the deadline described in Subsection (2); or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5(4)(b): the inclusion will cause the area proposed for incorporation to violate a requirement for incorporation described in this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5(5): 10-2a-204.3 The county clerk shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5(5)(a): 10-2a-204.3 no earlier than 30 days after, but no later than 44 days after, the day of the first public hearing described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5(5)(b): forward to the lieutenant governor for review:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5(5)(b)(i): all timely requests for exclusion or inclusion;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5(5)(b)(ii): the county clerk's determination on each of the requests described in Subsection (5)(b)(i); and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5(5)(b)(iii): the reasons, including the supporting data, for each determination described in Subsection (5)(b)(ii); and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5(5)(c): within five days after the day on which the lieutenant governor makes a final determination on whether to include or exclude land under Subsection (7), the county clerk shall mail or transmit written notice of whether the land is included or excluded from the proposed incorporation boundaries to:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5(5)(c)(i): for a request for exclusion, the specified landowner that requested the exclusion;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5(5)(c)(ii): for a request for inclusion, the owner of land that requested the inclusion; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5(5)(c)(iii): the contact sponsor.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5(6): For a request for exclusion or inclusion that is denied, the county clerk shall include, in the written notice described in Subsection (5)(c), a detailed explanation of the reason for the denial and the facts supporting the denial.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5(7): Within 14 days after the day on which the lieutenant governor receives the information described in Subsection (5)(b) the lieutenant governor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5(7)(a): review each determination;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5(7)(b): uphold or reverse each determination; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5(7)(c): forward to the county clerk:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5(7)(c)(i): the lieutenant governor's final determinations; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-204.5(7)(c)(ii): if the lieutenant governor reverses a determination of the county clerk, the reason for the reversal and the supporting facts.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205(3)(a): 10-2a-204.5; 10-2a-202 The feasibility study shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205(3)(a)(i): an analysis of the population and population density within the area proposed for incorporation and the surrounding area;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205(3)(a)(ii): the current and projected five-year demographics and tax base within the boundaries of the proposed municipality and surrounding area, including household size and income, commercial and industrial development, and public facilities;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205(3)(a)(iii): subject to Subsection (3)(b), the current and five-year projected cost of providing municipal services to the proposed municipality, including administrative costs;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205(3)(a)(iv): assuming the same tax categories and tax rates as currently imposed by the county and all other current service providers, the present and five-year projected revenue for the proposed municipality;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205(3)(a)(v): an analysis of the risks and opportunities that might affect the actual costs described in Subsection (3)(a)(iii) or revenues described in Subsection (3)(a)(iv) of the newly incorporated municipality;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205(3)(a)(vi): an analysis of new revenue sources that may be available to the newly incorporated municipality that are not available before the area incorporates, including an analysis of the amount of revenues the municipality might obtain from those revenue sources;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205(3)(a)(vii): the projected tax burden per household of any new taxes that may be levied within the proposed municipality within five years after incorporation;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205(3)(a)(viii): the fiscal impact of the municipality's incorporation on unincorporated areas, other municipalities, special districts, special service districts, and other governmental entities in the county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205(3)(a)(ix): 10-2a-204.5; 10-2a-202 if the county clerk excludes property from, or includes property in, the proposed municipality under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205(3)(b)(ii): In calculating the current cost of a municipal service under Subsection (3)(a)(iii), the feasibility consultant shall consider:

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205(3)(b)(ii)(B): the current municipal service provider's present and five-year projected cost of providing the municipal service.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205(3)(b)(iii): In calculating costs under Subsection (3)(a)(iii), the feasibility consultant shall account for inflation and anticipated growth.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205(3)(c): In conducting the feasibility study, the feasibility consultant shall consult with the following before submitting a draft of the feasibility study under Subsection (2)(c)(i):

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205(3)(c)(ii): if the proposed municipality will include lands owned by the state, the entity within state government that has jurisdiction over the land;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205(3)(c)(iii): each entity that provides a municipal service to a portion of the proposed municipality; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205(3)(c)(iv): each other special service district that provides services to a portion of the proposed municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205(4): If the five-year projected revenues calculated under Subsection (3)(a)(iv) exceed the five-year projected costs calculated under Subsection (3)(a)(iii) by more than 5%, the feasibility consultant shall project and report the expected annual revenue surplus to the contact sponsor and the lieutenant governor.
