Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205.5 Additional feasibility consultant considerations for proposed incorporation of community council area -- Additional feasibility study requirements.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205.5(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205.5(1)(a): "Applicable community council" means the community council that represents the community council area that is proposed to be incorporated.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205.5(1)(b): "Request sponsors" means the sponsors of a feasibility request relating to the proposed incorporation of a community council area.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205.5(2): 10-2a-205 Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205.5(3): 10-2-429; 10-2-429 A feasibility consultant conducting a feasibility study for a proposed incorporation of a community council area shall consider:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205.5(3)(a): population and population density within the community council area;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205.5(3)(b): current and five-year projections of demographics and economic base in the community council area, including household size and income, commercial and industrial development, and public facilities;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205.5(3)(c): projected population growth in the community council area during the next five years;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205.5(3)(d): 10-2-429 subject to Subsection (4)(a), the present and five-year projections of the cost, including overhead, of providing the same or a similar service in the community council area as is provided by the municipal services district, including a comparison of:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205.5(3)(d)(i): the estimated cost if the municipal services district continues to provide service;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205.5(3)(d)(ii): the estimated cost if the community council municipality provides service directly or through a contract with another service provider; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205.5(3)(d)(iii): 10-2-429 the estimated cost if an unincorporated island within the community council area is annexed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205.5(3)(e): subject to Subsection (4)(a), evaluating the present and five-year projections of the cost, including overhead, of a municipal services district providing municipal services to the community council area, comparing those costs assuming that the community council area is included in the service area of the municipal services district with those costs assuming that the community council area is excluded from the service area of the municipal services district;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205.5(3)(f): a projection of any new taxes per household that may be levied within the community council municipality within five years after incorporation;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205.5(3)(g): the fiscal impact that the community council area's incorporation will have on other municipalities and unincorporated areas served by the municipal services district, including any rate increase that may become necessary to maintain required coverage ratios for the municipal services district's debt if, after incorporation:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205.5(3)(g)(i): the municipal services district continues to provide service to the community council area; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205.5(3)(g)(ii): the community council area provides service directly or through contract with another service provider;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205.5(3)(h): the physical and other assets that will be required by the municipal services district to provide, without interruption or diminution of service, the same or a similar service to the community council municipality upon incorporation;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205.5(3)(i): the physical and other assets that will no longer be required by the municipal services district to continue to provide the current level of service to the remainder of the service area without the community council area if the community council area incorporates and provides services directly or through contract with another service provider;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205.5(3)(j): the number and classification of municipal services district employees who will no longer be required to serve the remaining portions of the service area if a community council area provides service directly or through contract with another service provider upon incorporation, including the dollar amount of the wages, salaries, and benefits attributable to the employees and the estimated cost associated with termination of the employees if the community council municipality does not employ the employees;

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-205.5(3)(l): 10-2-429 any other factor that the feasibility consultant considers relevant to the cost of providing municipal services as a result of a community council area's incorporation or the annexation of one or more unincorporated islands under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-501 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-501(1): "Affordable housing" means housing occupied or reserved for occupancy by households with a gross household income equal to or less than 80% of the median gross income of the applicable municipal or county statistical area for households of the same size.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-501(2): 10-3b-402 "Board," in relation to a preliminary municipality, means the same as a council described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-501(3): 10-3b-402 "Board chair," in relation to a preliminary municipality, means the same as a mayor described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-501(4): 10-2a-102 "Contiguous" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-501(5): "Feasibility consultant" means a person or firm:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-501(5)(a): with expertise in the processes and economics of local government; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-501(5)(b): who is independent of, and not affiliated with, a county or a sponsor of a petition to incorporate a preliminary municipality under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-501(6): 10-2a-502 "Feasibility request" means a request, described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-501(7): 20A-1-501 "Initial landowners" means the persons who owned the land within the proposed preliminary municipality area when the person filed the feasibility request under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-501(8): 10-2a-102 "Municipal service" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-501(9): 10-2-403; 10-2a-502 "Pending annexation area" means an area proposed for annexation in an annexation petition described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-501(10): 10-2a-502; 10-2a-507 "Primary sponsor contact" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-501(10)(a): 10-2a-502 in relation to a feasibility request:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-501(10)(a)(i): 10-2a-502 the individual designated as the primary sponsor contact for a feasibility request under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-501(10)(a)(ii): an individual designated, in writing, by the initial landowners if a replacement primary sponsor contact is needed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-501(10)(b): 10-2a-507 in relation to a petition for incorporation of a preliminary municipality:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-501(10)(b)(i): 10-2a-507 the individual designated as the primary sponsor contact for a petition for incorporation of a preliminary municipality under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-501(10)(b)(ii): an individual designated, in writing, by the initial landowners if a replacement primary sponsor contact is needed.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-501(11): "Private," in relation to real property, means taxable real property.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-501(12): "Proposed preliminary municipality area" means the area proposed for incorporation as a preliminary municipality in a feasibility request.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-501(13): 10-2a-502 "System infrastructure" means, as shown on the map or plat described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-501(13)(a): the main thoroughfares within the proposed preliminary municipal area, including the roads that connect the proposed preliminary municipality area to an existing road outside the proposed preliminary municipality area; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-501(13)(b): the main lines that will connect a utility to the proposed preliminary municipality area, including the stubs that will connect the main lines to the development in the proposed preliminary municipality area.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502 Incorporation of a preliminary municipality --  Feasibility request -- Requirements.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(1): A person may apply to incorporate an area as a preliminary municipality by filing a feasibility request in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(2): Subject to Subsection (6), a person may file a feasibility request in relation to an area that the person seeks to incorporate as a preliminary municipality if:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(2)(a): the area is contiguous;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(2)(b): no part of the area is within a county of the first class or second class;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(2)(c): no part of the area is within, or within .25 miles of, a municipality;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(2)(d): on the day on which the person files the feasibility request:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(2)(d)(i): the area is owned by no more than three persons, all of whom consent to incorporation as a preliminary municipality; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(2)(d)(ii): at least 50% of the area is undeveloped;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(2)(e): the persons who sign the feasibility request intend to develop the area to the point that:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(2)(e)(i): at least 100 individuals reside in the area;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(2)(e)(ii): the area will have an average population density of no less than seven individuals per square mile, unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(2)(e)(ii)(A): a population density of less than seven individuals per square mile is necessary in order to connect separate areas that share a demonstrable community interest; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(2)(e)(ii)(B): the average population of the area has a population density of no less than seven individuals per square mile if the land necessary to connect the separate areas described in Subsection (2)(e)(ii)(A) is not included in the calculation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(2)(e)(iii): at least 10% of the housing in the preliminary municipality is affordable housing;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(2)(f): the area does not include land owned by the United States government unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(2)(f)(i): the area, including the land owned by the United States government, is contiguous; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(2)(f)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(2)(f)(ii)(A): incorporating the land is necessary to connect separate areas that share a demonstrable community interest; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(2)(f)(ii)(B): excluding the land from the area would create an unincorporated island within the proposed preliminary municipality;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(2)(g): the area is entirely within one county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(2)(h): the feasibility request complies with Subsection (3).
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(3): 10-2a-205; 10-2a-210; 10-2a-208; 10-2a-208; 10-2a-504; 10-2a-507; 10-2a-507
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(3)(a): A proposed preliminary municipality area may not include all or part of a pending annexation area, unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(3)(a)(i): the portion of the pending annexation area included in the proposed preliminary municipality area does not exceed 20% of the proposed preliminary municipality area; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(3)(a)(ii): the feasibility request would comply with the requirements of this section regardless of whether the portion of the pending annexation area included in the proposed preliminary municipality area is excluded from, or remains included in, the proposed preliminary municipality area.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(3)(b): 10-2a-205; 10-2a-210; 10-2a-208; 10-2a-208 A proposed preliminary municipality area may not include all or part of an area that is the subject of a completed feasibility study or supplemental feasibility study that qualifies to proceed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(3)(b)(i): 10-2a-210 the proposed incorporation that is the subject of the completed feasibility study or supplemental feasibility study has been defeated by the voters at an election under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(3)(b)(ii): 10-2a-208; 10-2a-208 the time described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(3)(c): 10-2a-504; 10-2a-507; 10-2a-507 A proposed preliminary municipality area may not include all or part of an area that is the subject of a completed feasibility study or supplemental feasibility study whose results comply with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(4): 10-2a-505 Except as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(5): A person who files a feasibility request under this section shall file the feasibility request with the lieutenant governor, including in the feasibility request:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(5)(a): the signatures of all owners of real property included in the proposed preliminary municipality area, showing that the owners consent to including the real property in the proposed preliminary municipality area;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(5)(b): the name, address, and phone number of each owner signing the feasibility request;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(5)(c): a designation of one individual who signs the feasibility request as the primary sponsor contact for the feasibility request;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(5)(d): a description of the proposed preliminary municipality area;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(5)(e): an accurate map or plat, prepared by a licensed surveyor, showing:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(5)(e)(i): a legal description of the boundaries of the proposed preliminary municipality area and each phase of the proposed preliminary municipality area;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(5)(e)(ii): all development planned for the proposed preliminary municipality area; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(5)(e)(iii): that the first phase of the proposed preliminary municipality area is projected to have at least 100 residents when completed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(5)(f): a request that the lieutenant governor commission a study to determine the feasibility of incorporating the area as a preliminary municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(6)(a): The provisions of this part, providing for the incorporation of a preliminary municipality, is a pilot project that ends on January 1, 2031.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(6)(b): Except as provided in Subsection (7), a person may not file a feasibility request under this part in a calendar year during which two or more requests have already been filed in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(7): 10-2a-503; 10-2a-503; 10-2a-503; 10-2a-504; 10-2a-505; 10-2a-505 A feasibility request does not count towards the limit described in Subsection (6)(b) if:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(7)(a): the sponsors who file the request withdraw the request;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(7)(b): 10-2a-503; 10-2a-503; 10-2a-503 the lieutenant governor rejects the feasibility request under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(7)(b)(i): 10-2a-503 do not timely amend the feasibility request under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(7)(b)(ii): 10-2a-503 are prohibited from amending the feasibility request under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(7)(c): 10-2a-504; 10-2a-505; 10-2a-505 the process to incorporate is prohibited from proceeding under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-502(7)(c)(i): 10-2a-505 do not timely file a modified feasibility request under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504 Feasibility study -- Feasibility study consultant -- Qualifications for proceeding with incorporation.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(1): 10-2a-503; 10-2a-503 Unless the lieutenant governor rescinds the certification under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(2): 10-2a-506 The lieutenant governor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(2)(a): select a feasibility consultant in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 6a, Utah Procurement Code;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(2)(b): ensure that the feasibility consultant:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(2)(b)(i): has expertise in the processes and economics of local government; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(2)(b)(ii): is not affiliated with a sponsor of the feasibility request or the county in which the proposed municipality is located; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(2)(c): 10-2a-506 require the feasibility consultant to:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(2)(c)(i): submit a draft of the feasibility study to each applicable person with whom the feasibility consultant is required to consult under Subsection (3)(c) within 90 days after the day on which the lieutenant governor engages the feasibility consultant to conduct the study;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(2)(c)(ii): allow each person to whom the consultant provides a draft under Subsection (2)(c)(i) to review and provide comment on the draft;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(2)(c)(iii): submit a completed feasibility study, including a one-page summary of the results, to the following within 120 days after the day on which the lieutenant governor engages the feasibility consultant to conduct the feasibility study:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(2)(c)(iii)(A): the lieutenant governor;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(2)(c)(iii)(B): the county legislative body of the county in which the proposed preliminary municipality area is located;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(2)(c)(iii)(C): the primary sponsor contact; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(2)(c)(iii)(D): each person to whom the consultant provided a draft under Subsection (2)(c)(i); and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(2)(c)(iv): 10-2a-506 attend the public hearings described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(3)(a): The feasibility study shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(3)(a)(i): an analysis of:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(3)(a)(i)(A): the likely population and population density within the proposed preliminary municipality area when all phases of the map or plat for the proposed preliminary municipality area are completed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(3)(a)(i)(B): the population and population density of the area surrounding the proposed preliminary municipality area on the day on which the feasibility request was submitted;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(3)(a)(ii): an analysis of the following, determined as if, at the time of the analysis, the proposed  preliminary municipality area is incorporated as a town with a population of 100 people:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(3)(a)(ii)(A): the initial and projected five-year demographics and tax base within the boundaries of the proposed preliminary municipality area and the surrounding area, including household size and income, commercial and industrial development, and public facilities;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(3)(a)(ii)(B): subject to Subsection (3)(b), the initial and five-year projected cost of providing municipal services to the proposed preliminary municipality area, including administrative costs;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(3)(a)(ii)(C): assuming the same tax categories and tax rates as imposed by the county and all other current service providers at the time during which the feasibility consultant prepares the feasibility study, the initial and five-year projected revenue for the proposed preliminary municipality area;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(3)(a)(ii)(D): the risks and opportunities that might affect the actual costs described in Subsection (3)(a)(ii)(B) or the revenues described in Subsection (3)(a)(ii)(C) of the proposed preliminary municipality area;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(3)(a)(ii)(E): new revenue sources that may be available to the proposed preliminary municipality area that are not available before the area incorporates, including an analysis of the amount of revenues the proposed preliminary municipality area might obtain from those revenue sources;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(3)(a)(ii)(F): the projected tax burden per household of any new taxes that may be levied within the proposed preliminary municipality area within five years after incorporation as a town; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(3)(a)(ii)(G): the fiscal impact of the proposed preliminary municipality area's incorporation as a town on unincorporated areas, other municipalities, special districts, special service districts, and other governmental entities in the county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(3)(a)(iii): an analysis regarding whether sufficient water will be available to support the proposed preliminary municipality area when the development of the area is complete.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(3)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(3)(b)(i): In calculating the projected costs under Subsection (3)(a)(ii)(B), the feasibility consultant shall assume the proposed preliminary municipality area will provide a level and quality of municipal services that fairly and reasonably approximate the level and quality of municipal services that are provided to the area surrounding the proposed preliminary municipality area at the time the feasibility consultant conducts the feasibility study.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(3)(b)(ii): In calculating the current cost of a municipal service under Subsection (3)(a)(ii)(B), the feasibility consultant shall consider:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(3)(b)(ii)(A): the amount it would cost the proposed preliminary municipality area to provide the municipal service for the first five years after the area incorporates as a town; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(3)(b)(ii)(B): the proposed or current municipal service provider's initial and five-year projected cost of providing the municipal service after the proposed preliminary municipality area incorporates as a town.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(3)(b)(iii): In calculating costs under Subsection (3)(a)(ii)(B), the feasibility consultant shall account for inflation and anticipated growth.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(3)(c): In conducting the feasibility study, the feasibility consultant shall consult with the following before submitting a draft of the feasibility study under Subsection (2)(c)(iii):
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(3)(c)(i): if the proposed preliminary municipality will include lands owned by the United States federal government, the entity within the United States federal government that has jurisdiction over the land;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(3)(c)(ii): if the proposed preliminary municipality will include lands owned by the state, the entity within state government that has jurisdiction over the land;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(3)(c)(iii): each entity that provides, or is proposed to provide, a municipal service to a portion of the proposed preliminary municipality area; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(3)(c)(iv): each other special service district that provides, or is proposed to provide, services to a portion of the proposed preliminary municipality area.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(4): If the five-year projected revenues calculated under Subsection (3)(a)(ii)(C) exceed the five-year projected costs calculated under Subsection (3)(a)(ii)(B) by more than 5%, the feasibility consultant shall project and report the expected annual revenue surplus to the primary sponsor contact and the lieutenant governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(5): 10-2a-505; 10-2a-505; 10-2a-505
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(5)(a): 10-2a-505 Except as provided in Subsection (5)(b), if the results of the feasibility study, or a supplemental feasibility study described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-504(5)(b): 10-2a-505; 10-2a-505 Except as provided in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-507 Petition for incorporation -- Requirements and form.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-507(1): 10-2a-506; 10-2a-502; 10-2a-504; 10-3b-402 At any time within one year after the day on which the lieutenant governor completes the public hearings required under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-507(1)(a): includes the typed or printed name, signature, address, and phone number of the initial landowners;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-507(1)(b): describes the proposed preliminary municipality area, as described in the feasibility request or the modified feasibility request;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-507(1)(c): 10-2a-504 demonstrates compliance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-507(1)(d): states the proposed name for the proposed preliminary municipality;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-507(1)(e): designates the primary sponsor contact for the proposed preliminary municipality;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-507(1)(f): 10-3b-402 designates the board chair and three of the four board members who will serve as a five member council form of government for the preliminary municipality, described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-507(1)(g): is accompanied by an accurate map or plat, prepared by a licensed surveyor, showing:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-507(1)(g)(i): the boundaries of the proposed preliminary municipality;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-507(1)(g)(ii): a single development plan for the proposed municipality, depicting each phase of the development;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-507(1)(h): is accompanied by a bond, cash deposit, or letter of credit that:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-507(1)(h)(i): is posted by the initial landowners;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-507(1)(h)(ii): is in favor of the proposed preliminary municipality, to guarantee that the initial landowners will complete the system infrastructure no later than six years after the day on which the initial landowners file the petition for incorporation described in this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-507(1)(h)(iii): will be refunded to the initial landowners in percentages that reflect the progress toward completing the system infrastructure; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-507(1)(i): is accompanied by payment in full, from the initial landowners, of the costs incurred by the lieutenant governor for the feasibility study, the public notices, the hearings, and the other expenses incurred by the lieutenant governor to comply with the requirements of this part in relation to the proposed preliminary municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-507(2): If, within six years after the day on which the initial landowners file a petition for incorporation under Subsection (1), the system infrastructure for the preliminary municipality is not completed, the portion of the bond, cash deposit, or letter of credit described in Subsection (1)(h) that has not been refunded to the initial landowners shall forfeit to the preliminary municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-507(3): 10-2a-503 If, within four years after the day on which the first residential certificate of occupancy is issued for the development described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-507(3)(a): the lieutenant governor shall issue a certificate dissolving the preliminary municipality;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-507(3)(b): all roads and infrastructure within the preliminary municipality revert to the county in which the preliminary municipality is located;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-507(3)(c): the area within the proposed municipality falls under the jurisdiction of the county and is no longer incorporated; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-507(3)(d): the initial landowners are liable to the county for damages caused to the county due to the dissolution of the preliminary municipality.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-509(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-509(4)(a): Subject to Subsection (4)(b), a preliminary municipality has all the powers and duties of a municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-509(4)(b): A preliminary municipality:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-509(4)(b)(i): may not impose a tax;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-509(4)(b)(ii): may enter into an interlocal agreement with a special district to provide utility services to the preliminary municipality;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-509(4)(b)(iii): has the same authority as another municipality to make decisions regarding zoning and land use;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-509(4)(b)(iv): may not receive an allocation of sales tax or gas tax; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-509(4)(b)(v): may not exercise eminent domain authority.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-509(5): As needed, the county shall provide all services and utility connections to the preliminary municipality that the county provides other areas in the county if the preliminary municipality:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-509(5)(a): pays the uniformly assessed rates for the services and utilities and reasonable connection fees; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-509(5)(b): complies with the county's established regulations and specifications for the construction and connection of the local improvements.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-509(6): 10-2a-502 The preliminary municipality shall maintain and repair any roadway that, on the day on which the individual filed the feasibility request under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-509(6)(a): existed within the preliminary municipality;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-509(6)(b): was within a public right of way that abuts the preliminary municipality; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-509(6)(c): was within 1/2 mile of the preliminary municipality and connected to, or was proposed in the feasibility request to be connected to, the preliminary municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-509(7): Before the preliminary municipality submits a petition to transition to a town, the preliminary municipality shall select an independent third-party engineer to review and approve all building permit applications within the preliminary municipality to ensure compliance with the law.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-509(8): Chapter 2, Classification, Boundaries, Consolidation, and Dissolution of Municipalities, does not apply to a preliminary municipality.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510 Transitioning from a preliminary municipality to a town -- Petition -- Election of officers.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(1): Within 30 days after the day on which the population of a preliminary municipality exceeds 99 people, a person who filed the application to incorporate as a preliminary municipality or a resident of the preliminary municipality shall file with the lieutenant governor a petition to transition the preliminary municipality into a town.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(2): A petition to transition a preliminary municipality into a town shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(2)(a): a request that the lieutenant governor certify the transition of the preliminary municipality to, and the incorporation of the preliminary municipality as, a town;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(2)(b): the name, address, and phone number of the person filing the request;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(2)(c): the map or plat of the preliminary municipality;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(2)(d): a legal description of the boundaries of the preliminary municipality;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(2)(e): information regarding the preliminary municipality, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(2)(e)(i): the number of residences in the preliminary municipality;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(2)(e)(ii): the population of the preliminary municipality;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(2)(e)(iii): the number of adults and the number of children who reside in the preliminary municipality; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(2)(e)(iv): information regarding the providers of municipal services and emergency services to the preliminary municipality;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(2)(f): the proposed name for the town; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(2)(g): a signature sheet containing the names, addresses, and signatures of a majority of the adult residents of the preliminary municipality, supporting the proposed name for the town.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(3): Within 30 days after the day on which a person files a petition to transition a preliminary municipality into a town, the lieutenant governor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(3)(a): determine whether the preliminary municipality has a population of more than 99 people;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(3)(b): examine the petition to determine whether the petition complies with Subsection (2);
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(3)(c): if the lieutenant governor determines that the preliminary municipality has a population of more than 99 people and that the petition complies with Subsection (2), proceed to transition the preliminary municipality as a town in accordance with Subsection (4);
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(3)(d): if the lieutenant governor determines that the preliminary municipality has a population of less than 100 people, deny the petition, inform the person who filed the petition of the determination, and request that the person refile the petition when the population exceeds 99 people; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(3)(e): if the lieutenant governor determines that the petition fails to comply with Subsection (2), deny the petition, inform the person who filed the petition of the denial and the reason for the denial, and request that the person correct and refile the petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(4): 20A-1-201; 20A-1-202 After making the determination described in Subsection (3)(c), the lieutenant governor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(4)(a): inform the person who filed the petition of the determination;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(4)(b): inform the county in which the preliminary municipality is located of the determination; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(4)(c): 20A-1-201; 20A-1-202 direct the county to conduct an election for mayor and city council of the future town, to be held on the date of the next regular general election described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(5): 63G-30-102 The county shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(5)(a): comply with the direction given by the lieutenant governor under Subsection (4)(c);
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(5)(b): determine the initial terms of the mayor and municipal council members to ensure that:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(5)(b)(i): the mayor and two of the municipal county members are elected in the next municipal general election;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(5)(b)(ii): the remaining municipal council members are elected at elections that result in the staggering of council member terms; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(5)(b)(iii): the council members who receive the highest number of votes are assigned the longer initial terms; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(5)(c): 63G-30-102 provide notice of the election for the preliminary municipality as a class B notice under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(6): The notice described in Subsection (5)(c) shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(6)(a): a statement of the contents of the petition to transition the preliminary municipality to a town;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(6)(b): a description of the area to be incorporated as a town;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(6)(c): the name of the town;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(6)(d): information about the deadline for an individual to file a declaration of candidacy to become a candidate for mayor or municipal council;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(6)(e): information about the initial terms of office;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(6)(f): a statement of the date and time of the election and the location of polling places; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(6)(g): a statement that the purpose of the election is to elect a mayor and a council to govern the town upon the town's incorporation.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(7): 20A-7-402
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(7)(a): 20A-7-402 In addition to the notice described in Subsection (6), the county clerk shall publish and distribute, before the election is held, a voter information pamphlet:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(7)(a)(i): 20A-7-402 in accordance with the procedures and requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(7)(a)(ii): in consultation with the lieutenant governor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(7)(a)(iii): in a manner that the county clerk determines is adequate.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(7)(b)(i): shall inform the public of the election and the purpose of the election; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(7)(b)(ii): may include additional information regarding the election of the elected officials and the incorporation of the town.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(8): 20A-1-102 An individual may not vote in the election described in this section unless the individual is a registered voter who is a resident, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(9): The town, incorporated under Subsection (10)(b), shall pay to the county the cost of running the election described in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(10): On the day after the day on which the canvass for the election is completed:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(10)(a): the elected mayor and council members shall take office and replace the board chair and board members of the preliminary municipality;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(10)(b): the lieutenant governor shall issue a certification that the preliminary municipality has transitioned to, and is incorporated as, a town; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(10)(c): subject to Subsection (14), the town holds all authority and power of a town.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(11): The former mayor and council members for the preliminary municipality shall assist the newly-elected mayor of the town and the newly-elected council members of the town with the transition to a town and the transfer of power to the elected government of the town.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(12): The initial government of a town incorporated under this section is the five member council form of government described in Chapter 3b, Part 4, Five-Member Council Form of Municipal Government, with the mayor and counsel members elected at large.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(13): Within 30 days after the day on which the mayor takes office under Subsection (10)(a), the mayor shall record the certification described in Subsection (10)(b), and a copy of the plat for the municipality, with the county recorder.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(14): Until the mayor complies with Subsection (13), the municipality may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(14)(a): levy or collect a property tax on property within the municipality;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(14)(b): levy or collect an assessment on property within the municipality; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-2a-510(14)(c): charge or collect a fee for a service provided to property within the municipality.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 10 - Chapter 3 - Municipal Government
*****************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-201 Municipal general election -- Terms of office.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-201(1): 20A-1-202 Consistent with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-201(2): The officers so elected shall begin their term of office at 12 o'clock noon on the first Monday in January following their election.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-202 Terms of elected municipal officers.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Each elected officer of a municipality shall hold office for the term for which he is elected and until his successor is chosen and qualified, unless the office becomes vacant under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-205 Election of officers in municipalities operating under a city council form of government.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Each municipality operating under a five-member or six-member city council form of government  shall hold municipal elections to fill, for a term of four years, the following offices in the following years:Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-205(1): in the year following a year in which a presidential election is held, the offices of:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-205(1)(a): approximately half the council members; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-205(1)(b): except as provided in Subsection (2)(b), mayor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-205(2): in the year preceding a year in which a presidential election is held, the  offices of:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-205(2)(a): the remaining council members; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-205(2)(b): for a municipality that elected a mayor in 2015 for a term of four years, mayor.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-205.5 At-large election of officers -- Election of commissioners or council members.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-205.5(1): Except as provided in Subsection (2), (3), or (4), the officers of each city shall be elected in an at-large election held at the time and in the manner provided for electing municipal officers.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-205.5(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-205.5(2)(a): The governing body of a city may by ordinance provide for the election of some or all commissioners or council members, as the case may be, by district equal in number to the number of commissioners or council members elected by district.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-205.5(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-205.5(2)(b)(i): Each district shall be of substantially equal population as the other districts.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-205.5(2)(b)(ii): Within six months after the Legislature completes its redistricting process, the governing body of each city that has adopted an ordinance under Subsection (2)(a) shall make any adjustments in the boundaries of the districts as may be required to maintain districts of substantially equal population.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208 Campaign finance disclosure in municipal election.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1): 20A-11-101; 20A-11-101; 20A-11-101; 20A-11-101; 20A-11-101; 20A-11-1501 Unless a municipality adopts by ordinance more stringent definitions, the following are defined terms for purposes of this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(a): "Agent of a candidate" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(a)(i): a person acting on behalf of a candidate at the direction of the reporting entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(a)(ii): a person employed by a candidate in the candidate's capacity as a candidate;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(a)(iii): the personal campaign committee of a candidate;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(a)(iv): a member of the personal campaign committee of a candidate in the member's capacity as a member of the personal campaign committee of the candidate; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(a)(v): a political consultant of a candidate.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(b): "Anonymous contribution limit" means for each calendar year:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(b)(i): $50; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(b)(ii): an amount less than $50 that is specified in an ordinance of the municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(c)(i): "Candidate" means a person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(c)(i)(A): files a declaration of candidacy for municipal office; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(c)(i)(B): receives contributions, makes expenditures, or gives consent for any other person to receive contributions or make expenditures to bring about the person's nomination or election to a municipal office.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(c)(ii): "Candidate" does not mean a person who files for the office of judge.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(d)(i): "Contribution" means any of the following when done for political purposes:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(d)(i)(A): a gift, subscription, donation, loan, advance, or deposit of money or anything of value given to a candidate;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(d)(i)(B): an express, legally enforceable contract, promise, or agreement to make a gift, subscription, donation, unpaid or partially unpaid loan, advance, or deposit of money or anything of value to the candidate;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(d)(i)(C): any transfer of funds from another reporting entity to the candidate;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(d)(i)(D): compensation paid by any person or reporting entity other than the candidate for personal services provided without charge to the candidate;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(d)(i)(E): a loan made by a candidate deposited to the candidate's own campaign; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(d)(i)(F): an in-kind contribution.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(d)(ii): "Contribution" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(d)(ii)(A): services provided by an individual volunteering a portion or all of the individual's time on behalf of the candidate if the services are provided without compensation by the candidate or any other person;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(d)(ii)(B): money lent to the candidate by a financial institution in the ordinary course of business; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(d)(ii)(C): goods or services provided for the benefit of a candidate at less than fair market value that are not authorized by or coordinated with the candidate.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(e): "Coordinated with" means that goods or services provided for the benefit of a candidate are provided:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(e)(i): with the candidate's prior knowledge, if the candidate does not object;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(e)(ii): by agreement with the candidate;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(e)(iii): in coordination with the candidate; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(e)(iv): using official logos, slogans, and similar elements belonging to a candidate.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(f): 20A-11-101
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(f)(i): 20A-11-101 "Expenditure" means any of the following made by a candidate or an agent of the candidate on behalf of the candidate:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(f)(i)(A): any disbursement from contributions, receipts, or from an account described in Subsection (3)(a);
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(f)(i)(B): a purchase, payment, donation, distribution, loan, advance, deposit, gift of money, or anything of value made for political purposes;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(f)(i)(C): an express, legally enforceable contract, promise, or agreement to make any purchase, payment, donation, distribution, loan, advance, deposit, gift of money, or anything of value for a political purpose;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(f)(i)(D): compensation paid by a candidate for personal services rendered by a person without charge to a reporting entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(f)(i)(E): 20A-11-101 a transfer of funds between the candidate and a candidate's personal campaign committee as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(f)(i)(F): goods or services provided by a reporting entity to or for the benefit of the candidate for political purposes at less than fair market value.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(f)(ii): "Expenditure" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(f)(ii)(A): services provided without compensation by an individual volunteering a portion or all of the individual's time on behalf of a candidate; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(f)(ii)(B): money lent to a candidate by a financial institution in the ordinary course of business.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(g): "In-kind contribution" means anything of value other than money, that is accepted by or coordinated with a candidate.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(h): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(h)(i): "Political consultant" means a person who is paid by a candidate, or paid by another person on behalf of and with the knowledge of the candidate, to provide political advice to the candidate.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(h)(ii): "Political consultant" includes a circumstance described in Subsection (1)(h)(i), where the person:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(h)(ii)(A): has already been paid, with money or other consideration;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(h)(ii)(B): expects to be paid in the future, with money or other consideration; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(h)(ii)(C): understands that the person may, in the discretion of the candidate or another person on behalf of and with the knowledge of the candidate, be paid in the future, with money or other consideration.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(i): "Political purposes" means an act done with the intent or in a way to influence or tend to influence, directly or indirectly, any person to refrain from voting or to vote for or against any candidate or a person seeking a municipal office at any caucus, political convention, or election.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(j): 20A-11-101; 20A-11-101; 20A-11-101; 20A-11-101; 20A-11-1501 "Reporting entity" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(j)(i): a candidate;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(j)(ii): a committee appointed by a candidate to act for the candidate;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(j)(iii): a person who holds an elected municipal office;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(j)(iv): 20A-11-101 a party committee as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(j)(v): 20A-11-101 a political action committee as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(j)(vi): 20A-11-101 a political issues committee as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(j)(vii): 20A-11-101 a corporation as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(1)(j)(viii): 20A-11-1501 a labor organization as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(2)(a): A municipality may adopt an ordinance establishing campaign finance disclosure requirements for a candidate that are more stringent than the requirements provided in Subsections (3) through (7).
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(2)(b): The municipality may adopt definitions that are more stringent than those provided in Subsection (1).
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(2)(c): If a municipality fails to adopt a campaign finance disclosure ordinance described in Subsection (2)(a), a candidate shall comply with financial reporting requirements contained in Subsections (3) through (7).
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(3): Each candidate:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(3)(a): shall deposit a contribution in a separate campaign account in a financial institution; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(3)(b): may not deposit or mingle any campaign contributions received into a personal or business account.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(4): 20A-1-201.5
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(4)(a): 20A-1-201.5 In a year in which a municipal primary is held, each candidate who will participate in the municipal primary shall file a campaign finance statement with the municipal clerk or recorder no later than seven days before the day described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(4)(b): Each candidate who is not eliminated at a municipal primary election shall file a campaign finance statement with the municipal clerk or recorder no later than:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(4)(b)(i): 28 days before the day on which the municipal general election is held;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(4)(b)(ii): seven days before the day on which the municipal general election is held; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(4)(b)(iii): 30 days after the day on which the municipal general election is held.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(4)(c): Each candidate for municipal office who is eliminated at a municipal primary election shall file with the municipal clerk or recorder a campaign finance statement within 30 days after the day on which the municipal primary election is held.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(5): If a municipality does not conduct a primary election for a race, each candidate who will participate in that race shall file a campaign finance statement with the municipal clerk or recorder no later than:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(5)(a): 28 days before the day on which the municipal general election is held;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(5)(b): seven days before the day on which the municipal general election is held; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(5)(c): 30 days after the day on which the municipal general election is held.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(6): Each campaign finance statement described in Subsection (4) or (5) shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(6)(a): except as provided in Subsection (6)(b):
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(6)(a)(i): report all of the candidate's itemized and total:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(6)(a)(i)(A): contributions, including in-kind and other nonmonetary contributions, received up to and including five days before the campaign finance statement is due, excluding a contribution previously reported; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(6)(a)(i)(B): expenditures made up to and including five days before the campaign finance statement is due, excluding an expenditure previously reported; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(6)(a)(ii): identify:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(6)(a)(ii)(A): for each contribution, the amount of the contribution and the name of the donor, if known; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(6)(a)(ii)(B): for each expenditure, the amount of the expenditure and the name of the recipient of the expenditure; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(6)(b): report the total amount of all contributions and expenditures if the candidate receives $500 or less in contributions and spends $500 or less on the candidate's campaign.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(7): Within 30 days after receiving a contribution that is cash or a negotiable instrument, exceeds the anonymous contribution limit, and is from a donor whose name is unknown, a candidate shall disburse the amount of the contribution to:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(7)(a): the treasurer of the state or a political subdivision for deposit into the state's or political subdivision's general fund; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(7)(b): an organization that is exempt from federal income taxation under Section 501(c)(3), Internal Revenue Code.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(8)(a): A municipality may, by ordinance:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(8)(a)(i): provide an anonymous contribution limit less than $50;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(8)(a)(ii): require greater disclosure of contributions or expenditures than is required in this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(8)(a)(iii): impose additional penalties on candidates who fail to comply with the applicable requirements beyond those imposed by this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(8)(b): A candidate is subject to the provisions of this section and not the provisions of an ordinance adopted by the municipality under Subsection (8)(a) if:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(8)(b)(i): the municipal ordinance establishes requirements or penalties that differ from those established in this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(8)(b)(ii): the municipal clerk or recorder fails to notify the candidate of the provisions of the ordinance as required in Subsection (9).
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(9): Each municipal clerk or recorder shall, at the time the candidate for municipal office files a declaration of candidacy, and again 35 days before each municipal general election, notify the candidate in writing of:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(9)(a): the provisions of statute or municipal ordinance governing the disclosure of contributions and expenditures;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(9)(b): the dates when the candidate's campaign finance statement is required to be filed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(9)(c): the penalties that apply for failure to file a timely campaign finance statement, including the statutory provision that requires removal of the candidate's name from the ballot for failure to file the required campaign finance statement when required.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(10): 20A-11-103(4)(b)(ii) Notwithstanding any provision of Title 63G, Chapter 2, Government Records Access and Management Act, the municipal clerk or recorder shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(10)(a): make each campaign finance statement filed by a candidate available for public inspection and copying no later than one business day after the statement is filed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(10)(b): 20A-11-103(4)(b)(ii) make the campaign finance statement filed by a candidate available for public inspection by:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(10)(b)(i): posting an electronic copy or the contents of the statement on the municipality's website no later than seven business days after the day on which the statement is filed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(10)(b)(ii): 20A-11-103(4)(b)(ii) in order to comply with the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(11): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(11)(a): If a candidate fails to timely file a campaign finance statement required under Subsection (4) or (5), the municipal clerk or recorder:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(11)(a)(i): may send an electronic notice to the candidate that states:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(11)(a)(i)(A): that the candidate failed to timely file the campaign finance statement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(11)(a)(i)(B): that, if the candidate fails to file the report within 24 hours after the deadline for filing the report, the candidate will be disqualified; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(11)(a)(ii): may impose a fine of $50 on the candidate.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(11)(b): The municipal clerk or recorder shall disqualify a candidate and inform the appropriate election official that the candidate is disqualified if the candidate fails to file a campaign finance statement described in Subsection (4) or (5) within 24 hours after the deadline for filing the report.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(11)(c): If a candidate is disqualified under Subsection (11)(b), the election official:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(11)(c)(i): shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(11)(c)(i)(A): notify every opposing candidate for the municipal office that the candidate is disqualified;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(11)(c)(i)(B): send an email notification to each voter who is eligible to vote in the municipal election office race for whom the election official has an email address informing the voter that the candidate is disqualified and that votes cast for the candidate will not be counted;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(11)(c)(i)(C): post notice of the disqualification on a public website; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(11)(c)(i)(D): if practicable, remove the candidate's name from the ballot by blacking out the candidate's name before the ballots are delivered to voters; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(11)(c)(ii): may not count any votes for that candidate.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(12): An election official may fulfill the requirements described in Subsection (11)(c)(i) in relation to a mailed ballot, including a military overseas ballot, by including with the ballot a written notice:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(12)(a): informing the voter that the candidate is disqualified; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(12)(b): directing the voter to a public website to inform the voter whether a candidate on the ballot is disqualified.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(13): Notwithstanding Subsection (11)(b), a candidate who timely files each campaign finance statement required under Subsection (4) or (5) is not disqualified if:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(13)(a): the statement details accurately and completely the information required under Subsection (6), except for inadvertent omissions or insignificant errors or inaccuracies; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(13)(b): the omissions, errors, or inaccuracies are corrected in an amended report or in the next scheduled report.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(14): A candidate for municipal office who is disqualified under Subsection (11)(b) shall file with the municipal clerk or recorder a complete and accurate campaign finance statement within 30 days after the day on which the candidate is disqualified.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(15): A campaign finance statement required under this section is considered filed if it is received in the municipal clerk or recorder's office by 5 p.m. on the date that it is due.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(16): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(16)(a): A private party in interest may bring a civil action in a court with jurisdiction under Title 78A, Judiciary and Judicial Administration, to enforce the provisions of this section or an ordinance adopted under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-208(16)(b): In a civil action under Subsection (16)(a), the court may award costs and attorney fees to the prevailing party.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209 Personal use expenditure -- Authorized and prohibited uses of campaign funds -- Enforcement -- Penalties.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(1): Unless a municipality adopts by ordinance more stringent definitions, the following are defined terms for the purposes of this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(1)(a): "Candidate" means a person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(1)(a)(i): files a declaration of candidacy for municipal office; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(1)(a)(ii): receives contributions, makes expenditures, or gives consent for any other person to receive contributions or make expenditures to bring about the person's nomination or election to a public office.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(1)(b): "Officeholder" means a person who is elected to and currently holds a municipal office.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(1)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(1)(c)(i): "Personal use expenditure" means an expenditure that:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(1)(c)(i)(A): is not excluded from the definition of personal use expenditure by Subsection (2) and primarily furthers a personal interest of a candidate or officeholder or a candidate's or officeholder's family, which interest is not connected with the performance of an activity as a candidate or an activity or duty of an officeholder; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(1)(c)(i)(B): would cause the candidate or officeholder to recognize the expenditure as taxable income under federal law.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(1)(c)(ii): "Personal use expenditure" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(1)(c)(ii)(A): a mortgage, rent, utility, or vehicle payment;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(1)(c)(ii)(B): a household food item or supply;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(1)(c)(ii)(C): a clothing expense, except:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(1)(c)(ii)(C)(I): clothing bearing the candidate's name or campaign slogan or logo that is used in the candidate's campaign;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(1)(c)(ii)(C)(II): clothing bearing the logo or name of a jurisdiction, district, government organization, government entity, caucus, or political party that the officeholder represents or of which the officeholder is a member; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(1)(c)(ii)(C)(III): repair or replacement of clothing that is damaged while the candidate or officeholder is engaged in an activity of a candidate or officeholder;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(1)(c)(ii)(D): an admission to a sporting, artistic, or recreational event or other form of entertainment;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(1)(c)(ii)(E): dues, fees, or gratuities at a country club, health club, or recreational facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(1)(c)(ii)(F): a salary payment made to a candidate, officeholder, or a person who has not provided a bona fide service to a candidate or officeholder;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(1)(c)(ii)(G): a vacation;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(1)(c)(ii)(H): a vehicle expense;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(1)(c)(ii)(I): a meal expense;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(1)(c)(ii)(J): a travel expense;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(1)(c)(ii)(K): a payment of an administrative, civil, or criminal penalty;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(1)(c)(ii)(L): a satisfaction of a personal debt;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(1)(c)(ii)(M): a personal service, including the service of an attorney, accountant, physician, or other professional person;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(1)(c)(ii)(N): a membership fee for a professional or service organization; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(1)(c)(ii)(O): a payment in excess of the fair market value of the item or service purchased.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(2): 63A-3-107; 59-13-102; 13-22-2; 13-22-2 As used in this section, "personal use expenditure" does not mean an expenditure made:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(2)(a): for a political purpose;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(2)(b): for candidacy for public office;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(2)(c): to fulfill a duty or activity of an officeholder;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(2)(d): for a donation to a registered political party;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(2)(e): for a contribution to another candidate's campaign account, including sponsorship of or attendance at an event, the primary purpose of which is to solicit a contribution for another candidate's campaign account;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(2)(f): to return all or a portion of a contribution to a donor;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(2)(g): 63A-3-107; 59-13-102 for the following items, if made in connection with the candidacy for public office or an activity or duty of an officeholder:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(2)(g)(i): 63A-3-107; 59-13-102
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(2)(g)(i)(A): 63A-3-107 a mileage allowance at the rate established by the Division of Finance under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(2)(g)(i)(B): 59-13-102 for motor fuel or special fuel, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(2)(g)(ii): a meal expense;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(2)(g)(iii): a travel expense, including an expense incurred for airfare or a rental vehicle;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(2)(g)(iv): a payment for a service provided by an attorney or accountant;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(2)(g)(v): a tuition payment or registration fee for participation in a meeting or conference;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(2)(g)(vi): a gift;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(2)(g)(vii): a payment for the following items in connection with an office space:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(2)(g)(vii)(A): rent;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(2)(g)(vii)(B): utilities;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(2)(g)(vii)(C): a supply; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(2)(g)(vii)(D): furnishing;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(2)(g)(viii): a booth at a meeting or event; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(2)(g)(ix): educational material;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(2)(h): to purchase or mail informational material, a survey, or a greeting card;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(2)(i): 13-22-2; 13-22-2 for a donation to a charitable organization, as defined by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(2)(j): to repay a loan a candidate makes from the candidate's personal account to the candidate's campaign account;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(2)(k): to pay membership dues to a national organization whose primary purpose is to address general public policy;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(2)(l): for admission to or sponsorship of an event, the primary purpose of which is to promote the social, educational, or economic well-being of the state or the candidate's or officeholder's community;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(2)(m): for one or more guests of an officeholder or candidate to attend an event, meeting, or conference described in this Subsection (2); or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(2)(n): to pay childcare expenses of:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(2)(n)(i): a candidate while the candidate is engaging in campaign activity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(2)(n)(ii): an officeholder while the officeholder is engaging in the duties of an officeholder.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(3)(a): A municipality may adopt an ordinance prohibiting a personal use expenditure by a candidate with requirements that are more stringent than the requirements provided in Subsection (4).
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(3)(b): The municipality may adopt definitions that are more stringent than those provided in Subsection (1) or (2).
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(3)(c): If a municipality fails to adopt a personal use expenditure ordinance described in Subsection (3)(a), a candidate shall comply with the requirements contained in Subsection (4).
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(4): A candidate or an officeholder may not use money deposited into a campaign account for:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(4)(a): a personal use expenditure; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(4)(b): an expenditure prohibited by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(5): A municipality may enforce this section by adopting an ordinance:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(5)(a): to provide for the evaluation of a campaign finance statement to identify a personal use expenditure; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(5)(b): to commence informal adjudicative proceedings if, after an evaluation described in Subsection (5)(a), there is probable cause to believe that a candidate or officeholder has made a personal use expenditure.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(6): If, in accordance with the proceedings described in Subsection (5)(b) established in municipal ordinance, a municipality determines that a candidate or officeholder has made a personal use expenditure, the municipality:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(6)(a): may require the candidate or officeholder to:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(6)(a)(i): remit an administrative penalty of an amount equal to 50% of the personal use expenditure to the municipality; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(6)(a)(ii): deposit the amount of the personal use expenditure into the campaign account from which the personal use expenditure was disbursed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-209(6)(b): shall deposit the money received under Subsection (6)(a)(i) into the municipal general fund.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-504 Quorum defined.
----------------------------------------------
The number of council members necessary to constitute a quorum is:Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-504(1): in a municipality with a seven-member council, four;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-504(2): in a municipality with a five-member council, three; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-504(3): in a municipality operating under a six-member council form of government, three, excluding the mayor.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-505 Compelling attendance at meetings of legislative body.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The legislative body of a municipality may compel the attendance of its own members at its meetings and provide penalties it considers necessary for the failure to comply with an exercise of the authority to compel attendance.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-506 How the vote is taken.
-----------------------------------------------------
A roll call vote shall be taken and recorded for all ordinances, resolutions, and any action which would create a liability against the municipality and in any other case at the request of any member of the governing body by a "yes" or a "no" vote and shall be recorded. Every resolution or ordinance shall be in writing before the vote is taken.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-507 Minimum vote required.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-507(1): The minimum number of yes votes required to pass any ordinance or resolution, or to take any action by the council, unless otherwise prescribed by law, is a majority of the voting members of the council, regardless of absence or vacancy.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-507(2): (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-507(2)(a): Any ordinance, resolution, or motion of the council having fewer favorable votes than required in this section is defeated and invalid.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-507(2)(b): (2)(a) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-507(3): 20A-1-510 If a vacancy exists in one or more council seats, a majority of the council members may vote to fill the vacancy as provided under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-508 Reconsideration.
-----------------------------------------------
Any action taken by the governing body may not be reconsidered or rescinded at any special meeting unless the number of members of the governing body present at the special meeting is equal to or greater than the number of members present at the meeting when the action was approved.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-601 Business of governing body conducted only in open meeting.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
All meetings of the governing body of each municipality shall be held in compliance with the provisions of

Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-603 Public records.
----------------------------------------------
The governing body of each municipality shall keep a journal of its proceedings. The books, records, accounts and documents of each municipality shall be kept at the office of the recorder and approved copies shall be open and available to the public during regular business hours for examination and copying. The governing body may by resolution establish reasonable charges for providing copies of its public records to individuals, except when by law the municipality must provide the records without cost to the public.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-604 Annual examination of municipal finances -- Publication of results.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
At the end of each fiscal year, the governing body of each city of the first and second class shall cause a full and complete examination of all books and accounts of the city to be made by certified public accountants, and shall publish the results of the examination and a detailed and itemized statement of all receipts and disbursements of the city in a summary of their proceedings and expenses during the fiscal year. The city shall then provide printed copies to the newspapers of the city and to the city recorder who shall provide one copy of it to any person on request.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-605 Penalty.
---------------------------------------
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of Section

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-608 Rules of conduct for the public.
---------------------------------------------------------------
The governing body on a two-thirds vote may expel any person who is disorderly during the meeting of the governing body.  This section or any action taken by the governing body pursuant hereto does not preclude prosecution under any other provision of law.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-609 Action on committee reports.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Final action on any report of any committee appointed by the governing body shall be deferred to the next regular meeting of the governing body on the request of any two members, except that the council in a city of the third, fourth, or fifth class or a town may call a special meeting to consider final action.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-610 Requiring attendance of witnesses, production of evidence.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The governing body of each municipality may require the attendance of any person to give testimony or produce records, documents or things for inspection, copying or examination necessary or useful for the governance of the municipality. The governing body may by ordinance establish its own procedures for issuing subpoenas to require attendance and production under this section or it may issue subpoenas in its own name in the same manner as is provided in the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-701 Legislative power exercised by ordinance.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Except as otherwise specifically provided, the governing body of each municipality shall exercise its legislative powers through ordinances.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-3-702 Extent of power exercised by ordinance.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
The governing body may pass any ordinance to regulate, require, prohibit, govern, control or supervise any activity, business, conduct or condition authorized by this act or any other provision of law.  An officer of the municipality may not be convicted of a criminal offense where he relied on or enforced an ordinance he reasonably believed to be a valid ordinance.  It shall be a defense to any action for punitive damages that the official acted in good faith in enforcing an ordinance or that he enforced an ordinance on advice of legal counsel.
