Utah Code Annotated § 10-7-27 Street railway companies to restore streets.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every street railway company shall at its own expense restore the pavement, including the foundation thereof, of every street disturbed by it in the construction, reconstruction, removal or repair of its tracks, to the same condition as before the disturbance thereof, to the satisfaction of the governing body having charge of such street. The obligation imposed hereby shall, in cities other than cities of the first class, be in lieu and substitution of any and all other obligations of any such company to pave, repave or repair any street, or to pay any part of the cost thereof, and may be enforced in the same manner as similar obligations are or may be enforced under the laws of this state. Nothing herein contained shall be considered to relieve any such company from the repayment of any money which has heretofore been advanced or expended by any city for any paving heretofore done under or by virtue of a specific contract or agreement made and entered into between the board of commissioners or the city council of any city and such company providing for the repayment thereof, but the obligation for such repayment shall be and remain enforceable as if this section had not been passed.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-7-29 Railway companies to repave streets.
------------------------------------------------------------------
All railway companies shall be required to pave or repave at their own cost all the space between their different rails and tracks and also a space two feet wide outside of the outer rails of the outside tracks in any city or town, including all sidetracks, crossings and turnouts used by such companies. Where two or more companies occupy the same street or alley with separate tracks each company shall be responsible for its proportion of the surface of the street or alley occupied by all the parallel tracks as herein required. Such paving or repaving by such railway companies shall be done at the same time and shall be of the same material and character as the paving or repaving of the streets or alleys upon which the track or tracks are located, unless other material is specially ordered by the municipality. Such railway companies shall be required to keep that portion of the street which they are herein required to pave or repave in good and proper repair, using for that purpose the same material as the street upon which the track or tracks are laid at the point of repair or such other material as the governing body of the city may require and order; and as streets are hereafter paved or repaved street railway companies shall be required to lay in the best approved manner a rail to be approved by the governing body of the city. The tracks of all railway companies when located upon the streets or avenues of a city or town shall be kept in repair and safe in all respects for the use of the traveling public, and such companies shall be liable for all damages resulting by reason of neglect to keep such tracks in repair, or for obstructing the streets. For injuries to persons or property arising from the failure of any such company to keep its tracks in proper repair and free from obstructions such company shall be liable and the city or town shall be exempt from liability. The word "railway companies" as used in this section shall be taken to mean and include any persons, companies, corporations or associations owning or operating any street or other railway in any city or town.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-7-32 Actions to recover taxes.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-7-32(1): It shall also be competent for any municipality to bring a civil action against any party owning or operating any such railway liable to pay such taxes to recover the amount thereof, or any part thereof, delinquent and unpaid, in any court having jurisdiction of the amount, and obtain judgment and have execution therefor, and no property, real or personal, shall be exempt from any such execution; provided, that real estate may not be levied upon by execution except by execution out of the court on judgment therein, or transcript of judgment filed therein, as is now or hereafter may be provided by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-7-32(2): No defense shall be allowed in any such civil action except such as goes to the groundwork, equity and justice of the tax, and the burden of proof shall rest upon the party assailing the tax.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-7-32(3): In case part of such special tax shall be shown to be invalid, unjust or inequitable, judgment shall be rendered for such amount as is just and equitable.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-7-33 Delinquent taxes -- Installment payments -- Election and waiver.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
It shall be competent for the governing body, upon the written application of any company owning any such railway, to provide that such special taxes shall become delinquent and be payable in installments as in case of taxes levied upon abutting real estate as herein provided, but such application shall be taken and deemed a waiver of any and all objections to such taxes and the validity thereof. Such application shall be made at or before the final levy of such taxes.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-7-65 Party plaintiff -- Successive actions permitted.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
All actions brought to recover any fine or to enforce any penalty under an ordinance of a city or town shall be brought in the corporate name of the city or town as plaintiff.  No prosecution, recovery, or acquittal for the violation of any such ordinance shall constitute a defense to any other prosecution of the same person for any other violation of any such ordinance although the different causes of action existed at the same time and if united would not have exceeded the jurisdiction of a justice court judge.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-7-66 Fines and forfeitures to be paid to treasurer -- Exceptions.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Except where otherwise provided by law in relation to fines, fees, and forfeitures imposed or received by a court of this state, all fines and forfeitures for the violation of ordinances shall be paid into the treasury of the corporation at such times and in such manner as may be prescribed by ordinance.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-7-67 Pleading -- Reference to ordinance -- Judgment enforced by imprisonment.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In all actions for the violation of any ordinance it shall be sufficient if the complaint refers to the title and section of the ordinance under which such action is brought. Any person upon whom any fine or penalty shall be imposed may upon the order of the court before whom the conviction is had be committed to the county jail or the city prison or to such other place as may be provided for the incarceration of offenders until such fine, penalty and costs shall be fully paid.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-7-68 Service of process and arrests.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Any peace officer may serve any process or make any arrest authorized to be made by any city or town officer.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-7-69 Corporations may be complained against.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
A corporation violating any of the provisions of a city or town ordinance may be complained against the same as a natural person.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-7-70 Corporate violation -- Summons -- Forms.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Whenever complaint is made against a corporation for violation of a city or town ordinance summons shall be issued thereon substantially in the following form:

Utah Code Annotated § 10-7-71 Corporate violation -- Summons -- Time and manner of service.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The summons and copy of complaint shall be served at least 24 hours before the hour of appearance fixed therein by delivering to and leaving a copy thereof with the president or other head of the corporation, or the secretary, the cashier, or the managing or process agent thereof, and by showing to him the original summons.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-7-72 Appearance by agent of corporation -- Bench warrant for default.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
At the time appointed in the summons, the corporation shall appear by agent or attorney and plead thereto the same as a natural person.  In case no appearance is made on or before the hour appointed, the court may issue a bench warrant for the person served as the officer or agent of the corporation, requiring him to be brought forthwith before the court to plead on its behalf.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-7-73 Corporate violation -- Hearing -- Penalty imposed to be a fine.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
After the plea of the corporation is entered the court shall fix a time for the hearing of the cause, and thereafter the proceedings therein shall be the same as in the cases of natural persons charged with violating a city or town ordinance, except that in cases of conviction the penalty imposed in all instances shall be by way of fine.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-7-74 Execution on judgment against corporation.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Whenever a fine and costs, either or both, shall be imposed upon a corporation upon conviction for a violation of a city or town ordinance, judgment therefor may be collected on execution issued out of the court in the same manner as an execution in a civil action.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-7-76 Payment of witness fees and mileage.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Whenever a criminal action arising out of the violation of a city or town ordinance is tried on appeal, the per diems and mileage of witnesses for the prosecution shall be paid out of the treasury of the city or town in which such action originated.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-7-79 Power of board of city commissioners or council to provide for development of resources.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The boards of city commissioners or city councils of the respective cities within the state are authorized and empowered to provide for the development of the city's mineral, water, manpower, industrial and other resources.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-7-80 Development committee -- Appointment of members -- Terms, compensation and expenses, vacancies and removal of members.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The board of city commissioners or council of any city within the state is hereby authorized and empowered to appoint by resolution an unpaid commission of three or more members, to be known as the city resource development committee. One or more members of the board of city commissioners or council shall be designated by the board of city commissioners or council as members of such committee. Each of the other members of the committee shall be a resident of the city. The term of appointed members of the committee shall be two years and until their respective successors have been appointed. The members of the committee shall serve as such without compensation, except that the board of city commissioners or council may provide for reimbursement of the members of the committee for actual expenses incurred, upon presentation of proper receipts and vouchers. The board of city commissioners or council shall provide for the filling of vacancies in the membership of the committee and for the removal of a member for nonperformance of duty or misconduct.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-7-81 Development committee -- Election of officers -- Employment of executive director.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The city resource development committee may elect such officers from its members as it may deem advisable and may, with consent and approval of the board of city commissioners or council, employ an executive director for the committee.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-7-82 Development committee -- Functions.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
It shall be the function of the city resource development committee to assist in the development of the city's mineral, water, manpower, industrial and other resources, and to make such recommendations to the board of city commissioners or council for resource development programs as it may deem advisable.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-7-83 Power of board of city commissioners or council to contract with other authorities.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The board of city commissioners or council may co-operate with and enter into contracts with other municipalities, local communities and counties for the purpose of promoting the development of the economic resources of their respective areas.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-7-84 Expenditure of city funds authorized.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
The board of city commissioners or council may expend city funds as are deemed advisable to carry out the purposes of this act.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-7-85 Support of the arts.
--------------------------------------------------
The governing body of any municipality may provide for and appropriate funds for the support of the arts, including music, dance, theatre, crafts and visual, folk and literary art, for the purpose of enriching the lives of its residents and may establish guidelines for the support of the arts.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-7-86 Municipality may adopt Utah Procurement Code -- Hiring of professional architect, engineer, or surveyor.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-7-86(1): Title 63G, Chapter 6a, Utah Procurement Code The governing body of any municipality may adopt any or all of the provisions of
Utah Code Annotated § 10-7-86(2): (1); (2)(a) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-7-86(2)(a): shall consider, as a minimum, in the selection process:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-7-86(2)(a)(i): the qualifications, experience, and background of each firm submitting a proposal;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-7-86(2)(a)(ii): the specific individuals assigned to the project and the time commitments of each to the project; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-7-86(2)(a)(iii): the project schedule and the approach to the project that the firm will take; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-7-86(2)(b): (2)(a) may engage the services of a professional architect, engineer, or surveyor based on the criteria under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-1 Control of finances and property.
--------------------------------------------------------------
The boards of commissioners and city councils of cities shall have the power to control the finances and property of the corporation.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-2.5 Prohibition against spending certain transportation funds.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-2.5(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-2.5(1)(a): "Apportioned" means divided or assigned among the states based on a prescribed formula established in 23 U.S.C.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-2.5(1)(b): "Authorization act" means an act of Congress enacted after July 1, 2009 that authorizes transportation programs from the Highway Trust Fund established in 26 U.S.C. Sec. 9503.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-2.5(2): A municipality may not spend project-specific funds that are allocated through an authorization act for a transportation-related project that is eligible for funds apportioned to the state in support of the statewide transportation improvement program unless the specified project is included on the statewide transportation improvement program.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-3 Tax districts.
-------------------------------------------
They may divide the city into districts for the purpose of local taxation as occasion may require.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-4 Special taxes and licenses.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-4(1): (2) Municipal legislative bodies may:

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-4(2)(a): Municipal legislative bodies may not discriminate between resident community businesses and nonresident community businesses in establishing license requirements.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-4(2)(b)(i): are licensed as dealers in another municipality; or

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-5 Erection and care of buildings.
------------------------------------------------------------
They may erect all needful buildings for the use of the city, and provide for their care.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-6 Borrowing power -- Warrants and bonds.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
They may borrow money on the credit of the corporation for corporate purposes in the manner and to the extent allowed by the Constitution and the laws, and issue warrants and bonds therefor in such amounts and forms and on such conditions as they shall determine.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-7 Refunding bonds -- Purpose of issuance.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
They may issue bonds in place of or to supply means to meet maturing bonds or for the consolidation or refunding of the same.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-8 Streets, parks, airports, parking facilities, public grounds, and pedestrian malls.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A municipal legislative body may lay out, establish, open, alter, widen, narrow, extend, grade, pave, or otherwise improve streets, alleys, avenues, boulevards, sidewalks, parks, airports, parking lots, or other facilities for the parking of vehicles off streets, public grounds, and pedestrian malls and may close, in accordance with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-8.6 Widening a street or alley.
----------------------------------------------------------
Before a city may widen a street or alley in such a way that access to underground facilities is affected, the city shall notify in writing, and consult with, the owners or operators of the underground facilities, as defined in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-9 Bathhouses, playgrounds.
-----------------------------------------------------
They may establish, maintain and provide for the supervision of bathhouses, public playgrounds, recreation places and swimming pools.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-10 Trees.
------------------------------------
They may plant, or direct and regulate the planting of, ornamental shade trees in streets, parks and public grounds.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-11 Streets -- Encroachments, lighting, sprinkling, cleaning.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
They may regulate the use of streets, alleys, avenues, sidewalks, crosswalks, parks, and public grounds, install, prevent, or remove obstructions and encroachments thereon, and provide for the lighting, sprinkling, and cleaning of the same.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-13 Conduits, drains, etc.
----------------------------------------------------
They may regulate the opening and use of streets, alleys, sidewalks, crosswalks and public grounds for the laying of gas or water mains and of conduits and pipes, and the building and repairing of sewers, tunnels, conduits and drains.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22 Water rates.
------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(1): (1)(c); (1)(c)(i) As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(1)(a): (1)(c) "Designated water service area" means the area defined by a municipality in accordance with the
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(1)(b): "Large municipal drinking water system" means a municipally owned and operated drinking water system serving a population of 10,000 or more.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(1)(c): (1)(c)(i) "Retail customer" means an end user:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(1)(c)(i): who receives culinary water directly from a municipality's waterworks system; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(1)(c)(ii): (1)(c)(i) whom the municipality described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(2): A municipality shall fix the rates to be paid for the use of water furnished by the municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(3): The setting of municipal water rates is a legislative act.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(4): Within the municipality's designated water service area, a municipality shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(4)(a): establish, by ordinance, reasonable rates for the services provided to the municipality's retail customers;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(4)(b): use the same method of providing notice to all retail customers of proposed rate changes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(4)(c): allow all retail customers the same opportunity to appear and participate in a public meeting addressing water rates.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(5)(a): A municipality may establish different rates for different classifications of retail customers within the municipality's designated water service area, if the rates and classifications have a reasonable basis.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(5)(b): A reasonable basis for charging different rates for different classifications may include, among other things, a situation in which:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(5)(b)(i): there is a difference in the cost of providing service to a particular classification;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(5)(b)(ii): one classification bears more risk in relation to a system operation or obligation;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(5)(b)(iii): retail customers in one classification invested or contributed to acquire a water source or supply or build or maintain a system differently than retail customers in another classification;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(5)(b)(iv): the needs or conditions of one classification:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(5)(b)(iv)(A): are distinguishable from the needs or conditions of another classification; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(5)(b)(iv)(B): based on economic, public policy, or other identifiable elements, support a different rate; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(5)(b)(v): there is a differential between the classifications based on a cost of service standard or a generally accepted rate setting method, including a standard or method the American Water Works Association establishes.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(5)(c): An adjustment based solely on the fact that a particular classification of retail customers is located either inside or outside of the municipality's corporate boundary is not a reasonable basis.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(6): (6)(a)(ii); (6)(b)(i); (ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(6)(a): If more than 10% of the retail customers within a large municipal drinking water system's designated water service area are located outside of the municipality's corporate boundary, the municipality shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(6)(a)(i): post on the municipality's website the rates assessed to retail customers within the designated water service area; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(6)(a)(ii): establish an advisory board to make recommendations to the municipal legislative body regarding water rates, capital projects, and other water service standards.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(6)(b): (6)(a)(ii); (6)(b)(i); (ii) In establishing an advisory board described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(6)(b)(i): if more than 10% but no more than 30% of the municipality's retail customers receive service outside the municipality's municipal boundary, ensure that at least 20% of the advisory board's members represent the municipality's retail customers receiving service outside the municipality's municipal boundary;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(6)(b)(ii): if more than 30% of the municipality's retail customers receive service outside of the municipality's municipal boundary, ensure that at least 40% of the advisory board's members represent the municipality's retail customers receiving service outside of the municipality's municipal boundary; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(6)(b)(iii): (6)(b)(i); (ii) in appointing board members who represent retail customers receiving service outside of the municipality's municipal boundary, as required in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(7): A municipality that supplies water outside of the municipality's designated water service area shall supply the water only by contract and shall include in the contract the terms and conditions under which the contract can be terminated.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(8): (8)(a) A municipality shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(8)(a): notify the director of the Division of Drinking Water of a contract the municipality enters into with a person outside of the municipality's designated water service area, including the name and contact information of the person named in each contract; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-22(8)(b): (8)(a) each year, provide any supplementing or new information regarding a contract described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-23 Sidewalks -- Regulation and control -- Owners required to remove weeds, litter, snow and ice.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
They may regulate and control the use of sidewalks and all structures thereunder or thereover; and they may require the owner or occupant, or the agent of any owner or occupant, of property to remove all weeds and noxious vegetation from such property, and in front thereof to the curb line of the street, and to keep the sidewalks in front of such property free from litter, snow, ice and obstructions.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-24 Litter in streets.
------------------------------------------------
They may regulate and prevent the throwing or depositing of ashes, offal, dirt, garbage or any offensive matter in, and prevent injury or obstruction to, any street, sidewalk, avenue, alley, park or public ground.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-25 Crosswalks, curbs and gutters.
------------------------------------------------------------
They may provide for and regulate the use of crosswalks, curbs and gutters.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-26 Signs and advertising material.
-------------------------------------------------------------
They may regulate or prevent the use of streets, sidewalks, public buildings and grounds for signs, signposts, awnings, horse troughs or racks, or for posting handbills or advertisements.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-27 Placards and handbills.
-----------------------------------------------------
They may regulate or prohibit the exhibition, distribution or carrying of placards or handbills on the streets, public grounds or sidewalks.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-28 Flags and banners.
------------------------------------------------
They may regulate or prevent the flying of flags, banners or signs across the streets or from houses.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-29 Sales and merchandising on streets.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
They may regulate merchandising and sales upon the streets, sidewalks and public places.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-30 Traffic regulations.
--------------------------------------------------
They may regulate the movement of traffic on the streets, sidewalks and public places, including the movement of pedestrians as well as of vehicles, and the cars and engines of railroads, street railroads and tramways, and may prevent racing and immoderate driving or riding.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-31 Numbering houses and lots.
--------------------------------------------------------
They may regulate the numbering of houses and lots.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-32 Naming streets and public places.
---------------------------------------------------------------
They may name streets, courts, parks, thoroughfares and other public places and change the names thereof.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-33 Railroads -- Tracks and franchises.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
They may permit, regulate or prohibit the locating, constructing or laying of the tracks of any railroad, or tramway in any street, alley or public place; and may by ordinance grant franchises to railroad and street railroad companies, and to union railroad depot companies, to lay, maintain and operate in any street or part or parts of streets or other public places tracks therefor, but such permission may not be exclusive or for a longer time than 100 years.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-34 Change of grade and crossings -- Nonuser as grounds for removal.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
They may provide for or change the location, grade or crossing of any railroad; and declare a nuisance and take up and remove, or cause to be taken up and removed, the tracks of any railroad or street railway company which shall have been laid upon the streets of the city and which such railway company has failed to operate with cars for public use for a period of nine months after the laying thereof.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-35 Fences, cattle guards and street crossings -- Duty of railroads.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
They may require railroad companies to fence their respective railroads or any portion of the same, and to construct cattle guards, crossings of streets and public roads, and keep the same in repair within the limits of the corporation.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-36 Flagmen -- Grade crossings -- Drains along tracks.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
They may require railroad companies to keep flagmen at railroad crossings of streets, or otherwise provide protection against injury to persons or property; may compel railroad and street railroad companies to raise or lower their tracks to conform to any grade which at any time may be established by the city, so that such tracks may be crossed at any place on any street, alley or highway; may compel railway companies to make and keep open, and keep in repair, ditches, drains, sewers and culverts along and under their tracks, so that the natural or artificial drainage of adjacent property may not be impaired.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-37 Construction, repair, and maintenance of bridges, viaducts, and tunnels -- Retainage.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-37(1): They may construct and keep in repair bridges, viaducts and tunnels, and regulate the use thereof.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-37(2): 13-8-5 If any payment on a contract with a private person, firm, or corporation to construct bridges, viaducts, or tunnels is retained or withheld, it shall be retained or withheld and released as provided in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-38(2): (2)(a)(i)

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-38(2)(d): A municipality may sell and deliver water or sewer services to others beyond the limits of the municipality from the surplus capacity of the municipality's waterworks or sewer system.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41 Prostitution, lewd or perverted acts, gambling, and obscene or lewd publications.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41(1): Boards of commissioners and city councils of cities may suppress and prohibit the keeping of disorderly houses, houses of ill fame or assignation, or houses kept by, maintained for, or resorted to or used by, one or more persons for acts of perversion, lewdness, or prostitution within the limits of the city and within three miles of the outer boundaries thereof, and may prohibit resorting thereto for any of the purposes aforesaid; they may also make it unlawful for any person to commit or offer or agree to commit an act of sexual intercourse for hire, lewdness, or moral perversion within the city, or for any person to secure, induce, procure, offer, or transport to any place within the city any person for the purpose of committing an act of sexual intercourse for hire, lewdness, or moral perversion, or for any person to receive or direct or offer or agree to receive or direct any person into any place or building within the city for the purpose of committing an act of sexual intercourse for hire, lewdness, or moral perversion, or for any person to aid, abet, or participate in the commission of any of the foregoing; and they may also suppress and prohibit gambling houses and gambling, lotteries and all fraudulent devices and practices, and all kinds of gaming, playing at dice or cards, and other games of chance, and the sale, distribution, or exhibition of obscene or lewd publications, prints, pictures, or illustrations.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41(2)(a): A woman's breast feeding, including breast feeding in any place where the woman otherwise may rightfully  be, does not under any circumstance constitute an obscene or lewd act, irrespective of whether or not the breast is covered during or incidental to feeding.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41(2)(b): Boards of commissioners and city councils of cities may not prohibit a woman's breast feeding in any location where she otherwise may rightfully be, irrespective of whether the breast is uncovered during or incidental to the breast feeding.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5 Regulation of sexually oriented business.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(1)(a): "Adult service" means dancing, serving food or beverages, modeling, posing, wrestling, singing, reading, talking, listening, or other performances or activities conducted by a nude or partially denuded individual for compensation.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(1)(b): "Compensation" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(1)(b)(i): a salary;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(1)(b)(ii): a fee;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(1)(b)(iii): a commission;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(1)(b)(iv): employment;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(1)(b)(v): a profit; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(1)(b)(vi): other pecuniary gain.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(1)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(1)(c)(i): "Escort" means a person who, for compensation, dates, socializes with, visits, consorts with, or accompanies another, or offers to date, consort with, socialize with, visit, or accompany another:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(1)(c)(i)(A): to a social affair, entertainment, or a place of amusement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(1)(c)(i)(B): within a place of public or private resort, a business or commercial establishment, or a private quarter.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(1)(c)(ii): "Escort" does not mean a person who provides business or personal services, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(1)(c)(ii)(A): a licensed private nurse;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(1)(c)(ii)(B): an aide for the elderly or a person with a disability;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(1)(c)(ii)(C): a social secretary or similar service personnel whose relationship with a patron is characterized by a contractual relationship having a duration of 12 hours or more and who provides a service not principally characterized as dating or socializing; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(1)(c)(ii)(D): a person who provides services such as singing telegrams, birthday greetings, or similar activities that are characterized by an appearance in a public place, contracted for by a party other than the person for whom the service is being performed, and of a duration not to exceed one hour.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(1)(d): "Escort service" means any person who furnishes or arranges for an escort to accompany another individual for compensation.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(1)(e): "Nude or partially denuded individual" means an individual with any of the following less than completely and opaquely covered:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(1)(e)(i): genitals;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(1)(e)(ii): the pubic region; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(1)(e)(iii): a female breast below a point immediately above the top of the areola.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(1)(f): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(1)(f)(i): "Sexually oriented business" means a business at which any nude or partially denuded individual, regardless of whether the nude or partially denuded individual is an employee of the sexually oriented business or an independent contractor, performs any service for compensation.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(1)(f)(ii): "Sexually oriented business" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(1)(f)(ii)(A): an escort service; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(1)(f)(ii)(B): an adult service.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(2): A person employed in a sexually oriented business may not work in a municipality if:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(2)(a): the municipality requires that a person employed in a sexually oriented business obtain an individual license; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(2)(b): the person has not obtained an individual license from the municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(3): A business entity that conducts a sexually oriented business may not conduct business in a municipality if:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(3)(a): the municipality requires that a sexually oriented business obtain a license; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(3)(b): the business entity has not obtained a license from the municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(4): 76-10-1302
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(4)(a): A violation of this section by an individual who is at least 18 years old is a class A misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.5(4)(b): 76-10-1302 A person charged under this section may not also be charged under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6 Regulation of retail tobacco specialty business.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(1): 26B-1-201; 76-10-101; 26A-1-102; 76-10-101; 76-10-105.1; 76-10-101; 76-10-101 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(1)(a): "Community location" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(1)(a)(i): a public or private kindergarten, elementary, middle, junior high, or high school;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(1)(a)(ii): a licensed child-care facility or preschool;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(1)(a)(iii): a trade or technical school;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(1)(a)(iv): a church;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(1)(a)(v): a public library;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(1)(a)(vi): a public playground;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(1)(a)(vii): a public park;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(1)(a)(viii): a youth center or other space used primarily for youth oriented activities;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(1)(a)(ix): a public recreational facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(1)(a)(x): a public arcade; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(1)(a)(xi): for a new license issued on or after July 1, 2018, a homeless shelter.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(1)(b): 26B-1-201 "Department" means the Department of Health and Human Services created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(1)(c): 76-10-101 "Electronic cigarette product" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(1)(d): "Licensee" means a person licensed under this section to conduct business as a retail tobacco specialty business.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(1)(e): 26A-1-102 "Local health department" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(1)(f): 76-10-101 "Nicotine product" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(1)(g): "Retail tobacco specialty business" means a commercial establishment in which:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(1)(g)(i): sales of tobacco products, electronic cigarette products, and nicotine products account for more than 35% of the total quarterly gross receipts for the establishment;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(1)(g)(ii): 20% or more of the public retail floor space is allocated to the offer, display, or storage of tobacco products, electronic cigarette products, or nicotine products;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(1)(g)(iii): 20% or more of the total shelf space is allocated to the offer, display, or storage of tobacco products, electronic cigarette products, or nicotine products;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(1)(g)(iv): the commercial establishment:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(1)(g)(iv)(A): holds itself out as a retail tobacco specialty business; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(1)(g)(iv)(B): causes a reasonable person to believe the commercial establishment is a retail tobacco specialty business; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(1)(g)(v): the retail space features a self-service display for tobacco products, electronic cigarette products, or nicotine products.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(1)(h): 76-10-105.1 "Self-service display" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(1)(i): 76-10-101; 76-10-101 "Tobacco product" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(1)(i)(i): 76-10-101 a tobacco product as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(1)(i)(ii): 76-10-101 tobacco paraphernalia as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(2): The regulation of a retail tobacco specialty business is an exercise of the police powers of the state by the state or by delegation of the state's police powers to other governmental entities.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(3)(a): A person may not operate a retail tobacco specialty business in a municipality unless the person obtains a license from the municipality in which the retail tobacco specialty business is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(3)(b): A municipality may only issue a retail tobacco specialty business license to a person if the person complies with the provisions of Subsections (4) and (5).
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(4)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (7), a municipality may not issue a license for a person to conduct business as a retail tobacco specialty business if the retail tobacco specialty business is located within:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(4)(a)(i): 1,000 feet of a community location;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(4)(a)(ii): 600 feet of another retail tobacco specialty business; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(4)(a)(iii): 600 feet from property used or zoned for:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(4)(a)(iii)(A): agriculture use; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(4)(a)(iii)(B): residential use.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(4)(b): For purposes of Subsection (4)(a), the proximity requirements shall be measured in a straight line from the nearest entrance of the retail tobacco specialty business to the nearest property boundary of a location described in Subsections (4)(a)(i) through (iii), without regard to intervening structures or zoning districts.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(5): 59-14-201; 59-14-301; 59-14-803 A municipality may not issue or renew a license for a person to conduct business as a retail tobacco specialty business until the person provides the municipality with proof that the retail tobacco specialty business has:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(5)(a): a valid permit for a retail tobacco specialty business issued under Title 26B, Chapter 7, Part 5, Regulation of Smoking, Tobacco Products, and Nicotine Products, by the local health department having jurisdiction over the area in which the retail tobacco specialty business is located; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(5)(b): 59-14-201; 59-14-301; 59-14-803
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(5)(b)(i): 59-14-201; 59-14-301 for a retailer that sells a tobacco product, a valid license issued by the State Tax Commission in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(5)(b)(ii): 59-14-803 for a retailer that sells an electronic cigarette product or a nicotine product, a valid license issued by the State Tax Commission in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(6)(a): Nothing in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(6)(a)(i): requires a municipality to issue a retail tobacco specialty business license; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(6)(a)(ii): prohibits a municipality from adopting more restrictive requirements on a person seeking a license or renewal of a license to conduct business as a retail tobacco specialty business.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(6)(b): A municipality may suspend or revoke a retail tobacco specialty business license issued under this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(6)(b)(i): if a licensee engages in a pattern of unlawful activity under Title 76, Chapter 10, Part 16, Pattern of Unlawful Activity Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(6)(b)(ii): if a licensee violates federal law or federal regulations restricting the sale and distribution of tobacco products or electronic cigarette products to protect children and adolescents;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(6)(b)(iii): upon the recommendation of the department or a local health department under Title 26B, Chapter 7, Part 5, Regulation of Smoking, Tobacco Products, and Nicotine Products; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(6)(b)(iv): under any other provision of state law or local ordinance.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(7): 26B-7-503; 26B-7-503
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(7)(a): A retail tobacco specialty business is exempt from Subsection (4) if:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(7)(a)(i): on or before December 31, 2018, the retail tobacco specialty business was issued a license to conduct business as a retail tobacco specialty business;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(7)(a)(ii): the retail tobacco specialty business is operating in a municipality in accordance with all applicable laws except for the requirement in Subsection (4); and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(7)(a)(iii): beginning July 1, 2022, the retail tobacco specialty business is not located within 1,000 feet of a public or private kindergarten, elementary, middle, junior high, or high school.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(7)(b): 26B-7-503 A retail tobacco specialty business may maintain an exemption under Subsection (7)(a) if:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(7)(b)(i): the license described in Subsection (7)(a)(i) is renewed continuously without lapse or permanent revocation;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(7)(b)(ii): the retail tobacco specialty business does not close for business or otherwise suspend the sale of tobacco products, electronic cigarette products, or nicotine products for more than 60 consecutive days;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(7)(b)(iii): the retail tobacco specialty business does not substantially change the business premises or business operation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(7)(b)(iv): 26B-7-503 the retail tobacco specialty business maintains the right to operate under the terms of other applicable laws, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(7)(b)(iv)(A): 26B-7-503 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(7)(b)(iv)(B): zoning ordinances;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(7)(b)(iv)(C): building codes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(7)(b)(iv)(D): the requirements of the license described in Subsection (7)(a)(i).
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(7)(c): A retail tobacco specialty business that does not qualify for an exemption under Subsection (7)(a) is exempt from Subsection (4) if:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(7)(c)(i): on or before December 31, 2018, the retail tobacco specialty business was issued a general tobacco retailer permit or a retail tobacco specialty business permit under Title 26B, Chapter 7, Part 5, Regulation of Smoking, Tobacco Products, and Nicotine Products, by the local health department having jurisdiction over the area in which the retail tobacco specialty business is located;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(7)(c)(ii): the retail tobacco specialty business is operating in the municipality in accordance with all applicable laws except for the requirement in Subsection (4); and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(7)(c)(iii): beginning July 1, 2022, the retail tobacco specialty business is not located within 1,000 feet of a public or private kindergarten, elementary, middle, junior high, or high school.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(7)(d): 26B-7-503 Except as provided in Subsection (7)(e), a retail tobacco specialty business may maintain an exemption under Subsection (7)(c) if:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(7)(d)(i): on or before December 31, 2020, the retail tobacco specialty business receives a retail tobacco specialty business permit from the local health department having jurisdiction over the area in which the retail tobacco specialty business is located;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(7)(d)(ii): the permit described in Subsection (7)(d)(i) is renewed continuously without lapse or permanent revocation;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(7)(d)(iii): the retail tobacco specialty business does not close for business or otherwise suspend the sale of tobacco products, electronic cigarette products, or nicotine products for more than 60 consecutive days;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(7)(d)(iv): the retail tobacco specialty business does not substantially change the business premises or business operation as the business existed when the retail tobacco specialty business received a permit under Subsection (7)(d)(i); and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(7)(d)(v): 26B-7-503 the retail tobacco specialty business maintains the right to operate under the terms of other applicable laws, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(7)(d)(v)(A): 26B-7-503 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(7)(d)(v)(B): zoning ordinances;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(7)(d)(v)(C): building codes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(7)(d)(v)(D): the requirements of the retail tobacco permit described in Subsection (7)(d)(i).
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(7)(e): A retail tobacco specialty business described in Subsection (7)(a) or (b) that is located within 1,000 feet of a public or private kindergarten, elementary, middle, junior high, or high school before July 1, 2022, is exempt from Subsection (4)(a)(iii)(B) if the retail tobacco specialty business:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(7)(e)(i): relocates, before July 1, 2022, to a property that is used or zoned for commercial use and located within a group of architecturally unified commercial establishments built on a site that is planned, developed, owned, and managed as an operating unit; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-41.6(7)(e)(ii): continues to meet the requirements described in Subsection (7)(b) that are not directly related to the relocation described in this Subsection (7)(e).


Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-42 Intoxicating liquors -- Prohibitions on manufacture, sale, possession, etc.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
They may prohibit, except as provided by law, any person from knowingly having in the person's possession any intoxicating liquor, and the manufacture, sale, keeping or storing for sale, offering or exposing for sale, importing, carrying, transporting, advertising, distributing, giving away, exchanging, dispensing or serving of intoxicating liquors.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-43 Establishment and regulation of markets -- Sale of meats, poultry, etc.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
They may establish markets and market houses, and provide for the regulation and use thereof, and provide for the place and the manner of sale of meats, poultry, fish, butter, cheese, lard, vegetables and all other provisions, and regulate the selling of the same.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-44 Food stuffs -- Regulation and inspection.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
They may provide for and regulate the inspection of meats, fruit, poultry, fish, butter, cheese, lard, vegetables, flour, meal and all other provisions, and provide for the inspection, measurement or graduation of any merchandise, manufacture or commodity, and appoint the necessary officers therefor.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-44.5 Prohibition against regulation of nutritional information dissemination.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-44.5(1): A municipality may not regulate the dissemination of nutritional information or the content required to be placed on a menu, menu board, or food tag by a restaurant, eating establishment, or other food facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-44.5(2): (1) An ordinance or regulation that violates Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-44.6 Regulation of drive-through facilities.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-44.6(1): 10-9a-103 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-44.6(1)(a): "Business" means a private enterprise carried on for the purpose of gain or economic profit.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-44.6(1)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-44.6(1)(b)(i): "Business lobby" means a public area, including a lobby, dining area, or other area accessible to the public where business is conducted within a place of business.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-44.6(1)(b)(ii): "Business lobby" does not include the area of a business where drive-through service is conducted.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-44.6(1)(c): 10-9a-103 "Land use application" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-44.6(1)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-44.6(1)(d)(i): "Motor vehicle" means a self-propelled vehicle, including a motorcycle, intended primarily for use and operation on the highways.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-44.6(1)(d)(ii): "Motor vehicle" does not include an off-highway vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-44.6(1)(e): "Motorcycle" means a motor vehicle having a saddle for the use of the operator and designed to travel on not more than two tires.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-44.6(1)(f): "Off-highway vehicle" means any snowmobile, all-terrain type I vehicle, all-terrain type II vehicle, or all-terrain type III vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-44.6(2): A municipality may not withhold a business license, deny a land use application, or otherwise require a business that has a drive-through service as a component of its business operations to:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-44.6(2)(a): allow a person other than a person in a motorized vehicle to use the drive-through service; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-44.6(2)(b): offer designated hours of the day that a customer is accommodated and business is conducted in the business lobby that are the same as or exceed the hours of the day that a customer is accommodated and business is conducted in the drive-through service.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-45 Weights and measures -- Inspection and sealing.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
They may provide for the inspection, sealing and use of proper weights, measures, computing scales, and all weighing and measuring devices indicating the numerical value as well as weight or quantity.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-46 Plumbing -- Regulation of construction and repair -- Board of examiners.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
They may regulate the construction, repair and use of vaults, cisterns, areas, hydrants, pumps, sewers, gutters and plumbing, and provide for a board of examiners to examine into the fitness and qualifications of persons following the plumbing trade, and may prescribe what qualifications are necessary for persons following said trade.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-47 Intoxication -- Fights -- Disorderly conduct -- Assault and battery -- Petit larceny -- Riots and disorderly assemblies -- Firearms and fireworks -- False pretenses and embezzlement -- Sale of liquor, narcotics, tobacco products, electronic cigarette products, or nicotine products to minors -- Possession of controlled substances -- Treatment of alcoholics and narcotics or drug addicts.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-47(1): 53-7-225; 76-10-101 A municipal legislative body may:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-47(1)(a): prevent intoxication, fighting, quarreling, dog fights, cockfights, prize fights, bullfights, and all disorderly conduct and provide against and punish the offenses of assault and battery and petit larceny;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-47(1)(b): restrain riots, routs, noises, disturbances, or disorderly assemblies in any street, house, or place in the city;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-47(1)(c): 53-7-225 regulate and prevent the discharge of firearms, rockets, powder, fireworks in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-47(1)(d): provide against and prevent the offense of obtaining money or property under false pretenses and the offense of embezzling money or property in the cases when the money or property embezzled or obtained under false pretenses does not exceed in value the sum of $500;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-47(1)(e): prohibit the sale, giving away, or furnishing of narcotics or alcoholic beverages to an individual younger than 21 years old; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-47(1)(f): 76-10-101 prohibit the sale, giving away, or furnishing of a tobacco product, an electronic cigarette product, or a nicotine product as those terms are defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-47(2): A city may:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-47(2)(a): by ordinance, prohibit the possession of controlled substances as defined in the Utah Controlled Substances Act or any other endangering or impairing substance, provided the conduct is not a class A misdemeanor or felony; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-47(2)(b): provide for treatment of alcoholics, narcotic addicts, and other individuals who are addicted to the use of drugs or intoxicants such that an individual substantially lacks the capacity to control the individual's use of the drugs or intoxicants, and judicial supervision may be imposed as a means of effecting the individual's rehabilitation.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-47.5 Knives regulated by state.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-47.5(1): As used in this section, "knife" means a cutting instrument that includes a sharpened or pointed blade.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-47.5(2): The authority to regulate a knife is reserved to the state except where the Legislature specifically delegates responsibility to a municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-47.5(3): (3)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-47.5(3)(a): (3)(b) Unless specifically authorized by the Legislature or, subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-47.5(3)(b): A municipality may not enact an ordinance with a criminal penalty pertaining to a knife that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-47.5(3)(b)(i): more restrictive than a state criminal penalty pertaining to a knife; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-47.5(3)(b)(ii): has a greater criminal penalty than a state penalty pertaining to a knife.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-49 Vagrants -- Arrest -- Fine -- Putting to work -- Municipal lodging.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
They may arrest and fine or set to work on the streets or elsewhere all vagrants, mendicants and persons found in the city without visible means of support or some legitimate business, and may establish and maintain municipal lodging and eating houses.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-50 Disturbing the peace -- Public intoxication -- Fighting -- Obscene language -- Disorderly conduct -- Lewd behavior -- Interference with officers -- Trespass.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-50(1): Boards of commissioners and city councils of cities may provide for the punishment of any person or persons for:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-50(1)(a): disturbing the peace or good order of the city;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-50(1)(b): disturbing the peace of any person or persons;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-50(1)(c): disturbing any lawful assembly;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-50(1)(d): public intoxication;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-50(1)(e): challenging, encouraging, or engaging in fighting;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-50(1)(f): using obscene or profane language in a place or under circumstances which could cause a breach of the peace or good order of the city;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-50(1)(g): engaging in indecent or disorderly conduct;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-50(1)(h): engaging in lewd or lascivious behavior or conduct in the city; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-50(1)(i): interfering with any city officer in the discharge of his duty.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-50(2): Boards of commissioners and city councils of cities may provide for the punishment of trespass and such other petty offenses as the board of commissioners or city council may  consider proper.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-50(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-50(3)(a): A woman's breast feeding, including breast feeding in any  location where she otherwise may rightfully be, does not under any circumstance constitute a lewd or indecent  act, irrespective of whether or not the breast is covered during or incidental to feeding.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-50(3)(b): Boards of commissioners and city councils of cities may not prohibit a woman's breast feeding in any location where she otherwise may rightfully  be, irrespective of whether the breast is uncovered during or incidental to the breast feeding.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-51 Beggars, prostitutes, swindlers -- Punishment.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
They may provide for the punishment of tramps, street beggars, prostitutes, habitual disturbers of the peace, pickpockets, gamblers and thieves, or persons who practice any game, trick or device with intent to swindle.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-52 Buildings -- Fire limits -- Removal and destruction of buildings violating ordinance.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
They may define fire limits and prescribe limits within which no building shall be constructed except of brick, stone or other incombustible material, without permission, and may cause the destruction or removal of any building constructed or repaired in violation of any ordinance, and cause all buildings and enclosures which may be in a dangerous state to be put in a safe condition or removed.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-53 Fire escapes -- Construction -- Building exits -- Fire extinguishers.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
They may prescribe the manner of constructing stone, brick and other buildings, and the construction and maintenance of fire escapes; may cause all buildings used for public purposes to be provided with sufficient and ample means of exit and entrance, and to be supplied with necessary and appropriate appliances for the extinguishment of fire; may prevent the overcrowding thereof, and regulate the placing and use of seats, scenery, curtains, blinds, screens, or other appliances therein.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-53.5 Regulation of carbon monoxide detectors -- Enforcement against occupant only.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-53.5(1): (2) Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-53.5(2): (1) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-53.5(2)(a): a building permit applicant's obligation to comply with a building code that requires the installation of a carbon monoxide detector as part of new construction; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-53.5(2)(b): a municipality's ability to require a building permit applicant to comply with a building code that requires the installation of a carbon monoxide detector as part of new construction.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-54 Regulation of construction and condition of chimneys and heating equipment -- Disposal of ashes.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
They may prevent the dangerous construction and condition of chimneys, fireplaces, stoves, stovepipes, heaters, ovens, furnaces, boilers, and apparatus used in and about buildings and manufactories, and cause the same to be removed or placed in a safe condition; and may regulate and prevent the carrying on of manufacturing likely to cause fires, and may prevent the deposit of ashes in unsafe places.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-55 Fire departments -- Fire-fighting equipment -- Rules and regulations.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
They may, except as otherwise provided by law, provide for the organization and support of a fire department, procure fire engines, hooks, ladders, buckets, hose and other apparatus, organize fire engine and hook and ladder companies, prescribe duties, rules and regulations for the government thereof, with such penalty as they may deem proper, and make all necessary appropriations therefor.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-55.5 Prohibition of flat response fee.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-55.5(1): A municipality, or a person who contracts with a municipality to provide emergency services:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-55.5(1)(a): may not impose a flat fee, or collect a flat fee, from an individual involved in a traffic incident; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-55.5(1)(b): may only charge the individual for the actual cost of services provided in responding to the traffic incident, limited to:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-55.5(1)(b)(i): medical costs for:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-55.5(1)(b)(i)(A): transporting an individual from the scene of a traffic accident; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-55.5(1)(b)(i)(B): treatment of a person injured in a traffic accident;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-55.5(1)(b)(ii): repair to damaged public property, if the individual is legally liable for the damage;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-55.5(1)(b)(iii): the cost of materials used in cleaning up the traffic accident, if the individual is legally liable for the traffic accident; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-55.5(1)(b)(iv): towing costs.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-55.5(2): If a municipality, or a person who contracts with a municipality to provide emergency services, imposes a charge on more than one individual for the actual cost of responding to a traffic incident, the municipality or person contracting with the municipality shall apportion the charges so that it does not receive more for responding to the traffic incident than the actual response cost.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-56 Storage of combustibles and explosives -- Use of lights -- Bonfires.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
They may regulate or prevent the storage of gunpowder, tar, pitch, resin, coal, oil, gas, gasoline, benzine, turpentine, nitroglycerine, petroleum or any of the products thereof, and other combustible or explosive substances or materials, and the use of lights in stables, shops and other places, and the building of bonfires.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-57 Inspection of boilers -- Licensing of stationary engineers.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
They may provide for the inspection and may regulate the use of steam boilers, provide for the examination, regulation and licensing of stationary engineers and others having charge or control of stationary engines, motors, boilers or steam or power generating apparatus, or elevators, within the corporate limits of the city.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-58 Jails and workhouses -- Establishment and maintenance.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The governing body of a city or town may:Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-58(1): establish, erect, and maintain city jails, houses of correction, and workhouses for the temporary confinement, not to exceed 72 hours, of persons convicted of violating any city ordinances;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-58(2): make rules for the government of them;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-58(3): appoint necessary jailers and keepers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-58(4): use the county correctional facilities, including the county jail, for the confinement or punishment of offenders on the following conditions:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-58(4)(a): a city or town may use the county correctional facilities without payment of compensation or reimbursement for incarceration costs or costs associated with booking of offenders in county correctional facilities;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-58(4)(b): subject to any conditions that are imposed by law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-58(4)(c): with the consent of the county legislative body which may include, without limitation, the allocation or rationing of correctional facility capacity and prohibition of booking for classes of offenses or offenders.  These limitations shall be applied equally to all entities using the county correctional facilities.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-58(5): If consent is given for the use of the county correctional facilities, the sheriff, at the sheriff's discretion, may assign offenders to county correctional facilities or programs or transfer offenders between facilities or programs.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-58(6): Nothing contained in this section shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-58(6)(a): preclude cities, towns, and counties from executing written agreements containing terms or conditions for the use of the county jail; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-58(6)(b): invalidate any agreements entered into prior to July 1, 2004.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-58.5(4)(c): may be left or stored at a jail at the discretion of the sheriff.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-59 Cruelty to animals.
-------------------------------------------------
They may prohibit cruelty to animals.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-60 Nuisances.
----------------------------------------
They may declare what shall be a nuisance, and abate the same, and impose fines upon persons who may create, continue or suffer nuisances to exist.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-66 Offensive businesses -- Regulation of management and construction.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
They may direct the location and regulate the management and construction of packing houses, dairies, tanneries, canneries, renderies, bone factories, slaughterhouses, butcher shops, soap factories, foundries, breweries, distilleries, livery stables and blacksmith shops in and within one mile of the limits of the corporation.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-67 Pigsties, privies, other offensive establishments -- Prohibiting establishment.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
They may prohibit any offensive, unwholesome business or establishment in and within one mile of the limits of the corporation, compel the owner of any pigsty, privy, barn, corral, sewer or other unwholesome or nauseous house or place to cleanse, abate or remove the same, and may regulate the location thereof.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-68 Census.
-------------------------------------
They may provide for the taking of censuses, but no census shall be taken oftener than once in five years, except as otherwise provided by law.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-69(1)(b): playing ball;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-69(1)(c): flying a kite;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-69(1)(d): riding a bicycle or tricycle; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-69(1)(e): any other conduct or activity that interferes with traffic.
