Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-70 Lumberyards and combustible materials.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
They may regulate or prohibit the keeping of any lumberyard, and the placing or piling or selling of any lumber, timber, wood or other combustible material within the fire limits of the city.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-71 Waterworks -- Police and fire signals -- Retainage.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-71(1): They may purchase, construct, lease, rent, manage and maintain any system or part of any system of waterworks, hydrants and supplies of water, telegraphic or other police or fire signals, and pass all ordinances, penal or otherwise, that shall be necessary for the full protection, maintenance, management and control of the property so leased, purchased or constructed.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-71(2): 13-8-5 If any payment on a contract with a private person, firm, or corporation to construct all or part of any waterworks system is retained or withheld, it shall be retained or withheld and released as provided in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-72 Libraries and reading rooms -- Establishment and maintenance.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
They may establish, maintain and regulate free public libraries and reading rooms, as provided by law, and may perpetuate such free libraries and reading rooms as may have been heretofore established in the city.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-73 Processions and demonstrations.
-------------------------------------------------------------
They may regulate or prohibit all public demonstrations and processions which interfere with public traffic or tend to cause disorder.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-74 Burial of indigents.
--------------------------------------------------
They may provide for the burial of the indigent dead and pay the expenses thereof.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-75 Destitute children.
-------------------------------------------------
They may authorize the taking, and provide for the safekeeping and education for such periods of time as may be expedient, for all children who are destitute of proper parental care.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-76 Noise abatement -- Street performances.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
They may prevent the ringing of bells, blowing of horns and bugles, crying of goods by auctioneers and others, and the making of other noises, for the purpose of business, amusement or otherwise, and prevent all performances and devices tending to the collection of persons on the streets or sidewalks of the city.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-77 Untied animals in streets.
--------------------------------------------------------
They may compel persons to fasten animals attached to vehicles standing or remaining in the street.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-78 Official bonds and reports.
---------------------------------------------------------
They may require all municipal officers and agents, elected or appointed, to give bond and security for the faithful performance of their duties, and require from every officer of the city at any time a report in detail of all transactions in the officer of the city's office or any matters connected therewith.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-79 Creating offices -- Filling vacancies.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
They may create any office they may deem necessary for the good government of the city, and provide for filling vacancies in elective and appointive offices, and prescribe the powers, duties and compensation of all officers of the city, except as otherwise provided by law.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-81 Social clubs and athletic associations.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
They may regulate all social clubs, recreational associations, athletic associations and kindred associations, whether incorporated or not, which maintain club rooms or regular meeting rooms within the corporate limits of the city.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-82 Railroads -- Removal of unused tracks.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
They may require the tracks of any railroad or street railway company to be taken up and removed which shall have been laid upon the streets or highways of the city, and which remain in the streets or highways contrary to the terms of the franchise of the company, or which are declared by the governing body a nuisance, or which such company has failed to operate for a period of nine months prior to the time when such nuisance shall be declared, and shall have the power to declare any of the acts specified in this section a nuisance.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-83 Railroad gates -- Kind and quality -- Installation.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
They may require any railroad or street railway company to place gates at any place along its tracks, and may designate the places where such gates shall be placed, and the nature, kind and quality of such gates.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-84 Ordinances, rules, and regulations -- Passage -- Penalties.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-84(1): The municipal legislative body may pass all ordinances and rules, and make all regulations, not repugnant to law, necessary for carrying into effect or discharging all powers and duties conferred by this chapter, and as are necessary and proper to provide for the safety and preserve the health, and promote the prosperity, improve the morals, peace and good order, comfort, and convenience of the city and its inhabitants, and for the protection of property in the city.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-84(2): 10-3-703 The municipal legislative body may enforce obedience to the ordinances with fines or penalties in accordance with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-85 Prison labor and fines.
-----------------------------------------------------
They may provide by ordinance that any person committed to the county or municipal jail or other place of incarceration as a punishment or in default of the payment of a fine, or fine and costs, shall be required to work for the city at such labor as the person's strength will permit not exceeding eight hours in each working day; and that a judgment that the defendant pay a fine or a fine and costs may also direct that the defendant be imprisoned until the amount thereof is satisfied, specifying the extent of imprisonment which cannot exceed one day for each $2 of such amount.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-85.4 Ordinances regarding short-term rentals -- Prohibition on ordinances restricting speech on short-term rental websites.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-85.6 Definitions -- Electronic payments -- Fee.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-85.6(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-85.6(1)(a): "Electronic payment" means the payment of money to a municipality by electronic means, including by means of a credit card, charge card, debit card, prepaid or stored value card or similar device, or automatic clearinghouse transaction.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-85.6(1)(b): "Electronic payment fee" means an amount of money to defray the discount fee, processing fee, or other fee charged by a credit card company or processing agent to process an electronic payment.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-85.6(1)(c): "Processing agent" means a bank, transaction clearinghouse, or other third party that charges a fee to process an electronic payment.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-85.6(2): A municipality may accept an electronic payment for the payment of funds which the municipality could have received through another payment method.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-85.6(3): A municipality that accepts an electronic payment may charge an electronic payment fee.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-85.7 Implements of husbandry tracking debris onto municipal roads.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A municipality may not prohibit or punish the tracking of dirt, mud, or other debris onto a municipal road resulting from the operation of an implement of husbandry if the operation of the implement of husbandry is consistent with accepted agricultural practices.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-85.8 Indemnification of farmers markets.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
A municipality may:Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-85.8(1): 4-5-102 operate a farmers market, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-85.8(2): indemnify a food producer participating in the farmers market; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-85.8(3): define the scope of the indemnification in an agreement with the food producer.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-85.9 Preservation of historical areas and sites.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
A municipality may:Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-85.9(1): expend public funds to preserve, protect, or enhance an historical area or site;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-85.9(2): acquire an historical area or site by direct purchase, contract, lease, trade, or gift;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-85.9(3): obtain an easement or right-of-way across public or private property to ensure access or proper development of an historical area or site;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-85.9(4): protect an historical area or site;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-85.9(5): ensure proper development and utilization of land or an area adjacent to an historical area or site; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-85.9(6): enter into an agreement with a private individual for the right to purchase an historical area or site if and when the private individual elects to sell or dispose of the owner's property.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-85.10 Ordinances regarding co-ownership -- Prohibition on municipal ordinances restricting co-ownership models.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-85.10(1)(a): "Co-owned home" means any residential unit that is jointly owned, in any manner or form, by any combination of individuals or entities.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-86 Organization, operation, maintenance, and funding of system for public transit authorized.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-86(1): 59-12-2213 The governing body of any municipality may adopt a resolution allowing the municipality to organize, operate, and maintain a system for public transit within the municipality and to impose a sales and a use tax to fund the system for public transit as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-86(2): The authority granted municipalities by this section to organize, operate, and maintain a system for public transit is inapplicable to a municipality located in or within five highway or roadway miles of the boundary of an existing transit district, unless the existing transit district consents to the organization and operation of the system for public transit by the municipality.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-89 Damage to abutting property -- Liability of city.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Whenever by the grading of any street, alley or other public ground in a city, pursuant to the action of the city authorities in changing the established grade of such street, alley or public ground, after valuable improvements have been made upon real property abutting thereon such real property is injured or diminished in value, the owner of such real property or improvements may recover from such city the amount of such damages or diminution in value in a civil action brought for that purpose.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-90 Ownership and operation of hospitals.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-90(1): Each city of the third, fourth, or fifth class and each town of the state is authorized to construct, own, and operate hospitals and to join with other cities, towns, and counties in the construction, ownership, and operation of hospitals.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-90(2): (1); Title 26B, Chapter 2, Part 2, Health Care Facility Licensing and Inspection; 26B-3-130; Title 11, Chapter 13, Interlocal Cooperation Act; (2)(a); (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-90(2)(a): (1); Title 26B, Chapter 2, Part 2, Health Care Facility Licensing and Inspection; 26B-3-130; Title 11, Chapter 13, Interlocal Cooperation Act Beginning July 1, 2017, a hospital under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-90(2)(b): (2)(a); (1) Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-92 Joint board -- Membership -- Powers.
------------------------------------------------------------------
When two or more political subdivisions of the state of Utah join together under this act for the purposes set forth herein, there shall be set up by the political subdivisions so joining, a joint board whose membership shall have equal representation from each of the political subdivisions joining, and which said board shall be empowered with the administration, operation, construction and maintenance of said joint hospital.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-93 Control of funds and disbursements -- Auditing of accounts by county auditor -- Transfer of county tax funds to board to cover deficiencies.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The joint board created pursuant to this act shall have the custody and control of all funds collected in the joint operation of such hospital and the disbursement thereof; provided that the county auditor of any county participating under the provisions of this act shall audit the accounts of said board quarterly or at more frequent intervals, if public interest, in the judgment of such auditor requires a more frequent audit. The county executive of any county participating in the operation and maintenance of hospitals pursuant to this act may pay over to the joint board of such hospitals any funds yielded by a levy made pursuant to Section

Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-94 Towns with same authority as cities.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Towns have the same powers and authority granted to cities under this chapter, in addition to other powers conferred by law, but subject to the following:Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-94(1): The town council may enact ordinances providing for the public safety, health, morals, and welfare of the town which are not prohibited, preempted by, or inconsistent with, the policy of state or federal law or the constitution of Utah or the United States, or attempt to regulate an area which by the nature of the subject requires uniform state regulation.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-94(2): The town council:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-94(2)(a): may lay out, construct, open, and keep in repair canals, water ditches, or water pipes to conduct water for artificial light and power purposes, and construct, own, and operate artificial light and power plants;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-94(2)(b): may construct, own, and operate water pipes for irrigation, domestic, or other use for the inhabitants of the town; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-8-94(2)(c): may annually assess and collect a special tax of not to exceed .0008 per dollar of taxable value of taxable property in the town for those purposes.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 10 - Chapter 9a - Municipal Land Use, Development, and Management Act
*************************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Municipal Land Use, Development, and Management Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102 Purposes -- General land use authority.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(1): The purposes of this chapter are to:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(1)(a): provide for the health, safety, and welfare;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(1)(b): promote the prosperity;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(1)(c): improve the morals, peace, good order, comfort, convenience, and aesthetics of each municipality and each municipality's present and future inhabitants and businesses;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(1)(d): protect the tax base;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(1)(e): secure economy in governmental expenditures;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(1)(f): foster the state's agricultural and other industries;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(1)(g): protect both urban and nonurban development;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(1)(h): protect and ensure access to sunlight for solar energy devices;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(1)(i): provide fundamental fairness in land use regulation;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(1)(j): facilitate orderly growth and allow growth in a variety of housing types; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(1)(k): protect property values.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(2): To accomplish the purposes of this chapter, a municipality may enact all ordinances, resolutions, and rules and may enter into other forms of land use controls and development agreements that the municipality considers necessary or appropriate for the use and development of land within the municipality, including ordinances, resolutions, rules, restrictive covenants, easements, and development agreements governing:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(2)(a): uses;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(2)(b): density;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(2)(c): open spaces;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(2)(d): structures;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(2)(e): buildings;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(2)(f): energy efficiency;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(2)(g): light and air;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(2)(h): air quality;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(2)(i): transportation and public or alternative transportation;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(2)(j): infrastructure;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(2)(k): street and building orientation;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(2)(l): width requirements;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(2)(m): public facilities;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(2)(n): fundamental fairness in land use regulation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(2)(o): considerations of surrounding land uses to balance the foregoing purposes with a landowner's private property interests and associated statutory and constitutional protections.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(3): 40-6-2.5; 40-6-2.5
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(3)(a): 40-6-2.5 Any ordinance, resolution, or rule enacted by a municipality pursuant to its authority under this chapter shall comply with the state's exclusive jurisdiction to regulate oil and gas activity, as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(3)(b): 40-6-2.5 A municipality may enact an ordinance, resolution, or rule that regulates surface activity incident to an oil and gas activity if the municipality demonstrates that the regulation:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(3)(b)(i): is necessary for the purposes of this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(3)(b)(ii): does not effectively or unduly limit, ban, or prohibit an oil and gas activity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-102(3)(b)(iii): 40-6-2.5 does not interfere with the state's exclusive jurisdiction to regulate oil and gas activity, as described in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(1): "Accessory dwelling unit" means a habitable living unit added to, created within, or detached from a primary single-family dwelling and contained on one lot.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(2): "Adversely affected party" means a person other than a land use applicant who:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(2)(a): owns real property adjoining the property that is the subject of a land use application or land use decision; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(2)(b): will suffer a damage different in kind than, or an injury distinct from, that of the general community as a result of the land use decision.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(3): "Affected entity" means a county, municipality, special district, special service district under Title 17D, Chapter 1, Special Service District Act, school district, interlocal cooperation entity established under Title 11, Chapter 13, Interlocal Cooperation Act, specified public utility, property owner, property owners association, or the Department of Transportation, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(3)(a): the entity's services or facilities are likely to require expansion or significant modification because of an intended use of land;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(3)(b): the entity has filed with the municipality a copy of the entity's general or long-range plan; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(3)(c): the entity has filed with the municipality a request for notice during the same calendar year and before the municipality provides notice to an affected entity in compliance with a requirement imposed under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(4): 20A-7-601; 20A-7-602.8 "Affected owner" means the owner of real property that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(4)(a): a single project;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(4)(b): 20A-7-601 the subject of a land use approval that sponsors of a referendum timely challenged in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(4)(c): 20A-7-602.8 determined to be legally referable under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(5): "Appeal authority" means the person, board, commission, agency, or other body designated by ordinance to decide an appeal of a decision of a land use application or a variance.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(6): "Billboard" means a freestanding ground sign located on industrial, commercial, or residential property if the sign is designed or intended to direct attention to a business, product, or service that is not sold, offered, or existing on the property where the sign is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(7)(a): "Charter school" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(7)(a)(i): an operating charter school;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(7)(a)(ii): a charter school applicant that a charter school authorizer approves in accordance with Title 53G, Chapter 5, Part 3, Charter School Authorization; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(7)(a)(iii): an entity that is working on behalf of a charter school or approved charter applicant to develop or construct a charter school building.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(7)(b): "Charter school" does not include a therapeutic school.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(8): "Conditional use" means a land use that, because of the unique characteristics or potential impact of the land use on the municipality, surrounding neighbors, or adjacent land uses, may not be compatible in some areas or may be compatible only if certain conditions are required that mitigate or eliminate the detrimental impacts.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(9): "Constitutional taking" means a governmental action that results in a taking of private property so that compensation to the owner of the property is required by the:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(9)(a): Fifth or Fourteenth Amendment of the Constitution of the United States; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(9)(b): Utah Constitution Article I, Section 22.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(10): "Culinary water authority" means the department, agency, or public entity with responsibility to review and approve the feasibility of the culinary water system and sources for the subject property.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(11): "Development activity" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(11)(a): any construction or expansion of a building, structure, or use that creates additional demand and need for public facilities;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(11)(b): any change in use of a building or structure that creates additional demand and need for public facilities; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(11)(c): any change in the use of land that creates additional demand and need for public facilities.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(12): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(12)(a): "Development agreement" means a written agreement or amendment to a written agreement between a municipality and one or more parties that regulates or controls the use or development of a specific area of land.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(12)(b): "Development agreement" does not include an improvement completion assurance.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(13): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(13)(a): "Disability" means a physical or mental impairment that substantially limits one or more of a person's major life activities, including a person having a record of such an impairment or being regarded as having such an impairment.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(13)(b): "Disability" does not include current illegal use of, or addiction to, any federally controlled substance, as defined in Section 102 of the Controlled Substances Act, 21 U.S.C. 802.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(14): "Educational facility":
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(14)(a): means:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(14)(a)(i): a school district's building at which pupils assemble to receive instruction in a program for any combination of grades from preschool through grade 12, including kindergarten and a program for children with disabilities;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(14)(a)(ii): a structure or facility:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(14)(a)(ii)(A): located on the same property as a building described in Subsection (14)(a)(i); and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(14)(a)(ii)(B): used in support of the use of that building; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(14)(a)(iii): a building to provide office and related space to a school district's administrative personnel; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(14)(b): does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(14)(b)(i): land or a structure, including land or a structure for inventory storage, equipment storage, food processing or preparing, vehicle storage or maintenance, or similar use that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(14)(b)(i)(A): not located on the same property as a building described in Subsection (14)(a)(i); and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(14)(b)(i)(B): used in support of the purposes of a building described in Subsection (14)(a)(i); or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(14)(b)(ii): a therapeutic school.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(15): "Fire authority" means the department, agency, or public entity with responsibility to review and approve the feasibility of fire protection and suppression services for the subject property.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(16): "Flood plain" means land that:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(16)(a): is within the 100-year flood plain designated by the Federal Emergency Management Agency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(16)(b): has not been studied or designated by the Federal Emergency Management Agency but presents a likelihood of experiencing chronic flooding or a catastrophic flood event because the land has characteristics that are similar to those of a 100-year flood plain designated by the Federal Emergency Management Agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(17): "General plan" means a document that a municipality adopts that sets forth general guidelines for proposed future development of the land within the municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(18): "Geologic hazard" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(18)(a): a surface fault rupture;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(18)(b): shallow groundwater;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(18)(c): liquefaction;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(18)(d): a landslide;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(18)(e): a debris flow;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(18)(f): unstable soil;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(18)(g): a rock fall; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(18)(h): any other geologic condition that presents a risk:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(18)(h)(i): to life;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(18)(h)(ii): of substantial loss of real property; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(18)(h)(iii): of substantial damage to real property.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(19): "Historic preservation authority" means a person, board, commission, or other body designated by a legislative body to:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(19)(a): recommend land use regulations to preserve local historic districts or areas; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(19)(b): administer local historic preservation land use regulations within a local historic district or area.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(20): 53G-6-201 "Home-based microschool" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(21): "Hookup fee" means a fee for the installation and inspection of any pipe, line, meter, or appurtenance that connects to a municipal water, sewer, storm water, power, or other utility system.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(22): "Identical plans" means building plans submitted to a municipality that:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(22)(a): are clearly marked as "identical plans";
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(22)(b): are substantially identical to building plans that were previously submitted to and reviewed and approved by the municipality; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(22)(c): describe a building that:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(22)(c)(i): is located on land zoned the same as the land on which the building described in the previously approved plans is located;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(22)(c)(ii): is subject to the same geological and meteorological conditions and the same law as the building described in the previously approved plans;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(22)(c)(iii): has a floor plan identical to the building plan previously submitted to and reviewed and approved by the municipality; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(22)(c)(iv): does not require any additional engineering or analysis.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(23): "Impact fee" means a payment of money imposed under Title 11, Chapter 36a, Impact Fees Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(24): "Improvement completion assurance" means a surety bond, letter of credit, financial institution bond, cash, assignment of rights, lien, or other equivalent security required by a municipality to guaranty the proper completion of landscaping or an infrastructure improvement required as a condition precedent to:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(24)(a): recording a subdivision plat; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(24)(b): development of a commercial, industrial, mixed use, or multifamily project.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(25): "Improvement warranty" means an applicant's unconditional warranty that the applicant's installed and accepted landscaping or infrastructure improvement:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(25)(a): complies with the municipality's written standards for design, materials, and workmanship; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(25)(b): will not fail in any material respect, as a result of poor workmanship or materials, within the improvement warranty period.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(26): "Improvement warranty period" means a period:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(26)(a): no later than one year after a municipality's acceptance of required landscaping; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(26)(b): no later than one year after a municipality's acceptance of required infrastructure, unless the municipality:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(26)(b)(i): determines for good cause that a one-year period would be inadequate to protect the public health, safety, and welfare; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(26)(b)(ii): has substantial evidence, on record:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(26)(b)(ii)(A): of prior poor performance by the applicant; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(26)(b)(ii)(B): that the area upon which the infrastructure will be constructed contains suspect soil and the municipality has not otherwise required the applicant to mitigate the suspect soil.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(27): "Infrastructure improvement" means permanent infrastructure that is essential for the public health and safety or that:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(27)(a): is required for human occupation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(27)(b): an applicant must install:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(27)(b)(i): in accordance with published installation and inspection specifications for public improvements; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(27)(b)(ii): whether the improvement is public or private, as a condition of:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(27)(b)(ii)(A): recording a subdivision plat;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(27)(b)(ii)(B): obtaining a building permit; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(27)(b)(ii)(C): development of a commercial, industrial, mixed use, condominium, or multifamily project.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(28): "Internal lot restriction" means a platted note, platted demarcation, or platted designation that:

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(28)(b):

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(29): "Land use applicant" means a property owner, or the property owner's designee, who submits a land use application regarding the property owner's land.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(30): "Land use application":
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(30)(a): means an application that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(30)(a)(i): required by a municipality; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(30)(a)(ii): submitted by a land use applicant to obtain a land use decision; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(30)(b): does not mean an application to enact, amend, or repeal a land use regulation.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(31): "Land use authority" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(31)(a): a person, board, commission, agency, or body, including the local legislative body, designated by the local legislative body to act upon a land use application; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(31)(b): if the local legislative body has not designated a person, board, commission, agency, or body, the local legislative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(32): "Land use decision" means an administrative decision of a land use authority or appeal authority regarding:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(32)(a): a land use permit; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(32)(b): a land use application.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(33): "Land use permit" means a permit issued by a land use authority.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(34): "Land use regulation":
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(34)(a): means a legislative decision enacted by ordinance, law, code, map, resolution, specification, fee, or rule that governs the use or development of land;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(34)(b): includes the adoption or amendment of a zoning map or the text of the zoning code; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-103(34)(c): does not include:

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-104 Municipal standards.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-104(1): This chapter does not prohibit a municipality from adopting the municipality's own land use standards.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-104(2): (1) Notwithstanding Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-201 Required notice.
------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-201(1): At a minimum, each municipality shall provide actual notice or the notice required by this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-201(2): A municipality may by ordinance require greater notice than required under this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-202 Applicant notice -- Waiver of requirements.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-202(1): For each land use application, the municipality shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-202(1)(a): notify the applicant of the date, time, and place of each public hearing and public meeting to consider the application;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-202(1)(b): provide to each applicant a copy of each staff report regarding the applicant or the pending application at least three business days before the public hearing or public meeting; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-202(1)(c): notify the applicant of any final action on a pending application.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-202(2): (1)(a); (b) If a municipality fails to comply with the requirements of Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-203(1)(a): to each affected entity;

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-203(3): A municipality shall send the newly adopted general plan and comprehensive general plan amendments to the relevant association of governments within 45 days of the date of adoption.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-302 Planning commission powers and duties -- Training requirements.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-302(1): The planning commission shall review and make a recommendation to the legislative body for:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-302(1)(a): a general plan and amendments to the general plan;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-302(1)(b): land use regulations, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-302(1)(b)(i): ordinances regarding the subdivision of land within the municipality; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-302(1)(b)(ii): amendments to existing land use regulations;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-302(1)(c): an appropriate delegation of power to at least one designated land use authority to hear and act on a land use application;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-302(1)(d): an appropriate delegation of power to at least one appeal authority to hear and act on an appeal from a decision of the land use authority; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-302(1)(e): application processes that:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-302(1)(e)(i): may include a designation of routine land use matters that, upon application and proper notice, will receive informal streamlined review and action if the application is uncontested; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-302(1)(e)(ii): shall protect the right of each:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-302(1)(e)(ii)(A): land use applicant and adversely affected party to require formal consideration of any application by a land use authority;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-302(1)(e)(ii)(B): land use applicant or adversely affected party to appeal a land use authority's decision to a separate appeal authority; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-302(1)(e)(ii)(C): participant to be heard in each public hearing on a contested application.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-302(2): 10-9a-404 Before making a recommendation to a legislative body on an item described in Subsection (1)(a) or (b), the planning commission shall hold a public hearing in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-302(3): A legislative body may adopt, modify, or reject a planning commission's recommendation to the legislative body under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-302(4): A legislative body may consider a planning commission's failure to make a timely recommendation as a negative recommendation.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-302(5): Nothing in this section limits the right of a municipality to initiate or propose the actions described in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-302(6): 61-2-201

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-303 Entrance upon land.
---------------------------------------------------
The municipality may enter upon any land at reasonable times to make examinations and surveys pertinent to the:Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-303(1): preparation of its general plan; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-303(2): preparation or enforcement of its land use ordinances.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-304 State and federal property.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Unless otherwise provided by law, nothing contained in this chapter may be construed as giving a municipality jurisdiction over property owned by the state or the United States.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305 Other entities required to conform to municipality's land use ordinances -- Exceptions -- School districts, charter schools, home-based microschools, and micro-education entities -- Submission of development plan and schedule.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(1)(a): Each county, municipality, school district, charter school, special district, special service district, and political subdivision of the state shall conform to any applicable land use ordinance of any municipality when installing, constructing, operating, or otherwise using any area, land, or building situated within that municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(1)(b): In addition to any other remedies provided by law, when a municipality's land use ordinance is violated or about to be violated by another political subdivision, that municipality may institute an injunction, mandamus, abatement, or other appropriate action or proceeding to prevent, enjoin, abate, or remove the improper installation, improvement, or use.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(2)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (3), a school district or charter school is subject to a municipality's land use ordinances.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(2)(b)(i): Notwithstanding Subsection (3), a municipality may:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(2)(b)(i)(A): subject a charter school to standards within each zone pertaining to setback, height, bulk and massing regulations, off-site parking, curb cut, traffic circulation, and construction staging; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(2)(b)(i)(B): impose regulations upon the location of a project that are necessary to avoid unreasonable risks to health or safety, as provided in Subsection (3)(f).
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(2)(b)(ii): The standards to which a municipality may subject a charter school under Subsection (2)(b)(i) shall be objective standards only and may not be subjective.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(2)(b)(iii): Except as provided in Subsection (7)(d), the only basis upon which a municipality may deny or withhold approval of a charter school's land use application is the charter school's failure to comply with a standard imposed under Subsection (2)(b)(i).
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(2)(b)(iv): Nothing in Subsection (2)(b)(iii) may be construed to relieve a charter school of an obligation to comply with a requirement of an applicable building or safety code to which it is otherwise obligated to comply.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(3): A municipality may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(3)(a): impose requirements for landscaping, fencing, aesthetic considerations, construction methods or materials, additional building inspections, municipal building codes, building use for educational purposes, or the placement or use of temporary classroom facilities on school property;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(3)(b): except as otherwise provided in this section, require a school district or charter school to participate in the cost of any roadway or sidewalk, or a study on the impact of a school on a roadway or sidewalk, that is not reasonably necessary for the safety of school children and not located on or contiguous to school property, unless the roadway or sidewalk is required to connect an otherwise isolated school site to an existing roadway;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(3)(c): require a district or charter school to pay fees not authorized by this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(3)(d): provide for inspection of school construction or assess a fee or other charges for inspection, unless the school district or charter school is unable to provide for inspection by an inspector, other than the project architect or contractor, who is qualified under criteria established by the state superintendent;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(3)(e): require a school district or charter school to pay any impact fee for an improvement project unless the impact fee is imposed as provided in Title 11, Chapter 36a, Impact Fees Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(3)(f): impose regulations upon the location of an educational facility except as necessary to avoid unreasonable risks to health or safety; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(3)(g): for a land use or a structure owned or operated by a school district or charter school that is not an educational facility but is used in support of providing instruction to pupils, impose a regulation that:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(3)(g)(i): is not imposed on a similar land use or structure in the zone in which the land use or structure is approved; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(3)(g)(ii): uses the tax exempt status of the school district or charter school as criteria for prohibiting or regulating the land use or location of the structure.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(4): 53E-3-710 Subject to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(4)(a): avoid or mitigate existing and potential traffic hazards, including consideration of the impacts between the new school and future highways; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(4)(b): maximize school, student, and site safety.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(5): Notwithstanding Subsection (3)(d), a municipality may, at its discretion:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(5)(a): provide a walk-through of school construction at no cost and at a time convenient to the district or charter school; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(5)(b): provide recommendations based upon the walk-through.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(6)(a): Notwithstanding Subsection (3)(d), a school district or charter school shall use:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(6)(a)(i): a municipal building inspector;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(6)(a)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(6)(a)(ii)(A): for a school district, a school district building inspector from that school district; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(6)(a)(ii)(B): for a charter school, a school district building inspector from the school district in which the charter school is located; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(6)(a)(iii): an independent, certified building inspector who isnot an employee of the contractor, licensed to perform the inspection that the inspector is requested to perform, and approved bya municipal building inspector or:

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(6)(a)(iii)(B): for a charter school, a school district building inspector from the school district in which the charter school is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(6)(b): The approval under Subsection (6)(a)(iii) may not be unreasonably withheld.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(6)(c): If a school district or charter school uses a school district or independent building inspector under Subsection (6)(a)(ii) or (iii), the school district or charter school shall submit to the state superintendent of public instruction and municipal building official, on a monthly basis during construction of the school building, a copy of each inspection certificate regarding the school building.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(7): 53E-3-706; 53E-3-706; 53E-3-706; 15A-2-103; 15A-2-103; 15A-1-210
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(7)(a): A charter school, home-based microschool, or micro-education entity shall be considered a permitted use in all zoning districts within a municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(7)(b): Each land use application for any approval required for a charter school, home-based microschool, or micro-education entity, including an application for a building permit, shall be processed on a first priority basis.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(7)(c): Parking requirements for a charter school or a micro-education entity may not exceed the minimum parking requirements for schools or other institutional public uses throughout the municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(7)(d): If a municipality has designated zones for a sexually oriented business, or a business which sells alcohol, a charter school or a micro-education entity may be prohibited from a location which would otherwise defeat the purpose for the zone unless the charter school or micro-education entity provides a waiver.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(7)(f): 15A-2-103
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(7)(f)(i): 15A-2-103 A micro-education entity may operate in a facility that meets Group E Occupancy requirements as defined by the International Building Code, as incorporated by Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(7)(f)(ii)(A): may have up to 100 students in the facility; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-305(7)(f)(ii)(B): shall have enough space for at least 20 net square feet per student.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-306 Land use authority requirements -- Nature of land use decision.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-306(1): A land use authority shall apply the plain language of land use regulations.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-306(2): If a land use regulation does not plainly restrict a land use application, the land use authority shall interpret and apply the land use regulation to favor the land use application.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-306(3): A land use decision of a land use authority is an administrative act, even if the land use authority is the legislative body.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-401 General plan required -- Content.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-401(1): To accomplish the purposes of this chapter, a municipality shall prepare and adopt a comprehensive, long-range general plan for:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-401(1)(a): present and future needs of the municipality; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-401(1)(b): growth and development of all or any part of the land within the municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-401(2): The general plan may provide for:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-401(2)(a): health, general welfare, safety, energy conservation, transportation, prosperity, civic activities, aesthetics, and recreational, educational, and cultural opportunities;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-401(2)(b): the reduction of the waste of physical, financial, or human resources that result from either excessive congestion or excessive scattering of population;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-401(2)(c): the efficient and economical use, conservation, and production of the supply of:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-401(2)(c)(i): food and water; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-401(2)(c)(ii): drainage, sanitary, and other facilities and resources;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-401(2)(d): the use of energy conservation and solar and clean energy resources;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-401(2)(e): the protection of urban development;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-401(2)(f): if the municipality is a town, the protection or promotion of moderate income housing;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-401(2)(g): the protection and promotion of air quality;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-401(2)(h): historic preservation;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-401(2)(i): identifying future uses of land that are likely to require an expansion or significant modification of services or facilities provided by an affected entity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-401(2)(j): an official map.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-401(3): 10-9a-408; 10-9a-403; 10-9a-408
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-401(3)(a): 10-9a-408; 10-9a-403 The general plan of a specified municipality, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-401(3)(b): 10-9a-408
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-401(3)(b)(i): This Subsection (3)(b) applies to a municipality that is not a specified municipality as of January 1, 2023.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-401(3)(b)(ii): 10-9a-408 As of January 1, if a municipality described in Subsection (3)(b)(i) changes from one class to another or grows in population to qualify as a specified municipality as defined in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-405 Effect of general plan.
-------------------------------------------------------
Except as provided in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-406 Public uses to conform to general plan.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
After the legislative body has adopted a general plan, no street, park, or other public way, ground, place, or space, no publicly owned building or structure, and no public utility, whether publicly or privately owned, may be constructed or authorized until and unless it conforms to the current general plan.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-408(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-408(3)(a): After the division approves a specified municipality's initial report under this section, the specified municipality shall, as an administrative act, annually submit to the division a subsequent progress report on or before August 1 of each year after the year in which the specified municipality is required to submit the initial report.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-408(3)(b): The subsequent progress report shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-408(3)(b)(i): subject to Subsection (3)(c), a description of each action, whether one-time or ongoing, taken by the specified municipality during the previous 12-month period to implement the moderate income housing strategies identified in the initial report for implementation;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-408(3)(b)(ii): a description of each land use regulation or land use decision made by the specified municipality during the previous 12-month period to implement the moderate income housing strategies, including an explanation of how the land use regulation or land use decision supports the specified municipality's efforts to implement the moderate income housing strategies;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-408(3)(b)(iii): a description of any barriers encountered by the specified municipality in the previous 12-month period in implementing the moderate income housing strategies;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-408(3)(b)(iv): information regarding the number of internal and external or detached accessory dwelling units located within the specified municipality for which the specified municipality:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-408(3)(b)(iv)(A): issued a building permit to construct; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-408(3)(b)(iv)(B): issued a business license or comparable license or permit to rent;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-408(3)(b)(v): the number of residential dwelling units that have been entitled that have not received a building permit as of the submission date of the progress report;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-408(3)(b)(vi): shapefiles, or website links if shapefiles are not available, to current maps and tables related to zoning;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-408(3)(b)(vii): a description of how the market has responded to the selected moderate income housing strategies, including the number of entitled moderate income housing units or other relevant data; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-408(3)(b)(viii): any recommendations on how the state can support the specified municipality in implementing the moderate income housing strategies.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-408(7):

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-408(7)(b): A specified municipality that receives a notice of noncompliance may:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-408(7)(b)(i): cure each deficiency in the report within 90 days after the day on which the notice of noncompliance is sent; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-408(7)(b)(ii): request an appeal of the division's determination of noncompliance within 10 days after the day on which the notice of noncompliance is sent.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-408(7)(c): The notice described in Subsection (7)(a) shall:

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-408(7)(c)(ii)(B): submit to the division a request for an appeal of the division's determination of noncompliance within 10 days after the day on which the notice of noncompliance is sent; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-408(7)(c)(iii): state that failure to take action under Subsection (7)(c)(ii) will result in the specified municipality's ineligibility for funds under Subsection (9).
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-408(7)(d): For purposes of curing the deficiencies in a report under this Subsection (7), if the action needed to cure the deficiency as described by the division requires the specified municipality to make a legislative change, the specified municipality may cure the deficiency by making that legislative change within the 90-day cure period.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-408(7)(e):

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-408(7)(e)(ii): A specified municipality that receives a second notice of noncompliance may submit to the division a request for an appeal of the division's determination of noncompliance within 10 days after the day on which the second notice of noncompliance is sent.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-408(8)(b): Within 90 days after the day on which the division receives a request for an appeal, an appeal board consisting of the following three members shall review and issue a written decision on the appeal:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-408(8)(b)(i): one individual appointed by the Utah League of Cities and Towns;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-408(8)(b)(ii): one individual appointed by the Utah Homebuilders Association; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-408(8)(b)(iii): one individual appointed by the presiding member of the association of governments, established pursuant to an interlocal agreement under Title 11, Chapter 13, Interlocal Cooperation Act, of which the specified municipality is a member.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-408(8)(c): The written decision of the appeal board shall either uphold or reverse the division's determination of noncompliance.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-408(8)(d): The appeal board's written decision on the appeal is final.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-505 Zoning districts.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-505(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-505(1)(a): The legislative body may divide the territory over which it has jurisdiction into zoning districts of a number, shape, and area that it considers appropriate to carry out the purposes of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-505(1)(b): Within those zoning districts, the legislative body may regulate and restrict the erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration, repair, or use of buildings and structures, and the use of land.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-505(1)(c): A municipality may enact an ordinance regulating land use and development in a flood plain or potential geologic hazard area to:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-505(1)(c)(i): protect life; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-505(1)(c)(ii): prevent:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-505(1)(c)(ii)(A): the substantial loss of real property; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-505(1)(c)(ii)(B): substantial damage to real property.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-505(2): The legislative body shall ensure that the regulations are uniform for each class or kind of buildings throughout each zoning district, but the regulations in one zone may differ from those in other zones.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-505(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-505(3)(a): There is no minimum area or diversity of ownership requirement for a zone designation.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-505(3)(b): Neither the size of a zoning district nor the number of landowners within the district may be used as evidence of the illegality of a zoning district or of the invalidity of a municipal decision.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-505(4): A municipality may by ordinance exempt from specific zoning district standards a subdivision of land to accommodate the siting of a public utility infrastructure.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-505.5 Limit on single family designation.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-505.5(1): As used in this section, "single-family limit" means the number of individuals allowed to occupy each residential unit that is recognized by a land use authority in a zone permitting occupancy by a single family.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-505.5(2): A municipality may not adopt a single-family limit that is less than:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-505.5(2)(a): three, if the municipality has within its boundary:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-505.5(2)(a)(i): a state university; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-505.5(2)(a)(ii): a private university with a student population of at least 20,000; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-505.5(2)(b): four, for each other municipality.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-506 Regulating annexed territory.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-506(1): The legislative body of each municipality shall assign a land use zone or a variety thereof to territory annexed to the municipality at the time the territory is annexed.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-506(2): If the legislative body fails to assign a land use zone at the time the territory is annexed, all land uses within the annexed territory shall be compatible with surrounding uses within the municipality.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-507 Conditional uses.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-507(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-507(1)(a): A municipality may adopt a land use ordinance that includes conditional uses and provisions for conditional uses that require compliance with objective standards set forth in an applicable ordinance.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-507(1)(b): A municipality may not impose a requirement or standard on a conditional use that conflicts with a provision of this chapter or other state or federal law.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-507(2): (2)(a)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-507(2)(a): (2)(a)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-507(2)(a)(i): A land use authority shall approve a conditional use if reasonable conditions are proposed, or can be imposed, to mitigate the reasonably anticipated detrimental effects of the proposed use in accordance with applicable standards.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-507(2)(a)(ii): (2)(a)(i) The requirement described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-507(2)(b): If a land use authority proposes reasonable conditions on a proposed conditional use, the land use authority shall ensure that the conditions are stated on the record and reasonably relate to mitigating the anticipated detrimental effects of the proposed use.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-507(2)(c): If the reasonably anticipated detrimental effects of a proposed conditional use cannot be substantially mitigated by the proposal or the imposition of reasonable conditions to achieve compliance with applicable standards, the land use authority may deny the conditional use.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-507(3): A land use authority's decision to approve or deny conditional use is an administrative land use decision.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-507(4): A legislative body shall classify any use that a land use regulation allows in a zoning district as either a permitted or conditional use under this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-511 Nonconforming uses and noncomplying structures.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-511(1): (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-511(1)(a): Except as provided in this section, a nonconforming use or noncomplying structure may be continued by the present or a future property owner.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-511(1)(b): A nonconforming use may be extended through the same building, provided no structural alteration of the building is proposed or made for the purpose of the extension.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-511(1)(c): (1) For purposes of this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-511(2): The legislative body may provide for:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-511(2)(a): the establishment, restoration, reconstruction, extension, alteration, expansion, or substitution of nonconforming uses upon the terms and conditions set forth in the land use ordinance;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-511(2)(b): the termination of all nonconforming uses, except billboards, by providing a formula establishing a reasonable time period during which the owner can recover or amortize the amount of his investment in the nonconforming use, if any; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-511(2)(c): the termination of a nonconforming use due to its abandonment.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-511(3): 10-9a-513(2)
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-511(3)(a): A municipality may not prohibit the reconstruction or restoration of a noncomplying structure or terminate the nonconforming use of a structure that is involuntarily destroyed in whole or in part due to fire or other calamity unless the structure or use has been abandoned.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-511(3)(b): A municipality may prohibit the reconstruction or restoration of a noncomplying structure or terminate the nonconforming use of a structure if:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-511(3)(b)(i): the structure is allowed to deteriorate to a condition that the structure is rendered uninhabitable and is not repaired or restored within six months after the day on which written notice is served to the property owner that the structure is uninhabitable and that the noncomplying structure or nonconforming use will be lost if the structure is not repaired or restored within six months; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-511(3)(b)(ii): the property owner has voluntarily demolished a majority of the noncomplying structure or the building that houses the nonconforming use.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-511(3)(c): 10-9a-513(2)
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-511(3)(c)(i): Notwithstanding a prohibition in the municipality's zoning ordinance, a municipality may permit a billboard owner to relocate the billboard within the municipality's boundaries to a location that is mutually acceptable to the municipality and the billboard owner.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-511(3)(c)(ii): 10-9a-513(2) If the municipality and billboard owner cannot agree to a mutually acceptable location within 180 days after the day on which the owner submits a written request to relocate the billboard, the billboard owner may relocate the billboard in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-511(4): (4)(c); (4)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-511(4)(a): Unless the municipality establishes, by ordinance, a uniform presumption of legal existence for nonconforming uses, the property owner shall have the burden of establishing the legal existence of a noncomplying structure or nonconforming use through substantial evidence, which may not be limited to municipal or county records.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-511(4)(b): Any party claiming that a nonconforming use has been abandoned shall have the burden of establishing the abandonment.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-511(4)(c): Abandonment may be presumed to have occurred if:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-511(4)(c)(i): a majority of the primary structure associated with the nonconforming use has been voluntarily demolished without prior written agreement with the municipality regarding an extension of the nonconforming use;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-511(4)(c)(ii): the use has been discontinued for a minimum of one year; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-511(4)(c)(iii): the primary structure associated with the nonconforming use remains vacant for a period of one year.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-511(4)(d): (4)(c); (4)(b) The property owner may rebut the presumption of abandonment under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-511(5): A municipality may terminate the nonconforming status of a school district or charter school use or structure when the property associated with the school district or charter school use or structure ceases to be used for school district or charter school purposes for a period established by ordinance.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-513 Municipality's acquisition of billboard by eminent domain -- Removal without providing compensation -- Limit on allowing nonconforming billboards to be rebuilt or replaced -- Validity of municipal permit after issuance of state permit.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-513(1): (1)(b)(ii) As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-513(1)(a): "Clearly visible" means capable of being read without obstruction by an occupant of a vehicle traveling on a street or highway within the visibility area.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-513(1)(b): (1)(b)(ii) "Highest allowable height" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-513(1)(b)(i): (1)(b)(ii) if the height allowed by the municipality, by ordinance or consent, is higher than the height under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-513(1)(b)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-513(1)(b)(ii)(A): for a noninterstate billboard:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-513(1)(b)(ii)(A)(I): if the height of the previous use or structure is 45 feet or higher, the height of the previous use or structure; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-513(1)(b)(ii)(A)(II): if the height of the previous use or structure is less than 45 feet, the height of the previous use or structure or the height to make the entire advertising content of the billboard clearly visible, whichever is higher, but no higher than 45 feet; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-513(1)(b)(ii)(B): for an interstate billboard:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-513(1)(b)(ii)(B)(I): if the height of the previous use or structure is at or above the interstate height, the height of the previous use or structure; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-513(1)(b)(ii)(B)(II): if the height of the previous use or structure is less than the interstate height, the height of the previous use or structure or the height to make the entire advertising content of the billboard clearly visible, whichever is higher, but no higher than the interstate height.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-513(1)(c): "Interstate billboard" means a billboard that is intended to be viewed from a highway that is an interstate.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-513(1)(d): "Interstate height" means a height that is the higher of:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-513(1)(d)(i): 65 feet above the ground; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-513(1)(d)(ii): 25 feet above the grade of the interstate.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-513(1)(e): "Noninterstate billboard" means a billboard that is intended to be viewed from a street or highway that is not an interstate.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-513(1)(f): "Visibility area" means the area on a street or highway that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-513(1)(f)(i): defined at one end by a line extending from the base of the billboard across all lanes of traffic of the street or highway in a plane that is perpendicular to the street or highway; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-513(1)(f)(ii): defined on the other end by a line extending across all lanes of traffic of the street or highway in a plane that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-513(1)(f)(ii)(A): perpendicular to the street or highway; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-513(1)(f)(ii)(B): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-513(1)(f)(ii)(B)(I): for an interstate billboard, 500 feet from the base of the billboard; or

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-514 Manufactured homes.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-514(1): 15A-1-302 For purposes of this section, a manufactured home is the same as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-514(2): A manufactured home may not be excluded from any land use zone or area in which a single-family residence would be permitted, provided the manufactured home complies with all local land use ordinances, building codes, and any restrictive covenants, applicable to a single family residence within that zone or area.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-514(3): A municipality may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-514(3)(a): adopt or enforce an ordinance or regulation that treats a proposed development that includes manufactured homes differently than one that does not include manufactured homes; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-514(3)(b): reject a development plan based on the fact that the development is expected to contain manufactured homes.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-515 Regulation of amateur radio antennas.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-515(1): A municipality may not enact or enforce an ordinance that does not comply with the ruling of the Federal Communications Commission in "Amateur Radio Preemption, 101 FCC 2nd 952 (1985)" or a regulation related to amateur radio service adopted under 47 C.F.R. Part 97.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-515(2): If a municipality adopts an ordinance involving the placement, screening, or height of an amateur radio antenna based on health, safety, or aesthetic conditions, the ordinance shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-515(2)(a): reasonably accommodate amateur radio communications; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-515(2)(b): represent the minimal practicable regulation to accomplish the municipality's purpose.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-516 Regulation of residential facilities for persons with disabilities.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A municipality may only regulate a residential facility for persons with a disability to the extent allowed by:Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-516(1): Title 57, Chapter 21, Utah Fair Housing Act
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-516(2): the Fair Housing Amendments Act of 1988, 42 U.S.C. Sec. 3601 et seq., and applicable jurisprudence; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-516(3): Section 504, Rehabilitation Act of 1973, and applicable jurisprudence.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-520 Licensing of residences for persons with a disability.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The responsibility to license programs or entities that operate facilities for persons with a disability, as well as to require and monitor the provision of adequate services to persons residing in those facilities, shall rest with the Department of Health and Human Services as provided in:Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-520(1): Title 26B, Chapter 2, Part 2, Health Care Facility Licensing and Inspection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-520(2): Title 26B, Chapter 6, Part 4, Division of Services for People with Disabilities


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-521 Wetlands.
-----------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-521(1): A municipality may not designate or treat any land as wetlands unless the United States Army Corps of Engineers or other agency of the federal government has designated the land as wetlands.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-521(2): 79-3-201 A land use authority that issues a land use permit that affects land designated as wetlands by the United States Army Corps of Engineers or another agency of the federal government shall provide a copy of the land use permit to the Utah Geological Survey established in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-522 Refineries.
-------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-522(1): As used in this section, "develop" or "development" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-522(1)(a): the construction, alteration, or improvement of land, including any related moving, demolition, or excavation outside of a refinery property boundary;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-522(1)(b): the subdivision of land for a non-industrial use; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-522(1)(c): the construction of a non-industrial structure on a parcel that is not subject to the subdivision process.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-522(2): Before a legislative body may adopt a non-industrial zoning change to permit development within 500 feet of a refinery boundary, the legislative body shall consult with the refinery to determine whether the proposed change is compatible with the refinery.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-522(3): Before a land use authority may approve an application to develop within 500 feet of a refinery boundary, the land use authority shall consult with the refinery to determine whether the development is compatible with the refinery.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-522(4)(c): information that is restricted from public disclosure under federal or state law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-522(4)(d): information that is available in public record.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-522(5): (2); (3)
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-522(5)(a): (2); (3) This section does not grant authority to a legislative body described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-522(5)(b): This section does not create a cause of action against a refinery.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-522(5)(c): Except as expressly provided in this section, this section does not alter or remove any legal right or obligation of a refinery.
