Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-525 High tunnels -- Exemption from municipal regulation.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-525(1): As used in this section, "high tunnel" means a structure that:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-525(1)(a): is not a permanent structure;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-525(1)(b): is used for the keeping, storing, sale, or shelter of an agricultural commodity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-525(1)(c): has a:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-525(1)(c)(i): metal, wood, or plastic frame;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-525(1)(c)(ii): plastic, woven textile, or other flexible covering; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-525(1)(c)(iii): floor made of soil, crushed stone, matting, pavers, or a floating concrete slab.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-525(2): A municipal building code does not apply to a high tunnel.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-525(3): No building permit shall be required for the construction of a high tunnel.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-527 Historic preservation authority.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-527(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-527(1)(a): A legislative body may designate a historic preservation authority.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-527(1)(b): A legislative body may not designate the legislative body or the municipality's governing body as a historic preservation authority.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-527(2): In making administrative decisions on land use applications, a historic preservation authority shall apply the plain language of the land use regulations to a land use application.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-527(3): If a land use regulation does not plainly restrict a land use application, the historic preservation authority shall interpret and apply the land use regulation to favor the land use application.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-534(3)(h)(ii): in exchange for an increase in density or other benefit not otherwise available as a permitted use in the zoning area or district; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-534(3)(i): an ordinance enacted to mitigate the impacts of an accidental explosion:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-534(3)(i)(i): in excess of 20,000 pounds of trinitrotoluene equivalent;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-534(3)(i)(ii): that would create overpressure waves greater than .2 pounds per square inch; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-534(3)(i)(iii): that would pose a risk of damage to a window, garage door, or carport of a facility located within the vicinity of the regulated area.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-535 Moderate income housing.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-535(1): A municipality may only require the development of a certain number of moderate income housing units as a condition of approval of a land use application if:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-535(1)(a): the municipality and the applicant enter into a written agreement regarding the number of moderate income housing units; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-535(1)(b): the municipality provides incentives for an applicant who agrees to include moderate income housing units in a development.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-535(2): (1)(a); (b) If an applicant does not agree to participate in the development of moderate income housing units under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-535(3): (1); (2); 59-12-401 Notwithstanding Subsections


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-536 Water wise landscaping.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-536(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-536(1)(a): "Lawn or turf" means nonagricultural land planted in closely mowed, managed grasses.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-536(1)(b): "Mulch" means material such as rock, bark, wood chips, or other materials left loose and applied to the soil.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-536(1)(c): "Overhead spray irrigation" means above ground irrigation heads that spray water through a nozzle.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-536(1)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-536(1)(d)(i): "Vegetative coverage" means the ground level surface area covered by the exposed leaf area of a plant or group of plants at full maturity.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-536(1)(d)(ii): "Vegetative coverage" does not mean the ground level surface area covered by the exposed leaf area of a tree or trees.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-536(1)(e): "Water wise landscaping" means any or all of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-536(1)(e)(i): installation of plant materials suited to the microclimate and soil conditions that can:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-536(1)(e)(i)(A): remain healthy with minimal irrigation once established; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-536(1)(e)(i)(B): be maintained without the use of overhead spray irrigation;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-536(1)(e)(ii): use of water for outdoor irrigation through proper and efficient irrigation design and water application; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-536(1)(e)(iii): use of other landscape design features that:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-536(1)(e)(iii)(A): minimize the need of the landscape for supplemental water from irrigation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-536(1)(e)(iii)(B): reduce the landscape area dedicated to lawn or turf.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-536(2): A municipality may not enact or enforce an ordinance, resolution, or policy that prohibits, or has the effect of prohibiting, a property owner from incorporating water wise landscaping on the property owner's property.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-536(3): (3)(b); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-536(3)(a): (3)(b); (2) Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-536(3)(a)(i): comply with a site plan review or other review process before installing water wise landscaping;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-536(3)(a)(ii): maintain plant material in a healthy condition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-536(3)(a)(iii): follow specific water wise landscaping design requirements adopted by the municipality, including a requirement that:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-536(3)(a)(iii)(A): restricts or clarifies the use of mulches considered detrimental to municipal operations;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-536(3)(a)(iii)(B): imposes minimum or maximum vegetative coverage standards; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-536(3)(a)(iii)(C): restricts or prohibits the use of specific plant materials.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-536(3)(b): A municipality may not require a property owner to install or keep in place lawn or turf in an area with a width less than eight feet.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-536(4): 73-10-37 A municipality shall report to the Division of Water Resources the existence, enactment, or modification of an ordinance, resolution, or policy that implements regional-based water use efficiency standards established by the Division of Water Resources by rule under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-537 Land use compatibility with military use.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-537(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-537(1)(a): "Department" means the Department of Veterans and Military Affairs.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-537(1)(b): "Military" means a branch of the armed forces of the United States, including the Utah National Guard.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-537(1)(c): "Military land" means the following land or facilities:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-537(1)(c)(i): Camp Williams;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-537(1)(c)(ii): Hill Air Force Base;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-537(1)(c)(iii): Dugway Proving Ground;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-537(1)(c)(iv): Tooele Army Depot;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-537(1)(c)(v): Utah Test and Training Range;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-537(1)(c)(vi): Nephi Readiness Center;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-537(1)(c)(vii): Cedar City Alternate Flight Facility; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-537(1)(c)(viii): Little Mountain Test Facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-537(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-537(2)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (2)(b), on or before July 1, 2025, for any area in a municipality within 5,000 feet of a boundary of military land, a municipality shall, in consultation with the department, develop and maintain a compatible use plan to ensure permitted uses and conditional uses relevant to the military land are compatible with the military operations on military land.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-537(2)(b): A municipality that has a compatible use plan as of January 1, 2023, is not required to develop a new compatible use plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-537(3): If a municipality receives a land use application related to land within 5,000 feet of a boundary of military land, before the municipality may approve the land use application, the municipality shall notify the department in writing.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-537(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-537(4)(a): If the department receives the notice described in Subsection (3), the executive director of the department shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-537(4)(a)(i): determine whether the proposed land use is compatible with the military use of the relevant military land; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-537(4)(a)(ii): within 90 days after the receipt of the notice described in Subsection (3), respond in writing to the municipality regarding the determination of compatibility described in Subsection (4)(a)(i).
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-537(4)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-537(4)(b)(i): For a land use application pertaining to a parcel within 5,000 feet of military land that may have an adverse effect on the operations of the military installation, except as provided in Subsection (4)(b)(ii), the municipality shall consider the compatible use plan in processing the land use application.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-537(4)(b)(ii): For a land use application pertaining to a parcel within 5,000 feet of military land that may have an adverse effect on the operations of the military installation, if the applicant has a vested right, the municipality is not required to consider the compatible land use plan in consideration of the land use application.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-537(5): If the department receives the notice described in Subsection (3) before the municipality has completed the compatible use plan as described in this section, the department shall consult with the municipality and representatives of the relevant military land to determine whether the use proposed in the land use application is a compatible use.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-538 Modular building.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-538(1): Title 15A, State Construction and Fire Codes Act, governs regulations related to the construction, transportation, installation, inspection, fees, and enforcement related to modular building.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-538(2): A municipality may adopt an ordinance regulating modular building so long as the ordinance conforms with Title 15A, State Construction and Fire Codes Act, and this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-539 Operation of a tower crane.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-539(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-539(1)(a): "Affected land" means a parcel of land over which a part of a tower crane travels, other than the parcel on which the tower crane is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-539(1)(b): "Airspace approval" means a license, easement, permission of the owner of affected land, or other approval for a part of a tower crane to travel within the air space over affected land.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-539(1)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-539(1)(c)(i): "Live load" means material being suspended from or lifted by a tower crane.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-539(1)(c)(ii): "Live load" does not include the components of a tower crane.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-539(1)(d): "Permit period" means the period during which a land use permit is in effect.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-539(1)(e): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-539(1)(e)(i): "Tower crane" means a crane that is attached to and supported by a building or foundation.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-539(1)(e)(ii): "Tower crane" does not include a crane supported by tracks or tires.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-539(2): Except as provided in Subsection (3), a municipality may not require airspace approval as a condition for the municipality's:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-539(2)(a): approval of a building permit; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-539(2)(b): authorization of a development activity.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-539(3): A municipality may require airspace approval relating to affected land as a condition for the municipality's approval of a building permit or for the municipality's authorization of a development activity if:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-539(3)(a): the tower crane will, during the permit period or development activity, carry a live load over the affected land; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-539(3)(b): the affected land is within:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-539(3)(b)(i): an airport overlay zone; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-539(3)(b)(ii): another zone designated to protect the airspace around an airport.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-540 Residential rear setback limitations.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-540(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-540(1)(a): "Allowable feature" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-540(1)(a)(i): a landing or walkout porch that:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-540(1)(a)(i)(A): is no more than 32 square feet in size; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-540(1)(a)(i)(B): is used for ingress to and egress from the rear of the residential dwelling; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-540(1)(a)(ii): a window well.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-540(1)(b): "Landing" means an uncovered, above-ground platform, with or without stairs, connected to the rear of a residential dwelling.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-540(1)(c): "Setback" means the required distance between the property line of a lot or parcel and the location where a structure is allowed to be placed under an adopted land use regulation.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-540(1)(d): "Walkout porch" means an uncovered platform that is on the ground and connected to the rear of a residential dwelling.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-540(1)(e): "Window well" means a recess in the ground around a residential dwelling to allow for ingress and egress through a window installed in a basement that is fully or partially below ground.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-540(2): A municipality may not enact or enforce an ordinance, resolution, or policy that prohibits or has the effect of prohibiting an allowable feature within the rear setback of a residential building lot or parcel.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-540(3): Subsection (2) does not apply to a historic district within the municipality.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-601 Enactment of subdivision ordinance.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-601(1): The legislative body of a municipality may enact ordinances requiring that a subdivision plat comply with the provisions of the municipality's ordinances and this part before:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-601(1)(a): the subdivision plat may be filed and recorded in the county recorder's office; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-601(1)(b): lots may be sold.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-601(2): If the legislative body fails to enact a subdivision ordinance, the municipality may regulate subdivisions only to the extent provided in this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-601(3): The joining of a lot or lots to a parcel does not constitute a subdivision as to the parcel or subject the parcel to the municipality's subdivision ordinance.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-601(4): A legislative body may adopt a land use regulation that specifies that combining lots does not require a subdivision plat amendment.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-602(2)(b): A legislative body may consider a planning commission's failure to make a timely recommendation as a negative recommendation if the legislative body has provided for that consideration by ordinance.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604 Subdivision plat approval procedure -- Effect of not complying.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604(1): 10-9a-603(6)(a); (1)(b); Title 57, Chapter 8a, Community Association Act; 57-8a-102; 57-8a-102 A person may not submit a subdivision plat to the county recorder's office for recording unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604(1)(a): 10-9a-603(6)(a) the person has complied with the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604(1)(b): the plat has been approved by:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604(1)(b)(i): the land use authority of the municipality in which the land described in the plat is located; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604(1)(b)(ii): other officers that the municipality designates in its ordinance;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604(1)(c): (1)(b) all approvals described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604(1)(d): Title 57, Chapter 8a, Community Association Act; 57-8a-102; 57-8a-102 if the person submitting the plat intends the plat to be or if the plat is part of a community association subject to
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604(2): A subdivision plat recorded without the signatures required under this section is void.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604(3): A transfer of land pursuant to a void plat is voidable by the land use authority.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.1 Process for subdivision review and approval.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.1(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.1(1)(a): As used in this section, an "administrative land use authority" means an individual, board, or commission, appointed or employed by a municipality, including municipal staff or a municipal planning commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.1(1)(b): "Administrative land use authority" does not include a municipal legislative body or a member of a municipal legislative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.1(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.1(2)(a): This section applies to land use decisions arising from subdivision applications for single-family dwellings, two-family dwellings, or townhomes.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.1(2)(b): This section does not apply to land use regulations adopted, approved, or agreed upon by a legislative body exercising land use authority in the review of land use applications for zoning or other land use regulation approvals.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.1(3): 10-9a-605; 10-9a-605 A municipal ordinance governing the subdivision of land shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.1(3)(a): comply with this section, and establish a standard method and form of application for preliminary subdivision applications and final subdivision applications; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.1(3)(b): 10-9a-605; 10-9a-605
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.1(3)(b)(i): designate a single administrative land use authority for the review of preliminary applications to subdivide land; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.1(3)(b)(ii): 10-9a-605; 10-9a-605 if the municipality has adopted an ordinance that establishes a separate procedure for the review and approval of subdivisions under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.1(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.1(4)(a): If an applicant requests a pre-application meeting, the municipality shall, within 15 business days after the request, schedule the meeting to review the concept plan and give initial feedback.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.1(4)(b): At the pre-application meeting, the municipal staff shall provide or have available on the municipal website the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.1(4)(b)(i): copies of applicable land use regulations;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.1(4)(b)(ii): a complete list of standards required for the project;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.1(4)(b)(iii): preliminary and final application checklists; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.1(4)(b)(iv): feedback on the concept plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.1(5): A preliminary subdivision application shall comply with all applicable municipal ordinances and requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.1(6): An administrative land use authority may complete a preliminary subdivision application review in a public meeting or at a municipal staff level.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.1(7): With respect to a preliminary application to subdivide land, an administrative land use authority may:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.1(7)(a): receive public comment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.1(7)(b): hold no more than one public hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.1(8): If a preliminary subdivision application complies with the applicable municipal ordinances and the requirements of this section, the administrative land use authority shall approve the preliminary subdivision application.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.1(9): A municipality shall review and approve or deny a final subdivision plat application in accordance with the provisions of this section and municipal ordinances, which:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.1(9)(a): may permit concurrent processing of the final subdivision plat application with the preliminary subdivision plat application; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.1(9)(b): may not require planning commission or city council approval.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.1(10): (9)(a) If a final subdivision application complies with the requirements of this section, the applicable municipal ordinances, and the preliminary subdivision approval granted under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2 Review of subdivision land use applications and subdivision improvement plans.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(1)(a): "Review cycle" means the occurrence of:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(1)(a)(i): the applicant's submittal of a complete subdivision land use application;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(1)(a)(ii): the municipality's review of that subdivision land use application;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(1)(a)(iii): the municipality's response to that subdivision land use application, in accordance with this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(1)(a)(iv): the applicant's reply to the municipality's response that addresses each of the municipality's required modifications or requests for additional information.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(1)(b): "Subdivision improvement plans" means the civil engineering plans associated with required infrastructure and municipally controlled utilities required for a subdivision.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(1)(c): "Subdivision ordinance review" means review by a municipality to verify that a subdivision land use application meets the criteria of the municipality's subdivision ordinances.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(1)(d): "Subdivision plan review" means a review of the applicant's subdivision improvement plans and other aspects of the subdivision land use application to verify that the application complies with municipal ordinances and applicable standards and specifications.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(2): The review cycle restrictions and requirements of this section do not apply to the review of subdivision applications affecting property within identified geological hazard areas.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(3)(a): No later than 15 business days after the day on which an applicant submits a complete preliminary subdivision land use application for a residential subdivision for single-family dwellings, two-family dwellings, or townhomes, the municipality shall complete the initial review of the application, including subdivision improvement plans.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(3)(b): A municipality shall maintain and publish a list of the items comprising the complete preliminary subdivision land use application, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(3)(b)(i): the application;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(3)(b)(ii): the owner's affidavit;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(3)(b)(iii): an electronic copy of all plans in PDF format;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(3)(b)(iv): the preliminary subdivision plat drawings; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(3)(b)(v): a breakdown of fees due upon approval of the application.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(4)(a): A municipality shall publish a list of the items that comprise a complete final subdivision land use application.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(4)(b): No later than 20 business days after the day on which an applicant submits a plat, the municipality shall complete a review of the applicant's final subdivision land use application for a residential subdivision for single-family dwellings, two-family dwellings, or townhomes, including all subdivision plan reviews.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(5): (5)(a)(i); (ii); (5)(d)(ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(5)(a): In reviewing a subdivision land use application, a municipality may require:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(5)(a)(i): additional information relating to an applicant's plans to ensure compliance with municipal ordinances and approved standards and specifications for construction of public improvements; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(5)(a)(ii): modifications to plans that do not meet current ordinances, applicable standards or specifications, or do not contain complete information.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(5)(b): (5)(a)(i); (ii) A municipality's request for additional information or modifications to plans under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(5)(c): A municipality may not require more than four review cycles.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(5)(d): (5)(d)(ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(5)(d)(i): (5)(d)(ii) Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(5)(d)(ii): A modification or correction necessary to protect public health and safety or to enforce state or federal law may not be waived.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(5)(d)(iii): If an applicant makes a material change to a plan set, the municipality has the discretion to restart the review process at the first review of the final application, but only with respect to the portion of the plan set that the material change substantively effects.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(5)(e): If an applicant does not submit a revised plan within 20 business days after the municipality requires a modification or correction, the municipality shall have an additional 20 business days to respond to the plans.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(6): After the applicant has responded to the final review cycle, and the applicant has complied with each modification requested in the municipality's previous review cycle, the municipality may not require additional revisions if the applicant has not materially changed the plan, other than changes that were in response to requested modifications or corrections.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(7)(a): In addition to revised plans, an applicant shall provide a written explanation in response to the municipality's review comments, identifying and explaining the applicant's revisions and reasons for declining to make revisions, if any.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(7)(b): The applicant's written explanation shall be comprehensive and specific, including citations to applicable standards and ordinances for the design and an index of requested revisions or additions for each required correction.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(7)(c): If an applicant fails to address a review comment in the response, the review cycle is not complete and the subsequent review cycle may not begin until all comments are addressed.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(8): 10-9a-508(5)(d)
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(8)(a): 10-9a-508(5)(d) If, on the fourth or final review, a municipality fails to respond within 20 business days, the municipality shall, upon request of the property owner, and within 10 business days after the day on which the request is received:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(8)(a)(i): 10-9a-508(5)(d) for a dispute arising from the subdivision improvement plans, assemble an appeal panel in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(8)(a)(ii): for a dispute arising from the subdivision ordinance review, advise the applicant, in writing, of the deficiency in the application and of the right to appeal the determination to a designated appeal authority.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2 Review of subdivision  applications and subdivision improvement plans.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(1)(a): "Review cycle" means the occurrence of:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(1)(a)(i): the applicant's submittal of a complete subdivision application;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(1)(a)(ii): the municipality's review of that subdivision application;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(1)(a)(iii): the municipality's response to that subdivision application, in accordance with this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(1)(a)(iv): the applicant's reply to the municipality's response that addresses each of the municipality's required modifications or requests for additional information.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(1)(b): "Subdivision application" means a land use application for the subdivision of land.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(1)(c): "Subdivision improvement plans" means the civil engineering plans associated with required infrastructure improvements and municipally controlled utilities required for a subdivision.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(1)(d): "Subdivision ordinance review" means review by a municipality to verify that a subdivision application meets the criteria of the municipality's ordinances.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(1)(e): "Subdivision plan review" means a review of the applicant's subdivision improvement plans and other aspects of the subdivision application to verify that the application complies with municipal ordinances and applicable installation standards and inspection specifications for infrastructure improvements.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(2): The review cycle restrictions and requirements of this section do not apply to the review of subdivision applications affecting property within identified geological hazard areas.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(3)(a): A municipality may require a subdivision improvement plan to be submitted with a subdivision application.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(3)(b): A municipality may not require a subdivision improvement plan to be submitted with both a preliminary subdivision application and a final subdivision application.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(4)(a): The review cycle requirements of this section apply:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(4)(a)(i): to the review of a preliminary subdivision application, if the municipality requires a subdivision improvement plan to be submitted with a preliminary subdivision application; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(4)(a)(ii): to the review of a final subdivision application, if the municipality requires a subdivision improvement plan to be submitted with a final subdivision application.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(4)(b): A municipality may not, outside the review cycle, engage in a substantive review of required infrastructure improvements or a municipally controlled utility.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(5)(a): A municipality shall complete the initial review of a complete subdivision application submitted for ordinance review for a residential subdivision for single-family dwellings, two-family dwellings, or town homes:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(5)(a)(i): no later than 15 business days after the complete subdivision application is submitted, if the municipality has a population over 5,000; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(5)(a)(ii): no later than 30 business days after the complete subdivision application is submitted, if the municipality has a population of 5,000 or less.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(5)(b): A municipality shall maintain and publish a list of the items comprising the complete subdivision application, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(5)(b)(i): the application;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(5)(b)(ii): the owner's affidavit;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(5)(b)(iii): an electronic copy of all plans in PDF format;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(5)(b)(iv): the preliminary subdivision plat drawings; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(5)(b)(v): a breakdown of fees due upon approval of the application.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(6): A municipality shall publish a list of the items that comprise a complete subdivision land use application.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(7): A municipality shall complete a subdivision plan review of a subdivision improvement plan that is submitted with a complete subdivision application for a residential subdivision for single-family dwellings, two-family dwellings, or town homes:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(7)(a): within 20 business days after the complete subdivision application is submitted, if the municipality has a population over 5,000; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(7)(b): within 40 business days after the complete subdivision application is submitted, if the municipality has a population of 5,000 or less.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(8)(a): In reviewing a subdivision application, a municipality may require:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(8)(a)(i): additional information relating to an applicant's plans to ensure compliance with municipal ordinances and approved standards and specifications for construction of public improvements; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(8)(a)(ii): modifications to plans that do not meet current ordinances, applicable standards or specifications, or do not contain complete information.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(8)(b): A municipality's request for additional information or modifications to plans under Subsection (8)(a)(i) or (ii) shall be specific and include citations to ordinances, standards, or specifications that require the modifications to subdivision improvement plans, and shall be logged in an index of requested modifications or additions.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(8)(c): A municipality may not require more than four review cycles for a subdivision improvement plan review.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(8)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(8)(d)(i): Subject to Subsection (8)(d)(ii), unless the change or correction is necessitated by the applicant's adjustment to a subdivision improvement plan or an update to a phasing plan that adjusts the infrastructure needed for the specific development, a change or correction not addressed or referenced in a municipality's subdivision improvement plan review is waived.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(8)(d)(ii): A modification or correction necessary to protect public health and safety or to enforce state or federal law may not be waived.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(8)(d)(iii): If an applicant makes a material change to a subdivision improvement plan, the municipality has the discretion to restart the review process at the first review of the subdivision improvement plan review, but only with respect to the portion of the subdivision improvement plan that the material change substantively affects.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(8)(e): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(8)(e)(i): This Subsection (8)(e) applies if an applicant does not submit a revised subdivision improvement plan within :
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(8)(e)(i)(A): 20 business days after the municipality requires a modification or correction, if the municipality has a population over 5,000; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(8)(e)(i)(B): 40 business days after the municipality requires a modification or correction, if the municipality has a population of 5,000 or less.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(8)(e)(ii): If an applicant does not submit a revised subdivision improvement plan within the time specified in Subsection (8)(e)(i), a municipality has an additional 20 business days after the time specified in Subsection (7) to respond to a revised subdivision improvement plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(9): After the applicant has responded to the final review cycle, and the applicant has complied with each modification requested in the municipality's previous review cycle, the municipality may not require additional revisions if the applicant has not materially changed the plan, other than changes that were in response to requested modifications or corrections.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(10)(a): In addition to revised plans, an applicant shall provide a written explanation in response to the municipality's review comments, identifying and explaining the applicant's revisions and reasons for declining to make revisions, if any.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(10)(b): The applicant's written explanation shall be comprehensive and specific, including citations to applicable standards and ordinances for the design and an index of requested revisions or additions for each required correction.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(10)(c): If an applicant fails to address a review comment in the response, the review cycle is not complete and the subsequent review cycle may not begin until all comments are addressed.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(11): 10-9a-508
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(11)(a): 10-9a-508 If, on the fourth or final review, a municipality fails to respond within 20 business days, the municipality shall, upon request of the property owner, and within 10 business days after the day on which the request is received:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(11)(a)(i): 10-9a-508 for a dispute arising from the subdivision improvement plans, assemble an appeal panel in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.2(11)(a)(ii): for a dispute arising from the subdivision ordinance review, advise the applicant, in writing, of the deficiency in the application and of the right to appeal the determination to a designated appeal authority.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5 Subdivision plat recording or development activity before required landscaping or infrastructure is completed -- Improvement completion assurance -- Improvement warranty.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(1): As used in this section, "public landscaping improvement" means landscaping that an applicant is required to install to comply with published installation and inspection specifications for public improvements that:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(1)(a): will be dedicated to and maintained by the municipality; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(1)(b): are associated with and proximate to trail improvements that connect to planned or existing public infrastructure.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(2): A land use authority shall establish objective inspection standards for acceptance of a public landscaping improvement or infrastructure improvement that the land use authority requires.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3): 10-9a-802; 10-9a-103
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3)(a): Before an applicant conducts any development activity or records a plat, the applicant shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3)(a)(i): complete any required public landscaping improvements or infrastructure improvements; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3)(a)(ii): post an improvement completion assurance for any required public landscaping improvements or infrastructure improvements.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3)(b): If an applicant elects to post an improvement completion assurance, the applicant shall provide completion assurance for:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3)(b)(i): completion of 100% of the required public landscaping improvements or infrastructure improvements; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3)(b)(ii): if the municipality has inspected and accepted a portion of the public landscaping improvements or infrastructure improvements, 100% of the incomplete or unaccepted public landscaping improvements or infrastructure improvements.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3)(c): 10-9a-802 A municipality shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3)(c)(i): establish a minimum of two acceptable forms of completion assurance;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3)(c)(ii): if an applicant elects to post an improvement completion assurance, allow the applicant to post an assurance that meets the conditions of this title, and any local ordinances;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3)(c)(iii): establish a system for the partial release of an improvement completion assurance as portions of required public landscaping improvements or infrastructure improvements are completed and accepted in accordance with local ordinance; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3)(c)(iv): 10-9a-802 issue or deny a building permit in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3)(d): 10-9a-103 A municipality may not require an applicant to post an improvement completion assurance for:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3)(d)(i): public landscaping improvements or an infrastructure improvement that the municipality has previously inspected and accepted;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3)(d)(ii): infrastructure improvements that are private and not essential or required to meet the building code, fire code, flood or storm water management provisions, street and access requirements, or other essential necessary public safety improvements adopted in a land use regulation;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3)(d)(iii): in a municipality where ordinances require all infrastructure improvements within the area to be private, infrastructure improvements within a development that the municipality requires to be private; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3)(d)(iv): 10-9a-103 landscaping improvements that are not public landscaping improvements, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(4): (4)(c); (4)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(4)(a): (4)(c) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(4)(b): (4)(a) Any agreement regarding a completion assurance bond under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(4)(c): A municipality may not require a completion assurance bond for the landscaping of residential lots or the equivalent open space surrounding single-family attached homes, whether platted as lots or common area.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(5): (3); (4) The sum of the improvement completion assurance required under Subsections

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(5)(b): 10% of the amount of the bond to cover administrative costs incurred by the municipality to complete the improvements, if necessary.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(6): At any time before a municipality accepts a public landscaping improvement or infrastructure improvement, and for the duration of each improvement warranty period, the municipality may require the applicant to:

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5 Subdivision plat recording or development activity before required landscaping or infrastructure is completed -- Improvement completion assurance -- Improvement warranty.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(1): As used in this section, "public landscaping improvement" means landscaping that an applicant is required to install to comply with published installation and inspection specifications for public improvements that:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(1)(a): will be dedicated to and maintained by the municipality; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(1)(b): are associated with and proximate to trail improvements that connect to planned or existing public infrastructure.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(2): A land use authority shall establish objective inspection standards for acceptance of a public landscaping improvement or infrastructure improvement that the land use authority requires.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3): 10-9a-802
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3)(a): Before an applicant conducts any development activity or records a plat, the applicant shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3)(a)(i): complete any required public landscaping improvements or infrastructure improvements; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3)(a)(ii): post an improvement completion assurance for any required public landscaping improvements or infrastructure improvements.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3)(b): If an applicant elects to post an improvement completion assurance, the applicant shall provide completion assurance for:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3)(b)(i): completion of 100% of the required public landscaping improvements or infrastructure improvements; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3)(b)(ii): if the municipality has inspected and accepted a portion of the public landscaping improvements or infrastructure improvements, 100% of the incomplete or unaccepted public landscaping improvements or infrastructure improvements.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3)(c): 10-9a-802 A municipality shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3)(c)(i): establish a minimum of two acceptable forms of completion assurance;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3)(c)(ii): if an applicant elects to post an improvement completion assurance, allow the applicant to post an assurance that meets the conditions of this title, and any local ordinances;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3)(c)(iii): establish a system for the partial release of an improvement completion assurance as portions of required public landscaping improvements or infrastructure improvements are completed and accepted in accordance with local ordinance; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3)(c)(iv): 10-9a-802 issue or deny a building permit in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3)(d): A municipality may not require an applicant to post an improvement completion assurance for:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3)(d)(i): public landscaping improvements or an infrastructure improvement that the municipality has previously inspected and accepted;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3)(d)(ii): infrastructure improvements that are private and not essential or required to meet the building code, fire code, flood or storm water management provisions, street and access requirements, or other essential necessary public safety improvements adopted in a land use regulation;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3)(d)(iii): in a municipality where ordinances require all infrastructure improvements within the area to be private, infrastructure improvements within a development that the municipality requires to be private; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(3)(d)(iv): landscaping improvements that are not public landscaping improvements, unless the landscaping improvements and completion assurance are required under the terms of a development agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(4)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (4)(c), as a condition for increased density or other entitlement benefit not currently available under the existing zone, a municipality may require a completion assurance bond for landscaped amenities and common area that are dedicated to and maintained by a homeowners association.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(4)(b): Any agreement regarding a completion assurance bond under Subsection (4)(a) between the applicant and the municipality shall be memorialized in a development agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(4)(c): A municipality may not require a completion assurance bond for or dictate who installs or is responsible for the cost of the landscaping of residential lots or the equivalent open space surrounding single-family attached homes, whether platted as lots or common area.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(5): The sum of the improvement completion assurance required under Subsections (3) and (4) may not exceed the sum of:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(5)(a): 100% of the estimated cost of the public landscaping improvements or infrastructure improvements, as evidenced by an engineer's estimate or licensed contractor's bid; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(5)(b): 10% of the amount of the bond to cover administrative costs incurred by the municipality to complete the improvements, if necessary.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(6): At any time before a municipality accepts a public landscaping improvement or infrastructure improvement, and for the duration of each improvement warranty period, the municipality may require the applicant to:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(6)(a): execute an improvement warranty for the improvement warranty period; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(6)(b): post a cash deposit, surety bond, letter of credit, or other similar security, as required by the municipality, in the amount of up to 10% of the lesser of the:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(6)(b)(i): municipal engineer's original estimated cost of completion; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(6)(b)(ii): applicant's reasonable proven cost of completion.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(7): When a municipality accepts an improvement completion assurance for public landscaping improvements or infrastructure improvements for a development in accordance with Subsection (3)(c)(ii), the municipality may not deny an applicant a building permit if the development meets the requirements for the issuance of a building permit under the building code and fire code.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-604.5(8): The provisions of this section do not supersede the terms of a valid development agreement, an adopted phasing plan, or the state construction code.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-605(1)(b)(ii)(B): has been approved by the culinary water authority and the sanitary sewer authority;

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-607 Dedication by plat of public streets and other public places.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-607(1): A plat that is signed, dedicated, and acknowledged by each owner of record, and approved according to the procedures specified in this part, operates, when recorded, as a dedication of all public streets and other public places, and vests the fee of those parcels of land in the municipality for the public for the uses named or intended in the plat.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-607(2): The dedication established by this section does not impose liability upon the municipality for public streets and other public places that are dedicated in this manner but are unimproved unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-607(2)(a): adequate financial assurance has been provided in accordance with this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-607(2)(b): the municipality has accepted the dedication.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-609 Land use authority approval of vacation or amendment of plat -- Recording the amended plat.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-609(1): The land use authority may approve the vacation or amendment of a plat by signing an amended plat showing the vacation or amendment if the land use authority finds that:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-609(1)(a): there is good cause for the vacation or amendment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-609(1)(b): no public street or municipal utility easement has been vacated or amended.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-609(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-609(2)(a): The land use authority shall ensure that the amended plat showing the vacation or amendment is recorded in the office of the county recorder in which the land is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-609(2)(b): If the amended plat is approved and recorded in accordance with this section, the recorded plat shall vacate, supersede, and replace any contrary provision in a previously recorded plat of the same land.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-609(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-609(3)(a): A legislative body may vacate a subdivision or a portion of a subdivision by recording in the county recorder's office an ordinance describing the subdivision or the portion being vacated.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-609(3)(b): The recorded vacating ordinance shall replace a previously recorded plat described in the vacating ordinance.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-609(4): An amended plat may not be submitted to the county recorder for recording unless it is:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-609(4)(a): signed by the land use authority; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-609(4)(b): signed, acknowledged, and dedicated by each owner of record of the portion of the plat that is amended.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-610 Restrictions for solar and other energy devices.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The land use authority may refuse to approve or renew any plat, subdivision plan, or dedication of any street or other ground, if deed restrictions, covenants, or similar binding agreements running with the land for the lots or parcels covered by the plat or subdivision prohibit or have the effect of prohibiting reasonably sited and designed solar collectors, clotheslines, or other energy devices based on renewable resources from being installed on buildings erected on lots or parcels covered by the plat or subdivision.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-611(1)(a)(ii): (1)(a)(i) A violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-611(1)(b): (1)(a) The description by metes and bounds in an instrument of transfer or other documents used in the process of selling or transferring does not exempt the transaction from being a violation of Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-611(1)(c)(i): does not affect the validity of the instrument or other document; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-611(1)(c)(ii): does not affect whether the property that is the subject of the instrument or other document complies with applicable municipal ordinances on land use and development.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-701 Appeal authority required -- Condition precedent to judicial review -- Appeal authority duties.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-701(1): (1)(a); 10-9a-510; (1)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-701(1)(a): Each municipality adopting a land use ordinance shall, by ordinance, establish one or more appeal authorities.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-701(1)(b): (1)(a); 10-9a-510 An appeal authority described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-701(1)(b)(i): requests for variances from the terms of land use ordinances;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-701(1)(b)(ii): appeals from land use decisions applying land use ordinances; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-701(1)(b)(iii): 10-9a-510 appeals from a fee charged in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-701(1)(c): (1)(a) An appeal authority described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-701(2): As a condition precedent to judicial review, each adversely affected party shall timely and specifically challenge a land use authority's land use decision, in accordance with local ordinance.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-701(3): (1)(a) An appeal authority described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-701(3)(a): shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-701(3)(a)(i): act in a quasi-judicial manner; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-701(3)(a)(ii): serve as the final arbiter of issues involving the interpretation or application of land use ordinances; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-701(3)(b): may not entertain an appeal of a matter in which the appeal authority, or any participating member, had first acted as the land use authority.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-701(4): By ordinance, a municipality may:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-701(4)(a): designate a separate appeal authority to hear requests for variances than the appeal authority the municipality designates to hear appeals;

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-701(4)(c): require an adversely affected party to present to an appeal authority every theory of relief that the adversely affected party can raise in district court;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-701(4)(d): not require a land use applicant or adversely affected party to pursue duplicate or successive appeals before the same or separate appeal authorities as a condition of an appealing party's duty to exhaust administrative remedies; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-701(4)(e): provide that specified types of land use decisions may be appealed directly to the district court.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-701(5): If the municipality establishes or, prior to the effective date of this chapter, has established a multiperson board, body, or panel to act as an appeal authority, at a minimum the board, body, or panel shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-701(5)(a): notify each of the members of the board, body, or panel of any meeting or hearing of the board, body, or panel;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-701(5)(b): provide each of the members of the board, body, or panel with the same information and access to municipal resources as any other member;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-701(5)(c): convene only if a quorum of the members of the board, body, or panel is present; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-701(5)(d): act only upon the vote of a majority of the convened members of the board, body, or panel.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-702 Variances.
------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-702(1): Any person or entity desiring a waiver or modification of the requirements of a land use ordinance as applied to a parcel of property that he owns, leases, or in which he holds some other beneficial interest may apply to the applicable appeal authority for a variance from the terms of the ordinance.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-702(2): (2)(a); (2)(a); (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-702(2)(a): The appeal authority may grant a variance only if:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-702(2)(a)(i): literal enforcement of the ordinance would cause an unreasonable hardship for the applicant that is not necessary to carry out the general purpose of the land use ordinances;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-702(2)(a)(ii): there are special circumstances attached to the property that do not generally apply to other properties in the same zone;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-702(2)(a)(iii): granting the variance is essential to the enjoyment of a substantial property right possessed by other property in the same zone;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-702(2)(a)(iv): the variance will not substantially affect the general plan and will not be contrary to the public interest; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-702(2)(a)(v): the spirit of the land use ordinance is observed and substantial justice done.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-702(2)(b): (2)(a); (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-702(2)(b)(i): (2)(a) In determining whether or not enforcement of the land use ordinance would cause unreasonable hardship under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-702(2)(b)(i)(A): is located on or associated with the property for which the variance is sought; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-702(2)(b)(i)(B): comes from circumstances peculiar to the property, not from conditions that are general to the neighborhood.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-702(2)(b)(ii): (2)(a) In determining whether or not enforcement of the land use ordinance would cause unreasonable hardship under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-702(2)(c): (2)(a) In determining whether or not there are special circumstances attached to the property under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-702(2)(c)(i): relate to the hardship complained of; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-702(2)(c)(ii): deprive the property of privileges granted to other properties in the same zone.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-702(3): The applicant shall bear the burden of proving that all of the conditions justifying a variance have been met.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-702(4): Variances run with the land.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-702(5): The appeal authority may not grant a use variance.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-702(6): In granting a variance, the appeal authority may impose additional requirements on the applicant that will:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-702(6)(a): mitigate any harmful affects of the variance; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-702(6)(b): serve the purpose of the standard or requirement that is waived or modified.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-703(1): The land use applicant, a board or officer of the municipality, or an adversely affected party may, within the applicable time period, appeal that decision to the appeal authority by alleging that there is error in any order, requirement, decision, or determination made by the land use authority in the administration or interpretation of the land use ordinance.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-704 Time to appeal.
-----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-704(1): The municipality shall enact an ordinance establishing a reasonable time of not less than 10 days to appeal to an appeal authority a written decision issued by a land use authority.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-704(2): In the absence of an ordinance establishing a reasonable time to appeal, a land use applicant or adversely affected party shall have 10 calendar days to appeal to an appeal authority a written decision issued by a land use authority.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-704(3): (1); (2) Notwithstanding Subsections


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-705 Burden of proof.
------------------------------------------------
The appellant has the burden of proving that the land use authority erred.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-706 Due process.
--------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-706(1): Each appeal authority shall conduct each appeal and variance request as provided in local ordinance.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-706(2): Each appeal authority shall respect the due process rights of each of the participants.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-707 Scope of review of factual matters on appeal -- Appeal authority requirements.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-707(1): A municipality may, by ordinance, designate the scope of review of factual matters for appeals of land use authority decisions.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-707(2): If the municipality fails to designate a scope of review of factual matters, the appeal authority shall review the matter de novo, without deference to the land use authority's determination of factual matters.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-707(3): If the scope of review of factual matters is on the record, the appeal authority shall determine whether the record on appeal includes substantial evidence for each essential finding of fact.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-707(4): The appeal authority shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-707(4)(a): determine the correctness of the land use authority's interpretation and application of the plain meaning of the land use regulations; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-707(4)(b): interpret and apply a land use regulation to favor a land use application unless the land use regulation plainly restricts the land use application.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-707(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-707(5)(a): An appeal authority's land use decision is a quasi-judicial act.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-707(5)(b): A legislative body may act as an appeal authority unless both the legislative body and the appealing party agree to allow a third party to act as the appeal authority.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-707(6): Only a decision in which a land use authority has applied a land use regulation to a particular land use application, person, or parcel may be appealed to an appeal authority.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-708 Final decision.
-----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-708(1): A decision of an appeal authority takes effect on the date when the appeal authority issues a written decision, or as otherwise provided by ordinance.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-708(2): 10-9a-801(2)(a); 10-9a-801(4) A written decision, or other event as provided by ordinance, constitutes a final decision under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-802 Enforcement.
--------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-802(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-802(1)(a): A municipality or an adversely affected party may, in addition to other remedies provided by law, institute:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-802(1)(a)(i): injunctions, mandamus, abatement, or any other appropriate actions; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-802(1)(a)(ii): proceedings to prevent, enjoin, abate, or remove the unlawful building, use, or act.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-802(1)(b): A municipality need only establish the violation to obtain the injunction.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-802(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-802(2)(a): A municipality may enforce the municipality's ordinance by withholding a building permit.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-802(2)(b): It is an infraction to erect, construct, reconstruct, alter, or change the use of any building or other structure within a municipality without approval of a building permit.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-802(2)(c): A municipality may not issue a building permit unless the plans of and for the proposed erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration, or use fully conform to all regulations then in effect.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-802(2)(d): A municipality may not deny an applicant a building permit or certificate of occupancy because the applicant has not completed an infrastructure improvement:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-802(2)(d)(i): that is not essential to meet the requirements for the issuance of a building permit or certificate of occupancy under the building code and fire code; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-802(2)(d)(ii): for which the municipality has accepted an improvement completion assurance for landscaping or infrastructure improvements for the development.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-803 Penalties -- Notice.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-803(1): The municipality may, by ordinance, establish civil penalties for violations of any of the provisions of this chapter or of any ordinances adopted under the authority of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-803(2): Violation of any of the provisions of this chapter or of any ordinances adopted under the authority of this chapter is punishable as a class C misdemeanor upon conviction either:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-803(2)(a): as a class C misdemeanor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-803(2)(b): by imposing the appropriate civil penalty adopted under the authority of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-803(3): Prior to imposing upon an owner of record a civil penalty established by ordinance under authority of this chapter, a municipality shall provide:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-803(3)(a): written notice, by mail or hand delivery, of each ordinance violation to the address of the:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-803(3)(a)(i): owner of record on file in the office of the county recorder; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-803(3)(a)(ii): person designated, in writing, by the owner of record as the owner's agent for the purpose of receiving notice of an ordinance violation;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-803(3)(b): the owner of record a reasonable opportunity to cure a noticed violation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-803(3)(c): a schedule of the civil penalties that may be imposed upon the expiration of a time certain.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-901 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-901(1): "Critical infrastructure materials" means sand, gravel, or rock aggregate.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-901(2): "Critical infrastructure materials operations" means the extraction, excavation, processing, or reprocessing of critical infrastructure materials.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-901(3): "Critical infrastructure materials operator" means a natural person, corporation, association, partnership, receiver, trustee, executor, administrator, guardian, fiduciary, agent, or other organization or representative, either public or private, including a successor, assign, affiliate, subsidiary, and related parent company, that:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-901(3)(a): owns, controls, or manages a critical infrastructure materials operations; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-901(3)(b): has produced commercial quantities of critical infrastructure materials from the critical infrastructure materials operations.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-901(4): "Vested critical infrastructure materials operations" means critical infrastructure materials operations operating in accordance with a legal nonconforming use or a permit issued by the municipality that existed or was conducted or otherwise engaged in before:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-901(4)(a): a political subdivision prohibits, restricts, or otherwise limits the critical infrastructure materials operations; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-901(4)(b): January 1, 2019.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-902 Vested critical infrastructure materials operations -- Conclusive presumption.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-902(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-902(1)(a): Critical infrastructure materials operations operating in accordance with a legal nonconforming use or a permit issued by the municipality are conclusively presumed to be vested critical infrastructure materials operations if the critical infrastructure materials operations permitted by the municipality, existed or was conducted or otherwise engaged in before January 1, 2019 and before when a political subdivision prohibits, restricts, or otherwise limits the critical infrastructure materials operations.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-902(1)(b): A person claiming that a vested critical infrastructure materials operations has been established has the burden of proof to show by the preponderance of the evidence that the vested critical infrastructure materials operations has been established.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-902(2): A vested critical infrastructure materials operations:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-902(2)(a): runs with the land; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-902(2)(b): may be changed to another critical infrastructure materials operations conducted within the scope of a legal nonconforming use or the permit for the vested critical infrastructure materials operations without losing its status as a vested critical infrastructure materials operations.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-903 Rights of a critical infrastructure materials operator with a vested critical infrastructure materials operations.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Notwithstanding a political subdivision's prohibition, restriction, or other limitation on a critical infrastructure materials operations adopted after the establishment of the critical infrastructure materials operations, the rights of a critical infrastructure materials operator with vested critical infrastructure materials operations include the right to:Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-903(1): use, operate, construct, reconstruct, restore, maintain, repair, alter, substitute, modernize, upgrade, and replace equipment, processes, facilities, and buildings; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-903(2): discontinue, suspend, terminate, deactivate, or continue and reactivate, temporarily or permanently, all or any part of the critical infrastructure materials operations.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-904 Notice.
---------------------------------------
For any new subdivision development located in whole or in part within 1,000 feet of the boundary of a vested critical infrastructure materials operations, the owner of the development shall provide notice on any plat filed with the county recorder the following notice:

Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-905 Abandonment of a vested critical infrastructure materials operations.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-905(1): A critical infrastructure materials operator may abandon some or all of a vested critical infrastructure materials operations use only as provided in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-905(2): To abandon some or all of a vested critical infrastructure materials operations, a critical infrastructure materials operator shall record a written declaration of abandonment with the recorder of the county in which the vested critical infrastructure materials operations being abandoned is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-905(3): (2) The written declaration of abandonment under Subsection
