Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1002 Municipal designation of a home ownership promotion zone.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1002(1): 10-9a-1003; 10-9a-1004 Subject to the requirements of Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1002(2): A home ownership promotion zone created under this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1002(2)(a): is an area of 10 contiguous acres or less located entirely within the boundaries of the municipality, zoned for fewer than six housing units per acre before the creation of the home ownership promotion zone;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1002(2)(b): shall be re-zoned for at least six housing units per acre; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1002(2)(c): may not be encumbered by any residential building permits as of the day on which the home ownership promotion zone is created.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1002(3): 10-9a-1004; 10-9a-1003
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1002(3)(a): 10-9a-1004 The municipality shall designate the home ownership promotion zone by resolution of the legislative body of the municipality, passed or adopted in a public meeting of the legislative body of the municipality, following:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1002(3)(a)(i): the recommendation of the municipality planning commission; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1002(3)(a)(ii): 10-9a-1004 the notification requirements described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1002(3)(b): 10-9a-1003 The resolution described in Subsection (3)(a) shall describe how the home ownership promotion zone created pursuant to this section meets the objectives and requirements in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1002(3)(c): The home ownership promotion zone is created on the effective date of the resolution described in Subsection (3)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1002(4): If a home ownership promotion zone is created as described in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1002(4)(a): affected local taxing entities are required to participate according to the requirements of the home ownership promotion zone established by the municipality; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1002(4)(b): each affected taxing entity is required to participate at the same rate.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1002(5): A home ownership promotion zone may be modified by the same manner it is created as described in Subsection (3).
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1002(6): 63A-16-505 Within 30 days after the day on which the municipality creates the home ownership promotion zone as described in Subsection (3), the municipality shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1002(6)(a): record with the recorder of the county in which the home ownership promotion zone is located a document containing:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1002(6)(a)(i): a description of the land within the home ownership promotion zone; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1002(6)(a)(ii): the date of creation of the home ownership promotion zone;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1002(6)(b): 63A-16-505 transmit a copy of the description of the land within the home ownership promotion zone and an accurate map or plat indicating the boundaries of the home ownership promotion zone to the Utah Geospatial Resource Center created under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1002(6)(c): transmit a map and description of the land within the home ownership promotion zone to:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1002(6)(c)(i): the auditor, recorder, attorney, surveyor, and assessor of the county in which any part of the home ownership promotion zone is located;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1002(6)(c)(ii): the officer or officers performing the function of auditor or assessor for each taxing entity that does not use the county assessment roll or collect the taxing entity's taxes through the county;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1002(6)(c)(iii): the legislative body or governing board of each taxing entity impacted by the home ownership promotion zone;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1002(6)(c)(iv): the tax commission; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1002(6)(c)(v): the State Board of Education.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1002(7): 10-9a-1005 A municipality may receive tax increment and use home ownership promotion zone funds as described in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1003 Applicability, requirements, and limitations.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1003(1): A home ownership promotion zone shall promote the following objectives:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1003(1)(a): increasing availability of housing, including affordable housing;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1003(1)(b): promotion of home ownership;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1003(1)(c): overcoming development impediments and market conditions that render an affordable housing development cost prohibitive absent the incentives resulting from a home ownership promotion zone; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1003(1)(d): conservation of water resources through efficient land use.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1003(2): In order to accomplish the objectives described in Subsection (1), a municipality shall ensure that:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1003(2)(a): land inside the proposed home ownership promotion zone is zoned as residential, with at least six planned housing units per acre;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1003(2)(b): at least 60% of the proposed housing units within the home ownership promotion zone are affordable housing units; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1003(2)(c): all of the proposed housing units within the home ownership promotion zone are deed restricted to require owner occupation for at least five years.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1003(3): A municipality may restrict short term rentals in a home ownership promotion zone.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1003(4): 17C-1-102; 17C-1-702 A municipality may not create a home ownership promotion zone if:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1003(4)(a): the proposed home ownership promotion zone would overlap with a school district and:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1003(4)(a)(i): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1003(4)(a)(i)(A): the school district has more than one municipality within the school district's boundaries; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1003(4)(a)(i)(B): the school district already has 100 acres designated as home ownership promotion zone within the school district's boundaries; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1003(4)(a)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1003(4)(a)(ii)(A): the school district has one municipality within the school district's boundaries; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1003(4)(a)(ii)(B): the school district already has 50 acres designated as home ownership promotion zone within the school district's boundaries; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1003(4)(b): 17C-1-102; 17C-1-702 the area in the proposed home ownership zone would overlap with:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1003(4)(b)(i): 17C-1-102; 17C-1-702 a project area, as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1003(4)(b)(ii): an existing housing and transit reinvestment zone.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1004 Notification prior to creation of a home ownership promotion zone.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1004(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1004(1)(a): As used in this section, "hearing" means a public meeting in which the legislative body of a municipality:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1004(1)(a)(i): considers a resolution creating a home ownership promotion zone; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1004(1)(a)(ii): takes public comment on a proposed home ownership promotion zone.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1004(1)(b): A hearing under this section may be combined with any other public meeting of a legislative body of a municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1004(2): 10-9a-1002 Before a municipality creates a home ownership promotion zone as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1004(3): 63G-30-102 The notice required by Subsection (2) shall be given by:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1004(3)(a): 63G-30-102 publishing notice for the municipality, as a class A notice under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1004(3)(b): at least 30 days before the hearing, mailing notice to:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1004(3)(b)(i): each record owner of property located within the proposed home ownership promotion zone;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1004(3)(b)(ii): the State Tax Commission;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1004(3)(b)(iii): the assessor and auditor of the county in which the proposed home ownership promotion zone is located; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1004(3)(b)(iv): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1004(3)(b)(iv)(A): if the proposed home ownership promotion zone is subject to a taxing entity committee, each member of the taxing entity committee and the State Board of Education; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1004(3)(b)(iv)(B): if the proposed home ownership promotion zone is not subject to a taxing entity committee, the legislative body or governing board of each taxing entity within the boundaries of the proposed home ownership promotion zone.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1004(4): The mailing of the notice to record property owners required under Subsection (3)(b) shall be conclusively considered to have been properly completed if:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1004(4)(a): the agency mails the notice to the property owners as shown in the records, including an electronic database, of the county recorder's office and at the addresses shown in those records; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1004(4)(b): the county recorder's office records used by the agency in identifying owners to whom the notice is mailed and their addresses were obtained or accessed from the county recorder's office no earlier than 30 days before the mailing.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1004(5): The municipality shall include in each notice required under this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1004(5)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1004(5)(a)(i): a boundary description of the proposed home ownership promotion zone; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1004(5)(a)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1004(5)(a)(ii)(A): a mailing address or telephone number where a person may request that a copy of the boundary description of the proposed home ownership promotion zone be sent at no cost to the person by mail, email, or facsimile transmission; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1004(5)(a)(ii)(B): if the agency or community has an Internet website, an Internet address where a person may gain access to an electronic, printable copy of the boundary description of the proposed home ownership promotion zone;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1004(5)(b): a map of the boundaries of the proposed home ownership promotion zone;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1004(5)(c): an explanation of the purpose of the hearing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1004(5)(d): a statement of the date, time, and location of the hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1004(6): The municipality shall include in each notice under Subsection (3)(b):
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1004(6)(a): a statement that property tax revenue resulting from an increase in valuation of property within the proposed home ownership promotion zone will be paid to the municipality for proposed home ownership promotion zone development rather than to the taxing entity to which the tax revenue would otherwise have been paid; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1004(6)(b): an invitation to the recipient of the notice to submit to the municipality comments concerning the subject matter of the hearing before the date of the hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1004(7): A municipality may include in a notice under Subsection (2) any other information the municipality considers necessary or advisable, including the public purpose achieved by the proposed home ownership promotion zone.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1005 Payment, use, and administration of revenue from a home ownership promotion zone.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1005(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1005(1)(a): A municipality may receive tax increment and use home ownership promotion zone funds in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1005(1)(b): The maximum amount of time that a municipality may receive and use tax increment pursuant to a home ownership promotion zone is 15 consecutive years.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1005(2): 59-2-1365 A county that collects property tax on property located within a home ownership promotion zone shall, in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1005(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1005(3)(a): Tax increment distributed to a municipality in accordance with Subsection (2) is not revenue of the taxing entity or municipality, but home ownership promotion zone funds.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1005(3)(b): Home ownership promotion zone funds may be administered by an agency created by the municipality within which the home ownership promotion zone is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1005(3)(c): Before an agency may receive home ownership promotion zone funds from a municipality, the agency shall enter into an interlocal agreement with the municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1005(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1005(4)(a): A municipality or agency shall use home ownership promotion zone funds within, or for the direct benefit of, the home ownership promotion zone.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1005(4)(b): If any home ownership promotion zone funds will be used outside of the home ownership promotion zone, the legislative body of the municipality shall make a finding that the use of the home ownership promotion zone funds outside of the home ownership promotion zone will directly benefit the home ownership promotion zone.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1005(5): 10-9a-1003 A municipality or agency shall use home ownership promotion zone funds to achieve the purposes described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1005(5)(a): project improvement costs;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1005(5)(b): systems improvement costs; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1005(5)(c): the costs of the municipality or agency to create and administer the home ownership promotion zone, which may not exceed 3% of the total home ownership promotion zone funds.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1005(6): Home ownership promotion zone funds may be paid to a participant, if the municipality and participant enter into a participation agreement which requires the participant to utilize the home ownership promotion zone funds as allowed in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1005(7): Home ownership promotion zone funds may be used to pay all of the costs of bonds issued by the municipality in accordance with Title 17C, Chapter 1, Part 5, Agency Bonds, including the cost to issue and repay the bonds including interest.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1005(8): A municipality may:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1005(8)(a): create one or more public infrastructure districts within a home ownership promotion zone under Title 17D, Chapter 4, Public Infrastructure District Act; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-9a-1005(8)(b): pledge and utilize the home ownership promotion zone funds to guarantee the payment of public infrastructure bonds issued by a public infrastructure district.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 10 - Chapter 15 - Pedestrian Mall Law of Utah
*************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 10-15-1 Short title.
------------------------------------------
This act may be cited as the "Pedestrian Mall Law of Utah."

Utah Code Annotated § 10-15-2 Legislative findings and purposes.
----------------------------------------------------------------
The Legislature hereby finds and declares that in certain areas in municipalities within the state, and particularly in retail shopping areas thereof, there is need to separate pedestrian travel from vehicular travel and that such separation is necessary to protect the public safety or otherwise to serve the public interest and convenience. The Legislature further finds and declares that such objectives can, in part, be accomplished by the establishment of pedestrian malls pursuant to this act.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-15-3 Definitions.
------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 10-15-3(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-15-3(1)(a): "Intersection street" means any street which meets or crosses a pedestrian mall at a mall intersection but includes only those portions thereof on either side of the mall intersection which lie between the mall intersection and the first intersection of the intersecting street with a public street or highway open to vehicular traffic.  If any portion of a pedestrian mall terminates on a street at a place thereon other than at a place of intersection with a public street or highway open to vehicular traffic, such intersecting street shall also include that portion of any street which lies between such place of termination and the first intersection of such street with the public street or highway open to vehicular traffic.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-15-3(1)(b): "Intersecting street" also includes any other street or portion of a street which the legislative body declares to be such by resolution.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-15-3(2): "Legislative body" means the legislative body of the municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-15-3(3): "Mall intersection" means any intersection of a street constituting a part of a pedestrian mall with any street which intersection is itself part of a pedestrian mall.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-15-3(4): "Municipality" includes every city or town within this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-15-3(5): "Pedestrian mall" means one or more streets or portions thereof, on which vehicular traffic is, or is to be, restricted in whole or in part and which is, or is to be, used exclusively or primarily for pedestrian travel.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-15-3(6): "Street" means any public road, street, highway, alley, lane, court, way, or place of any nature open to the use of the public, excluding state highways.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-15-4 Powers of legislative body of municipality.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
The legislative body of the municipalities of this state shall have the power:Utah Code Annotated § 10-15-4(1): to establish pedestrian malls;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-15-4(2): to prohibit, in whole or in part, vehicular traffic on a pedestrian mall;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-15-4(3): to pay from the general funds of the municipality, or from other available money, or from the proceeds of assessments levied on land benefited by the establishment of a pedestrian mall, the damages, if any, allowed or awarded to any property owner by reason of the establishment of the pedestrian mall;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-15-4(4): to acquire, construct, and maintain on the municipality's streets which are established as a pedestrian mall, improvements of any kind or nature necessary or convenient to the operation of such streets as a pedestrian mall, including paving, sidewalks, curbs, gutters, sewers, drainage works, lighting facilities, fire protection facilities, flood protection facilities, water distribution facilities, vehicular parking areas, retaining walls, landscaping, tree planting, statuaries, fountains, decorative structures, benches, rest rooms, child care facilities, display facilities, information booths, public assembly facilities, and other structures, works or improvements necessary or convenient to serve members of the public using such pedestrian malls, including the reconstruction or relocation of existing municipally owned works, improvements, or facilities on such municipal streets; which foregoing changes or any portions thereof, are referred to in this act as "improvements";
Utah Code Annotated § 10-15-4(5): Title 11, Chapter 42, Assessment Area Act to pay from the general funds of the municipality or other available money, or from the proceeds of assessments levied on property benefited by any such improvements, or from the proceeds of special improvement warrants or bonds, the whole or any portion of the costs of acquisition, construction, and maintenance of such improvements in accordance with the provisions of
Utah Code Annotated § 10-15-4(6): to do any and all other acts or things necessary or convenient for the accomplishment of the purposes of this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-15-5 Powers of acquisition and improvement.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
The legislative body of the municipalities shall also have the power to acquire by gift, purchase, eminent domain, or otherwise, land, real property or rights of way which shall become part of the municipal street established as a pedestrian mall, or which shall otherwise be used by the municipality as a part of, or for purposes connected with, a pedestrian mall, and such lands, real property or rights of way may be improved in the same manner as municipal streets may be improved. The legislative body shall also have the power to make such improvements on mall intersections and intersecting streets or upon facilities acquired for parking and other related purposes where such improvements are necessary or convenient to the operation of the mall. The acquisitions and improvements authorized by this section shall be deemed "improvements."

Utah Code Annotated § 10-15-6 Public hearing -- Finance requirements.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
The designation of any street as a "mall" shall be by ordinance passed and published after full investigation and ample public hearing into the necessity and advisability of the creation of a mall.  The ordinance shall designate the manner in which the project is to be financed, and, if financed by levy of special taxes or special improvement warrants or bonds, shall be in accordance with the provisions of

Utah Code Annotated - Title 10 - Chapter 18 - Municipal Cable Television and Public Telecommunications Services Act
*******************************************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-101 Title -- Policy statement.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-101(1): This chapter is known as the "Municipal Cable Television and Public Telecommunications Services Act."
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-101(2): The Legislature finds that it is the policy of this state to:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-101(2)(a): ensure that cable television services and public telecommunications services are provided through fair competition consistent with the federal Telecommunications Act of 1996, Pub. L. 104-104, in order to provide the widest possible diversity of information and news sources to the general public;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-101(2)(b): advance the exercise of rights under the First Amendment of the Constitution of the United States;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-101(2)(c): enhance the development and widespread use of technological advances in providing cable television services and public telecommunications services;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-101(2)(d): encourage improved customer service of cable television services and public telecommunications services at competitive rates;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-101(2)(e): ensure that cable television services and public telecommunications services are each provided within a consistent, comprehensive, and nondiscriminatory federal, state, and local government framework; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-101(2)(f): ensure that when a municipality provides to its inhabitants cable television services, public telecommunications services, or both, and competes with private providers whose activities are regulated by the municipality, the municipality does not discriminate against the competing providers of the same services.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(1): "Cable television service" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(1)(a): the one-way transmission to subscribers of:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(1)(a)(i): video programming; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(1)(a)(ii): other programming service; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(1)(b): subscriber interaction, if any, that is required for the selection or use of:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(1)(b)(i): the video programming; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(1)(b)(ii): other programming service.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(2): "Capital costs" means all costs of providing a service that are capitalized in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(3): "Cross subsidize" means to pay a cost included in the direct costs or indirect costs of providing a service that is not accounted for in the full cost of accounting of providing the service.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(4): (4)(a) "Direct costs" means those expenses of a municipality that:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(4)(a): are directly attributable to providing:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(4)(a)(i): a cable television service; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(4)(a)(ii): a public telecommunications service; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(4)(b): (4)(a) would be eliminated if the service described in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(5)(a): cable television service; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(5)(b): public telecommunications service.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(6)(a): "Full-cost accounting" means the accounting of all costs incurred by a municipality in providing:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(6)(a)(i): a cable television service; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(6)(a)(ii): a public telecommunications service.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(6)(b): The costs included in a full-cost accounting include all:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(6)(b)(i): capital costs;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(6)(b)(ii): direct costs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(6)(b)(iii): indirect costs.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(7)(a): "Indirect costs" means any costs:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(7)(a)(i): identified with two or more services or other functions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(7)(a)(ii): that are not directly identified with a single service or function.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(7)(b): "Indirect costs" may include cost factors for:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(7)(b)(i): administration;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(7)(b)(ii): accounting;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(7)(b)(iii): personnel;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(7)(b)(iv): purchasing;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(7)(b)(v): legal support; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(7)(b)(vi): other staff or departmental support.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(8): "Private provider" means a person that:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(8)(a): provides:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(8)(a)(i): cable television services; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(8)(a)(ii): public telecommunications services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(8)(b): is a private entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(9): "Public telecommunications service" means the two-way transmission of signs, signals, writing, images, sounds, messages, data, or other information of any nature by wire, radio, lightwaves, or other electromagnetic means offered to the public generally.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(10): 10-18-105(2) "Public telecommunications service facilities" means a facility described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(11): "Subscribers" means a person that lawfully receives:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(11)(a): cable television services; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-102(11)(b): public telecommunications services.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-103 Antitrust immunity.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-103(1): 76-10-3109 When a municipality is offering or providing a cable television service or public telecommunications service, the immunity from antitrust liability afforded to political subdivisions of the state under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-103(2): A municipality that provides a cable television service or a public telecommunications service is subject to applicable antitrust liabilities under the federal Local Government Antitrust Act of 1984, 15 U.S.C. Secs. 34 to 36.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-106 Severability.
---------------------------------------------
If any provision of this chapter or the application of any provision of this chapter is found invalid, the remainder of this chapter shall be given effect without the invalid provision or application.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-201 Limitations on providing a cable television and public telecommunications services.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-201(1): Except as provided in this chapter, a municipality may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-201(1)(a): provide to one or more subscribers:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-201(1)(a)(i): a cable television service; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-201(1)(a)(ii): a public telecommunications service; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-201(1)(b): for the purpose of providing a cable television service or a public telecommunications service to one or more subscribers, purchase, lease, construct, maintain, or operate any facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-201(2): For purposes of this chapter, a municipality provides a cable television service or public telecommunications service if the municipality provides the service:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-201(2)(a): directly or indirectly, including through an authority or instrumentality:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-201(2)(a)(i): acting on behalf of the municipality; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-201(2)(a)(ii): for the benefit of the municipality;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-201(2)(b): by itself;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-201(2)(c): through:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-201(2)(c)(i): a partnership; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-201(2)(c)(ii): joint venture; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-201(2)(d): by contract, resale, or otherwise.

Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-303 General operating limitations -- Notice of change to price list.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-306 Enforcement and appeal.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-306(1): Before a person that is or is likely to have a substantial interest affected by a municipality's violation of this chapter may file an action in district court for violation of this chapter, that person shall file a written complaint with the municipality in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-306(2): (2)(a); (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-306(2)(a): A municipality that provides a cable television service or a public telecommunications service shall enact an ordinance establishing a procedure for the filing and resolution of complaints relating to the municipality providing:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-306(2)(a)(i): a cable television service; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-306(2)(a)(ii): a public telecommunications service.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-306(2)(b): (2)(a); (1) The procedure required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-306(2)(b)(i): (1) permit any person described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-306(2)(b)(i)(A): an individual subscriber; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-306(2)(b)(i)(B): a private provider that competes with the municipality in the geographic boundaries of the municipality;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-306(2)(b)(ii): establish an expedited process that requires within 45 days after the date the complaint is filed:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-306(2)(b)(ii)(A): that a hearing be held, unless the parties to the proceeding waive the requirement of a hearing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-306(2)(b)(ii)(B): the issuance of a final decision; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-306(2)(b)(iii): provide that failure to render a decision within the time allotted shall be treated as an adverse decision for purposes of appeal.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-18-306(3): Appeal of an adverse decision from the municipality may be taken to the district court for a de novo proceeding.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 10 - Chapter 19 - Municipal Electric Utility Carbon Emission Reduction Act
******************************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Municipal Electric Utility Carbon Emission Reduction Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(1): 10-19-201 "Adjusted retail electric sales" means the total kilowatt-hours of retail electric sales of a municipal electric utility to customers in this state in a calendar year, reduced by:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(1)(a): the amount of those kilowatt-hours attributable to electricity generated or purchased in that calendar year from qualifying zero carbon emissions generation and qualifying carbon sequestration generation;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(1)(b): 10-19-201 the amount of those kilowatt-hours attributable to electricity generated or purchased in that calendar year from generation located within the geographic boundary of the Western Electricity Coordinating Council that derives its energy from one or more of the following but that does not satisfy the definition of a clean energy source or that otherwise has not been used to satisfy Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(1)(b)(i): wind energy;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(1)(b)(ii): solar photovoltaic and solar thermal energy;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(1)(b)(iii): wave, tidal, and ocean thermal energy;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(1)(b)(iv): except for combustion of wood that has been treated with chemical preservatives such as creosote, pentachlorophenol or chromated copper arsenate, biomass and biomass byproducts, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(1)(b)(iv)(A): organic waste;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(1)(b)(iv)(B): forest or rangeland woody debris from harvesting or thinning conducted to improve forest or rangeland ecological health and to reduce wildfire risk;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(1)(b)(iv)(C): agricultural residues;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(1)(b)(iv)(D): dedicated energy crops; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(1)(b)(iv)(E): landfill gas or biogas produced from organic matter, wastewater, anaerobic digesters, or municipal solid waste;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(1)(b)(v): geothermal energy;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(1)(b)(vi): hydro-electric energy; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(1)(b)(vii): waste gas and waste heat capture or recovery; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(1)(c): the number of kilowatt-hours attributable to reductions in retail sales in that calendar year from activities or programs promoting electric energy efficiency or conservation or more efficient management of electric energy load.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(2): "Amount of kilowatt-hours attributable to electricity generated or purchased in that calendar year from qualifying carbon sequestration generation," for qualifying carbon sequestration generation, means the kilowatt-hours supplied by a facility during the calendar year multiplied by the ratio of the amount of carbon dioxide captured from the facility and sequestered to the sum of the amount of carbon dioxide captured from the facility and sequestered plus the amount of carbon dioxide emitted from the facility during the same calendar year.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(3): "Banked renewable energy certificate" means a bundled or unbundled renewable energy certificate that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(3)(a): not used in a calendar year to comply with this part or with a renewable energy program in another state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(3)(b): carried forward into a subsequent year.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(4): "Bundled renewable energy certificate" means a renewable energy certificate for qualifying electricity that is acquired:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(4)(a): by a municipal electric utility by a trade, purchase, or other transfer of electricity that includes the renewable energy attributes of, or certificate that is issued for, the electricity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(4)(b): by a municipal electric utility by generating the electricity for which the renewable energy certificate is issued.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5): 54-7-12.8 "Clean energy source" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(a): an electric generation facility or generation capability or upgrade that becomes operational on or after January 1, 1995, that derives energy from one or more of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(a)(i): wind energy;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(a)(ii): solar photovoltaic and solar thermal energy;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(a)(iii): wave, tidal, and ocean thermal energy;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(a)(iv): except for combustion of wood that has been treated with chemical preservatives such as creosote, pentachlorophenol or chromated copper arsenate, biomass and biomass byproducts, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(a)(iv)(A): organic waste;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(a)(iv)(B): forest or rangeland woody debris from harvesting or thinning conducted to improve forest or rangeland ecological health and to reduce wildfire risk;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(a)(iv)(C): agricultural residues;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(a)(iv)(D): dedicated energy crops; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(a)(iv)(E): landfill gas or biogas produced from organic matter, wastewater, anaerobic digesters, or municipal solid waste;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(a)(v): geothermal energy located outside the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(a)(vi): waste gas and waste heat capture or recovery, including methane gas from:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(a)(vi)(A): an abandoned coal mine; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(a)(vi)(B): a coal degassing operation associated with a state-approved mine permit;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(a)(vii): efficiency upgrades to a hydroelectric facility, without regard to the date upon which the facility became operational, if the upgrades become operational on or after January 1, 1995;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(a)(viii): a compressed air energy storage process, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(a)(viii)(A): the process used to compress the air is a renewable energy source and the associated renewable energy certificates are retired for the purpose of the compressed air energy storage process; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(a)(viii)(B): equivalent renewable energy certificates are obtained and retired for the purpose of the compressed air energy storage process;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(a)(ix): municipal solid waste;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(a)(x): nuclear fuel; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(a)(xi): carbon capture utilization and sequestration;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(b): any of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(b)(i): up to 50 average megawatts of electricity per year per municipal electric utility from a certified low-impact hydroelectric facility, without regard to the date upon which the facility becomes operational, if the facility is certified as a low-impact hydroelectric facility on or after January 1, 1995, by a national certification organization;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(b)(ii): geothermal energy if located within the state, without regard to the date upon which the facility becomes operational; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(b)(iii): hydroelectric energy if located within the state, without regard to the date upon which the facility becomes operational;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(c): hydrogen gas derived from any source of energy described in Subsection (5)(a) or (b);
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(d): if an electric generation facility employs multiple energy sources, that portion of the electricity generated that is attributable to energy sources described in Subsections (5)(a) through (c); and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(e): 54-7-12.8 any of the following located in the state and owned by a user of energy:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(e)(i): 54-7-12.8 a demand side management measure, as defined by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(e)(ii): a solar thermal system that reduces the consumption of fossil fuels, with the quantity of renewable energy certificates to which the user is entitled determined by the equivalent kilowatt-hours saved, except to the extent the commission determines otherwise with respect to net-metered energy;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(e)(iii): a solar photovoltaic system that reduces the consumption of fossil fuels with the quantity of renewable energy certificates to which the user is entitled determined by the total production of the system, except to the extent the commission determines otherwise with respect to net-metered energy;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(e)(iv): a hydroelectric or geothermal facility, with the quantity of renewable energy certificates to which the user is entitled determined by the total production of the facility, except to the extent the commission determines otherwise with respect to net-metered energy;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(e)(v): a waste gas or waste heat capture or recovery system other than from a combined cycle combustion turbine that does not use waste gas or waste heat, with the quantity of renewable energy certificates to which the user is entitled determined by the total production of the system, except to the extent the commission determines otherwise with respect to net-metered energy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(5)(e)(vi): the station use of solar thermal energy, solar photovoltaic energy, hydroelectric energy, geothermal energy, waste gas, or waste heat capture and recovery.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(6): "Commission" means the Public Service Commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(7): "Municipal electric utility" means any municipality that owns, operates, controls, or manages a facility that provides electric power for a retail customer, whether domestic, commercial, industrial, or otherwise.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(8): "Qualifying carbon sequestration generation" means a fossil-fueled generating facility located within the geographic boundary of the Western Electricity Coordinating Council that:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(8)(a): becomes operational or is retrofitted on or after January 1, 2008; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(8)(b): reduces carbon dioxide emissions into the atmosphere through permanent geological sequestration or through other verifiably permanent reductions in carbon dioxide emissions through the use of technology.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(9): "Qualifying electricity" means electricity generated on or after January 1, 1995 from a renewable energy source if:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(9)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(9)(a)(i): the clean energy source is located within the geographic boundary of the Western Electricity Coordinating Council; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(9)(a)(ii): the qualifying electricity is delivered to the transmission system of a municipal electric utility or a delivery point designated by the municipal electric utility for the purpose of subsequent delivery to the municipal electric utility; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(9)(b): the clean energy attributes of the electricity are not traded, sold, transferred, or otherwise used to satisfy another state's renewable energy program.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(10): 10-19-201 "Qualifying zero carbon emissions generation":
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(10)(a): means a generation facility located within the geographic boundary of the Western Electricity Coordinating Council that:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(10)(a)(i): becomes operational on or after January 1, 2008; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(10)(a)(ii): does not produce carbon as a byproduct of the generation process;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(10)(b): includes generation powered by nuclear fuel; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(10)(c): 10-19-201 does not include clean energy sources used to satisfy a target established under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(11): 10-19-202; 54-17-603 "Renewable energy certificate" means a certificate issued in accordance with the requirements of Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(12): "Unbundled renewable energy certificate" means a renewable energy certificate associated with:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(12)(a): qualifying electricity that is acquired by a municipal electric utility or other person by trade, purchase, or other transfer without acquiring the electricity for which the certificate was issued; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-102(12)(b): activities listed in Subsection (5)(e).


Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-201 Target amount of qualifying electricity -- Renewable energy certificate -- Cost-effectiveness.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-201(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-201(1)(a): To the extent that it is cost-effective to do so, beginning in 2025 the annual retail electric sales in this state of each municipal electric utility shall consist of qualifying electricity or renewable energy certificates in an amount equal to at least 20% of adjusted retail electric sales.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-201(1)(b): The amount under Subsection (1)(a) is computed based upon adjusted retail sales for the calendar year commencing 36 months before the first day of the year for which the target calculated under Subsection (1)(a) applies.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-201(1)(c): Notwithstanding Subsections (1)(a) and (b) an increase in the annual target from one year to the next is limited to the greater of:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-201(1)(c)(i): 17,500 megawatt-hours; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-201(1)(c)(ii): 20% of the prior year's amount under Subsections (1)(a) and (b).
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-201(2): Cost-effectiveness under Subsection (1) is determined using any criteria applicable to the municipal electric utility's acquisition of a significant energy resource established by the municipality's legislative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-201(3): This section does not require a municipal electric utility to:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-201(3)(a): substitute qualifying electricity for electricity from a generation source owned or contractually committed, or from a contractual commitment for a power purchase;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-201(3)(b): enter into any additional electric sales commitment or any other arrangement for the sale or other disposition of electricity that is not already, or would not be, entered into by the municipal electric utility; or
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-201(3)(c): acquire qualifying electricity in excess of its adjusted retail electric sales.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-201(4): A municipal electrical corporation may combine the following to meet Subsection (1):
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-201(4)(a): qualifying electricity from a clean energy source owned by the municipal electric utility;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-201(4)(b): qualifying electricity acquired by the municipal electric utility through trade, power purchase, or other transfer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-201(4)(c): a bundled or unbundled renewable energy certificate, including a banked renewable energy certificate.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-201(5): To meet Subsection (1), a municipal electric utility may also count:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-201(5)(a): qualifying electricity generated or acquired or renewable energy certificates acquired for a program permitting the municipal electric utility's customers to voluntarily contribute to a renewable energy source; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-201(5)(b): electricity allocated to this state that is produced by a hydroelectric facility becoming operational after December 31, 2007, if the hydroelectric facility is located in any state in which the municipal electric utility, or the interlocal entity with which the municipal electric utility has a contract, provides electric service.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-202 Renewable energy certificate -- Use to satisfy other requirements.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-202(1): 54-17-603 A municipal electric utility may buy, sell, trade, or otherwise transfer a renewable energy certificate issued or recognized under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-202(2): 10-19-201; 54-17-603 For the purpose of satisfying Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-202(2)(a): a clean energy source located in this state that derives its energy from solar photovoltaic and solar thermal energy shall be credited for 2.4 kilowatt-hours of qualifying electricity for each 1.0 kilowatt-hour generated; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-202(2)(b): if two or more municipal electric utilities jointly own a renewable energy resource, each municipal electric utility shall be credited with 1.0 kilowatt-hour of qualifying electricity for 1.0 kilowatt-hour of the renewable energy resource allocated to the municipal electric utility by contract, unless the contract otherwise provides.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-202(3): 10-19-201; 10-19-201 A renewable energy certificate:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-202(3)(a): 10-19-201 may be used only once to satisfy Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-202(3)(b): 10-19-201 may be used to satisfy Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-202(3)(c): may not be used if it has been used to satisfy any other state's renewable energy requirement.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-301 Plans and reports.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-301(1): 10-19-201 A municipal electric utility shall develop and maintain a plan for implementing Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-301(2): A progress report concerning a plan under Subsection (1) shall be filed with the municipality's legislative body by January 1 of each of the years 2010, 2015, 2020, and 2024.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-301(3): The progress report under Subsection (2) shall contain:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-301(3)(a): the actual and projected amount of qualifying electricity through 2025;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-301(3)(b): the source of qualifying electricity;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-301(3)(c): an estimate of the cost of achieving the target;
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-301(3)(d): a discussion of conditions impacting the clean energy source and qualifying electricity markets; and
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-301(3)(e): any recommendation for a suggested legislative or program change.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-301(4): The plan and progress report required by Subsections (1) and (2) may include procedures that will be used by the municipal electric utility to identify and select any cost-effective clean energy resource and qualifying electricity.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-301(5): 10-19-201; 10-19-201 By July 1, 2026, the municipal electric utility shall file a final progress report demonstrating:
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-301(5)(a): 10-19-201 how Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-301(5)(b): 10-19-201 the reason why Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-301(6): The plan and any progress report filed under this section shall be publicly available at the municipal legislative body's office.


Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-302 Municipal authority -- Commission authority.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-302(1): The municipal legislative body may adopt procedures necessary to implement this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 10-19-302(2): Nothing in this chapter authorizes the commission to exercise any power over a municipal electric utility's electrical generation, demand-side management program, or other operation.
